story:
Hi Everyone!

I have been living in California studying, practicting, and making herbal medicine for the past three years. I currently work at an amazing herbal shop called Rosemary's Garden, opened in 1974 by the famous herbalist Rosemary Gladstar.

Working at the herbal shop has really shown me that many health problems arise first from poor/unbalanced emotional states, for example; stress, anxiety, the loss of a loved one, relationships, poor self esteem, etc.  These emotional states can become very intense and settle in the body in the form of illness. So in steps Flower Essences!

Flower essences heal us on the spiritual and emotional level because many of our physical ailments stem from deep emotional trauma or abuse that gets stuck and can form blockages, physically and emotionally in the body. Certain flower essences, taken consistently over time, will release these energetic/physical blockages, allowing true healing and optimal health to take place! My goal is to successfully treat those going through intense physical and emotional health problems,using this gentle healing system of vibrational medicine.

 I want to be the best healthcare practioner I can be, but I need your help!

**The money you donate will go directly to pay for the rest of my class and airfare! My last paymentof $800 is due June 1st (out of $1,900) and I'm just not quite there!  My airfare will be an extra $400. Im working as hard as I can, and as often as I can, but still need some help.**

There are some great perks if you donate too!  Everyone will get a hand-written thank you, and many will recieve a flower essence that I will have made in Alaska! It doesn't get any more pristine and pure than that! Herbal teas, salves, and lip balms will be gifted too!

This program will teach me how to better consult one on one with patients, how to better choose the appropriate formulas for them, and how to make the best medicine that I can.  By helping me, I will be able to help others! :)

I set up flexible funding so if I don't reach my goal, the money you donated will still get put directly towards my class. So thank you thank you thank you thank you! I really appreciate your love and support.

Please share if you feel so inclined, and thank you so so much  all my love xoxo

Courtney L. Hall

www.alaskanessences.com

story:
<<Is it deja vu, or did we go on Indiegogo before? You must've thought of our Bus/MAX ad campaign last winter, which was a smashing success: http://igg.me/p/252697/x/1610398>>

<<Video Credit: Joe Kirkland, Portrait of an Occupation>>

 

Over a year ago, a small band of devoted Occupiers came together and created the “St. Francis Working Group” to plan well ahead about evolving our current Office and to prepare for the time if we do decide to move to another location. Now, with numerous General Assembly and Spokes Council approvals, as well as input from Info Team and FoOP, we have reached consensus that we will move to a more efficient and affordable location, but we need YOU to help make that happen.

There are several reasons why this consensus has been reached. Accessibility has always been an issue at St. Francis Parish, as anyone coming into our office can attest. At the current location there is no parking nor a direct entryway, and with none of the windows facing the adjacent street, it is tucked away and easy to pass by. We wanted to downsize so we can begin allocating our funds to events and social projects again and focus less on Rent. Moving to a new location is really an expansion of our movement by making the office more accessible, giving it better exposure and making it more efficient.

Your donations will be used to provide us with the first month, the last month and the security deposit organizations must submit up-front when renting any unit. It will provide us a safety net so we can more quickly allocate our funds to event and social projects.

If you don't have any money, you can still help us out!! While we are to move out and move in by April 15th and have our grand opening May 1st, we have yet to make any finalized agreements, meaning we are open to any tips of for-lease Office Spaces around the Portland metro area. Our preferences are 300-600 square feet for $300-$600 per month, with a window shop being a great bonus. But we are open to any suggestions, so please email us at our Info Email below or call us at 971-258-1006.

Occupy continues to act as a nexus and support for the peace and social justice movement in Portland. This space would be used for committee/working group meetings, meetings for other socioeconomic justice movement groups, a contact point, information dissemination and network hub, a computer lab for activists to use, an art lab for projects related to our movement, and a library (like our current meeting space). We are continually grateful that we are still one of the fewer Occupy branches who has an indoor Office to call home, and are acutely aware of how our long-term success and influence could not have been made possible without it.

We want to be clear, however, that our movement is not in any way centralized or trapped in our Office. So many different groups and offshoots have arose thanks to that fateful day in October 2011. There is an Occupy Beaverton, Occupy Gresham and Occupy St. Johns. There is Portland Action Lab, Community Supported Everything, Culture Mend, Overpass Light Brigade PDX, People’s Budget Committee, The City Hall Vigil, Bike Swarm and The Portland Occupier among others: if it weren’t for Occupy, they may have never came to existance. Of course, the branches don't always acknowledge their roots every time (like budget cuts and Wall St. greed), but us being the root, we are more than impressed how our city is being changed and the people's aspirations bearing fruit. We hope you’ll agree once you take time to redefine grassroots, organizational success.

We have always appreciated our time at St. Francis and want to hold a night of celebration for their gracious cooperation. That includes Red & Black Cafe, a real added bonus whose work and values they’ve been keeping long before we existed. We are in the works of planning this night, stay tuned for the announcement, the calendar post, and the social media RSVPs.

This is a pivotal time to recruit volunteers to staff our Office and join Info Team — if you want to sign up please contact Info Team: occupyportlandinfo@riseup.net or call 971-258-1006. Thanks for the continued, ongoing support: You really ARE the 99% rising up to action.

OCCUPY!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Short Story: 

I need your help to support my trip to Istanbul, where I will be volunteering in the arts sector for three and a half months this summer. In return for your contribution, I would love to give you some art! 

Please note: ignore the monetary value of the listed perks. Just let me know what you would like by emailing laurasthorne@gmail.com. 

About Me

My name is Laura Thorne. I'm a Canadian student, and I'm passionate about arts and culture. 

I currently study liberal arts in Halifax, Nova Scotia. I'm doing two Honours Majors, in Anthropology and Contemporary Philosophy, and a minor in Arabic. I have a 4.2 GPA.

In my spare time, I try to build community through the arts. I am the president of the King's Poetry Society, I have done slam poetry shows on the local radio, and I work for SchoolArts - a program that aims to program more arts into elementary school curriculae. I'm the vice-president of our Best Buddies chapter, an organization that matches students with disabled peers in one-on-one friendships. I'm the President of Residence at my university. I also play varsity rugby, I dance, and I'm a visual artist.

Why You're Reading This

This summer, I have the opportunity to travel to Istanbul, Turkey, in order to put my values to work in a global setting. 

I have been offered a job working at Culture City Foundation - a group dedicated to using culture to solve social problems. I will be working for them full time, throughout the whole summer, without pay. 

So, I need to fundraise a little bit to help me get there! 

What I'll Be Doing

I will be working with Culture City in their program that educates Turkish families about domestic violence against children. It aims for advocacy in the areas of mental health, self-esteem, negligence against children, and anger management. 

I will also be working with a psychological consultant to plan a new project that involves doing street art with autistic children. 

Finally, I'll be helping to plan an Intercultural Art Dialogue - an annual arts festival that brings together artists from 17 different countries. 

Where Your Money Will Go

My summer in Istanbul costs a little more than I can afford. I have a national scholarship that helps me out a lot, and it will be pitching in enough money for my accommodation this summer. 

My goal is to cover the cost of my flights through this campaign. 

Thank you for helping me get there! 

You can follow my travel blog at: http://continentalpress.tumblr.com to follow my adventures this summer!

And you can check out my artwork here: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10150839352650385.735634.514755384&type=1&l=14bb3b1917

story:
Hello, my name is Amy.  My good friend, Robert Fleming, started the Malayaka House orphanage in Uganda, in 2005.  It was very much by chance; he was visiting on a service trip when he encountered a pregnant woman who was mentally ill and living alone on the street.  She didn't even realize she was pregnant.  When she went into labor, Robert took her to the hospital, where she delivered - and abandoned - the baby.  Fast forward 8 years later, to today, and Malayaka House cares for 37 orphaned and abandoned children.  Education is of the utmost importance in Uganda, and all of the children are enrolled in a wonderful school.  However, transporting such a large number of kids to and from school every day is very difficult, and as more children become school-age, it is going to become impossible without a second van.  Robert asked me if I could help by setting up a fundraiser for this project, and I immediately said yes.  But I definitely need some help, and I am hoping that crowdfunding through Indiegogo works out!  Thank you for your support and for reading the story of Malayaka House :)

What We Need

The funding is strictly for the purchase of a 2nd van.  The van will cost more than the $12,000 we are asking for, but we have some outside funding as well, to take care of the difference.  This van will allow all of the children to be taken to and from school with ease, and (most importantly) safely.  If we don't raise the entire $12,000 through Indiegogo, the funds that we DO raise will still go to the purchase of a van.  We will just continue to raise money until our goal is reached. 

The Impact

These children have been shown that although there is pain and suffering in the world, people can be very good.  They have learned to trust again, and they have learned to feel loved and to give love.  Malayaka House is a truly amazing place.  We believe, very strongly, that what has been done for these children, they will do for others.  Places like Uganda need Ugandan citizens who wish to make their country a better place - people who grow up, get an education, get higher education and vocational training, and then spread their knowledge to other Ugandans.  The more knowledge and education in Uganda, the less hunger, poverty and suffering.  The children of Malayaka House will be ambassadors for their country, both within Uganda and abroad.  Malayaka House does not seek to "adopt  out" their children.  They raise and care for their children the way you would care for your own.  Saving for higher education and vocational training, and paying current school fees for primary and secondary school is a top priority, and it is an expensive one.  Therefore, things that seem "less important" like reliable transportation, often take a back seat (no pun intended) to food, education, and health care.  However, that doesn't mean that safe transportation isn't extremely important.  That is why we are asking for your help. 

Helping build stronger communities in Africa helps more than just Africa.  Our children, here in the US, are growing up in a global economy.  They are no longer living under the perception that life on this planet is what they wake up and see every day.  The pain and suffering is real...they see it...and they want it to change.  Our youth are ready to make a difference, and we can help them have less of an uphill battle by providing working examples of how to make an impact in a targeted, focused way.  Through education and knowledge, the youth in places like Uganda will begin to whittle away at the corruption that is so prevalent.  We need to work together to make this a reality.  Malayaka House does more than just help itself.  Through outreach programs, they are teaching other organizations within Uganda how to adopt similar sustainability practices, such as solar panels, biogas, rain-water collection and farming, so that they can provide for themselves in a more reliable, cost effective manner.  Resources that Malayaka House receives for projects, such as this van, help alleviate the time and man/woman power wasted on things such as multiple morning and afternoon trips to school, and allow more time for working on their goal of full sustainability and training other African organizations to do the same. 

Other Ways You Can Help

1.) Another wonderful way of supporting our cause is to help us get the word out! You can visit our web site at www.malayakahouse.com, volunteer at Malayaka House (Uganda is a friendly, welcoming, beautiful country, and volunteering is an experience that will change you forever), or donate to this project.  

2.) We have partnered with The Groove Tea Project on Bobo's Coffee!  This delicious, whole bean Ugandan coffee is roasted in small batches in the US, and 100% of the profits from Bobo's go directly to Malayaka House!  You can purchase today by going to this link - www.groovetea.com/store/adult-tea and scroll down to the bottom of the page, where you'll find Bobo's Coffee!  Bobo's was named after one very special little boy at Malayaka House.  

Thank you so much for your support!!!

story:
Open the Doors to A Future

65 students need your help to get back to school. Our schoolkids have been out of school for over a year. With your help they can be back in school within 4 months!

The schooolhouse provides a safe harbor for 65 at-risk girls to continue their education. In the school program kids learn the basics, plus computer skills, and take part in community projects.

Community projects include the production of maps using OpenStreetMap, articles about local heritage published to Wikipedia, multi-media print and digital art drawing on traditional designs, and our new community garden where the students grow their own food and provide meals for other needy schoolchildren in the area.

Without a schoolhouse all 65 students are out of school. We urgently need your help!

Make A Safe, Beautiful Place

Your small effort today can make a big difference. The program has received a 6 acre land grant for our schoolhouse and community garden.
 
Your contributions will be used to:
  • Build a bamboo schoolhouse
  • Construct tables and chairs

All of our construction will use sustainably-sourced materials and the more we raise the more students that the school can serve.

Contributors! Join in the Fun and Excitement of Building the Future Together!

Student projects in the past have included articles about local heritage and culture, cookbooks, maps of local resources and so much more. With their new skills students return to their local community the ability to shape their own future.
 
And if that's not enough then please do check out these great gifts from all of us here at the program.  A community art map for your and friends, a sampling of savory cuisine, or come and visit us!
  • Taste of Indonesia: Food Starter Kit and CookBook
  • East West Community Art Poster
  • Weekend Ecological Retreat
  • Weeklong Adventure

About the Program

The East West Education program serves disadvantaged girls. 2/3 of Indonesian children don't finish 9th grade, and the majority are girls. Despite the best efforts of the government schools still charge fees for materials, tuition, and uniforms, and these fees add up to a cost that so many families cannot afford.

The program is designed to help students build a commons for  their community. Throughout the program students as individuals learn how their contribution come together to produce real value and change in their community and bring new opportunities and support to their families.  

Through contributions of text articles, video, photos, map data and more th students are documenting their world and learning how to build the future for themselves. Indonesia is gripped by rapid industrialization at the moment and these students will be equipped with some of the skills that their community will need in order to make important chaoices about the future of development in the country.

Local community organizations have already taken note of past efforts by students, and the new site will allow the program to appeal to larger donors and give the students the chance to turn the value of their commons towards supporting themselves. 

Every new thigns starts with something small. Your small effort today can help these kids map their world, and document their heritage. During the last 400 years of colonization and military rule children are risking their lives in dangerous occupational situations. This program is a real chance for them to apply technology and wisdom to both their heritage and their future. With your help this program will have a chance, and with the efforts of the students, programs like this could open all over Indonesia and the world.

your donations help with the start-up costs of the program. We can rely on many local organizations for small monthly contributions to cover incidentals and even some of our staff salary. Larger donors are being sought to help us defray those costs further, and with the progress of a building the program will be completely self-supporting within the secondf year of operation.

Families in Indonesia have a lot of choices to make. They are asking themselves whether they can afford a more nutritious meal for their child or to put gas in their motorcycle fuel tank for another day of seeking work and a way out of unemployment. The minimum wage in the area is $160/month, but there are so few people making this amount that more than 60% of the country is surviving on $2 a day or $60 a month. Though Indonesia is a developing country $2 is not enough to provide nutritious meals when chicken is $3.50/kg and rice is $1/kg. Vegetables are widely available, but the high cost of protein is a real issue. We aren't even talking about the $25-50/month/child for education fees yet.

$42,000 might seem like a lot of money, but this building is being designed to last for 20 years of use on our new land grant to which we have access for 20 years. Our hope is that you will join with us in this stage of our development and stay with us to watch the school grow into a shining light of how education, free and open source, focused on building and educating for the commons, how this can be the seed of something new and exciting that can make a difference for decades to come.

For more information about the program, other ways to give, and to receive priority updates about the program please visit http://www.localroutes.org

*Update - Our program is being considered for an official poverty alleviation program as well as an offical alternative schooling program for the poor by the city government at this time. Your support is more important than ever, helping us to make further inroads to faster susintability and opening the program to even more kids.

story:
At Free Kicks Foundation we raise money to give deserving children (and sometimes adults) days out at football. In 2012, we will celebrate five years since our launch. The idea came about during the 2006 World Cup from a friend of mine, Leigh Porter, who had worked for Sue Ryder but at the time was working for Peterborough United. The idea grew and grew from that day and we launched with a fundraising gig and what is now our annual five-a-side tournament in May 2007.

After much paperwork and red tape we became a registered charity in October that year, after having our first Kicks, as we call them, in August at the pre-season friendly between Posh and Manchester United. Free Kicks is run by myself and my friend Sam around our full time jobs and family commitments. I run the fundraising and administration side, while Sam organises all the Kicks, liaising with hospitals, families and clubs.

Since we started, we have taken nearly 140 deserving children and young adults to matches all over the country. The majority of children we give Kicks to go along to the matches as mascots. This generally involves a tour of the ground, a new kit, visiting the players in the dressing rooms, a kickabout on the pitch and, of course, leading the team out ahead of kickoff.

Most of our Kicks are at Peterborough United matches as this is our team. We do many Kicks at London Road but also at away games, where we treat local children to the experience. Locally the children are nominated by either Peterborough City Hospital, Addenbrookes Hospital in Cambridge or the East Anglian Children’s Hospice, also in Cambridge. For Posh away games we contact local hospitals, hospices or charities and ask them to nominate a fan of the home team for the treat. We also have some Kicks at matches away from Posh, recently at Tottenham, Watford and our first Scottish kick at Glasgow Rangers.

Posh have been brilliant to us over the years. We were even one of their official charities for two seasons and our logo featured on the the third choice shirt for some games when they were last in the Championship, which was obviously a very proud moment for us. During that time, four Posh players agreed to be Free Kicks ambassadors – Joe Lewis and George Boyd are still at Posh but despite moving on, Aaron Mclean of Hull City and Gillingham’s Charlie Lee are still available to help whenever they can.

We fundraise in various ways. We have an annual five-a-side tournament and cricket match, as well as our main fundraiser each year where we like to challenge ourselves and our supporters! We have cycled from Posh to MK Dons, visited all 92 grounds in 92 hours, walked from Posh to Nottingham Forest and this year we walked from Barnet to Wembley Stadium via all other London league grounds, raising over £6,000!

Over the five years we have been running we have raised over £70,000 in total. Next year, amongst other events, we have a team of ten cycling from Posh to Paris over the course of four days. Since we got involved in using Twitter we have also had generous support from fans of other clubs. One of the most notable gestures came from Millwall fans who last season donated all the profits from the sale of their fanzine, No One Likes Us.

All the people we meet are inspirational in one way or another. The looks on their faces when they get to meet the players or get to go on the tour of the grounds and see behind the scenes makes all the hard work worthwhile.

Adam took part in one of our first Kicks. We managed to arrange for him to watch a game at Stamford Bridge from the players lounge and he also got to meet John Terry, who gave him his shirt and captain’s armband from the game. Sadly later that year, Adam passed away and this is what his mum Rachel wrote for us about Adam’s day and what it meant to him and his family:

Adam had been a fan of Chelsea for a few years before he was diagnosed with cancer. When Free Kicks Foundation offered him a VIP trip to see Chelsea play, he was more than anything overwhelmed, as was I, that he was being given such an amazing treat just for being ill (as he would put it). We watched the game from the players lounge with some of the players’ families and one of the players willingly had his picture taken with Adam, despite Adam not wanting to bother him!

After the game, we were taken behind the scenes downstairs to where the players were and Adam was taken through to meet the players. He was nervous and excited. When he came back he had tears in his eyes and said “Mum, John Terry gave me his shirt and his Premiership captain’s armband”, which he had apparently never given away before. He was just so overwhelmed and happy and for me to see him smiling and excited like that after everything meant so much.

The experience continued when four months later, a few weeks before he died, Adam received a package from Chelsea for his birthday with gifts and a card hand-written from John Terry and Frank Lampard. He couldn’t believe it. He kept saying “Mum, are they real? Are they really from them?” It was an unforgettable, touching experience for Adam and the whole family – the shirt, armband and cards are all in a huge frame on the wall.

We still stay in touch with Rachel, she did a skydive for us and kindly agreed for us to name our annual five-a-side tournament after Adam.

During the rest of the season, we have Kicks taking place at Posh away games at Burnley, Doncaster, Crystal Palace, Ipswich and Derby as well as more at London Road. We are also hoping to go back to one of our favourite clubs, Huddersfield Town, plus we are trying to organise days out at Everton and QPR. Our aim is to eventually have a Kick at every club in the country. When we visited Hull last Saturday, we were exactly halfway through the 92! We would also like to do more in Scotland and maybe even Europe!

We fundraise in various ways. We have an annual five-a-side tournament and cricket match, as well as our main fundraiser each year where we like to challenge ourselves and our supporters! We have cycled from Posh to MK Dons, visited all 92 grounds in 92 hours, walked from Posh to Nottingham Forest and this year we walked from Barnet to Wembley Stadium via all other London league grounds, raising over £6,000!
Over the five years we have been running we have raised over £70,000 in total. Next year, amongst other events, we have a team of ten cycling from Posh to Paris over the course of four days. Since we got involved in using Twitter we have also had generous support from fans of other clubs. One of the most notable gestures came from Millwall fans who last season donated all the profits from the sale of their fanzine, No One Likes Us.
All the people we meet are inspirational in one way or another. The looks on their faces when they get to meet the players or get to go on the tour of the grounds and see behind the scenes makes all the hard work worthwhile.
Adam took part in one of our first Kicks. We managed to arrange for him to watch a game at Stamford Bridge from the players lounge and he also got to meet John Terry, who gave him his shirt and captain’s armband from the game. Sadly later that year, Adam passed away and this is what his mum Rachel wrote for us about Adam’s day and what it meant to him and his family:

Adam had been a fan of Chelsea for a few years before he was diagnosed with cancer. When Free Kicks Foundation offered him a VIP trip to see Chelsea play, he was more than anything overwhelmed, as was I, that he was being given such an amazing treat just for being ill (as he would put it). We watched the game from the players lounge with some of the players’ families and one of the players willingly had his picture taken with Adam, despite Adam not wanting to bother him!
After the game, we were taken behind the scenes downstairs to where the players were and Adam was taken through to meet the players. He was nervous and excited. When he came back he had tears in his eyes and said “Mum, John Terry gave me his shirt and his Premiership captain’s armband”, which he had apparently never given away before. He was just so overwhelmed and happy and for me to see him smiling and excited like that after everything meant so much.
The experience continued when four months later, a few weeks before he died, Adam received a package from Chelsea for his birthday with gifts and a card hand-written from John Terry and Frank Lampard. He couldn’t believe it. He kept saying “Mum, are they real? Are they really from them?” It was an unforgettable, touching experience for Adam and the whole family – the shirt, armband and cards are all in a huge frame on the wall.

We still stay in touch with Rachel, she did a skydive for us and kindly agreed for us to name our annual five-a-side tournament after Adam.
During the rest of the season, we have Kicks taking place at Posh away games at Burnley, Doncaster, Crystal Palace, Ipswich and Derby as well as more at London Road. We are also hoping to go back to one of our favourite clubs, Huddersfield Town, plus we are trying to organise days out at Everton and QPR. Our aim is to eventually have a Kick at every club in the country. When we visited Hull last Saturday, we were exactly halfway through the 92! We would also like to do more in Scotland and maybe even Europe!

story:
Let's Help the Wexford Children's Center Upgrade their Kitchen!

 

The other day as we were helping prepare the Thanksgiving Feast for my daughter's 4 yr old preschool class, I noticed how old the stove and other appliances are at the Wexford Childrens Center.  Literally the stove uses white plastic push buttons.  I would like to raise money to purchase a new stove and other equipment for their kitchen, possibly a new microwave, pots and pans, maybe a mixer, etc.  This is a wonderful school and they love our kids and do a fantastic job, so this holiday season I would like to give back and show how much we all appreciate their hard work. All proceeds go to the Wexford Childrens Center.

All proceeds go to the Wexford Childrens Center.

story:
Background

Poor foundational skills in English and Maths are among the greatest barriers to future educational and employment opportunities for children living in South African townships.  Education without Borders (EwB) (www.educationwithoutborders.ca) is addressing these barriers by providing a tutoring program that is designed to instill a love of learning among primary and secondary learners. 

Program Goal

Our goal is to enhance EwB’s tutoring program by fully integrating e-Learning into our academic curriculum at Fezeka Secondary School in Gugulethu township, Cape Town.  Providing e-Learning opportunities for disadvantaged children is empowering, offering them the chance to become excited, focused and driven in their schooling.  We need your help to make this happen!

E-Learning

Education without Borders’ e-Learning program will use the Social Project’s School-in-a-Box (https://schoolinabox.co.za) which provides tablet-based lessons.  The curriculum provided by the tablets you're helping raise money for provides ten in-depth, engaging, and standard-aligned subjects for our learners.

Education without Borders’ primary focus is centered around English and Maths. Half of the subjects provided through the tablets directly align with this focus and give the learners a wide range of material to work with according to their skill level. The other five subjects (Natural Science, Science, Computer Technology, Afrikaans, and Business) will also be used by the learners, but as a secondary focus.

Program Impact

The learners at Fezeka Secondary School are incredibly disadvantaged. For a myriad of reasons, these children simply do not get a quality education, which severely limits the opportunities they have after their schooling is complete. Education is the best way to empower children and give them the chance to succeed and break the mold of their current life. 

Education without Border’s e-Learning program greatly increases the chances of empowering our learners and helping them succeed. Through the material provided on the tablets, supplemented by our already established curriculum, we’re able to bring EwB’s program to a new level of efficacy and modernity to create an environment where our learners are excited and driven to better themselves.

To be ‘job ready’, one needs to be technology literate. EwB learners are at a disadvantage due to lack of opportunities, including access to technology. Simply giving EwB learners the chance to work with, use, manipulate and interact with technology through e-Learning makes future employment success a more attainable goal.

Fundraising Goal

Education without Borders has set $3,500 as our fundraising goal to implement this game-changing, as well as life-changing, opportunity for our learners. Every cent donated towards this program goes straight into the purchase of a complete set of these tablets. The closer we get to our goal, the quicker we will be able to integrate it into the academic programs EwB offers.

Spread the Word

Please help us achieve our goal by sharing this with a friend or organization that could help. We greatly appreciate your support!

story:
Savannah Kaitlyn Hintze died Monday, April 25, 2011 (24 days after her 18th birthday) in Russellville, Arkansas as the result of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Savannah was on her way home from school when her car hydroplaned and struck a tree. Savannah's 6 year old brother, Logan was in the car with her and fortunately survived unharmed. Logan ran out to the road to wave for help and miraculously, someone he and Savannah knew, came by and called 911. We lost a beautiful person, but heaven gained an angel.



In August of 2011 students began to raise money in Savannah's name. Our goal is to give a scholarship in Savannah's name to a deserving Russellville High School student each year that represents the same characteristics as Savannah. Over the 2011-12 school year, RHS students worked a booth at football games, cooked pancakes, sold t-shirts, made bracelets and engaged in other activities to raise money to try to make the Savannah Kaitlyn Hintze Memorial Scholarship Fund a reality (also knows as "The Sunshine Fund"). Their efforts so far have raised $7,000. We need to raise $25,000 overall in order to endow the scholarship so it can be given in perpetuity.

We would be so appreciative if you could help these students, along with Savannah's mother Ingrid, in order to realize their goal of keeping this remarkable girl's memory alive by helping a deserving student go to college. In order to qualify for the scholarship, students must write a one page nomination letter indicating their desire for the Sunshine Scholarship. Students are encouraged to share the presence of a positive attitude and openness to all people, cultures, orientations and ideas. Savannah's mother will not feel at peace until this scholarship is endowed and knows that the passing of her daughter will forever help others.

ABOUT SAVANNAH
I'm sitting here typing this trying to figure out how best to describe Savannah, and I have no idea where to start. Savannah was honestly indescribable. She was one of those people that always made you feel happy to be around. She was beautiful inside and out and had a smile that would warm anyone's heart. She was generous, humble and literally full of sunshine. She made friends with everyone and had a laugh that was contagious. She was silly and funny and always had something nice to say when she saw you. She was honest, earnest and hard-working. Savannah was always the first to give everything she had - whether that was giving whatever money she had to someone in need or volunteering her time and talents. She came from a very modest means, but never asked for a thing from anyone. Savannah inspired hundreds and her passing devastated and silenced her entire high school, just four weeks before graduation.

Savannah's father, "J.K." died when she was only three years old. That loss caused her to see the unique value in every single day. She loved her family and her friends passionately. Investing in people rather than things was her daily goal. Always independent, at the age of three, Savannah insisted on dressing herself, fixing her own hair and painting her nails. However, on the first day of kindergarten she told her mom that she could "play mom" and do those things for her since this was such a special day for her (special for mom). Savannah is buried in Salt Lake City next to her father.

 


A celebration of Savannah's life was held on Saturday, April 30, 2011 in Russellville, Arkansas. Hundreds of people wearing tie-dye attended. Her cousins sang her favorite songs and lots of people said wonderful things about Savannah and how she impacted their lives. It was a true memorial to Savannah.

           

LOGAN
Savannah's little brother Logan received a medal of bravery at her memorial service.



SAVANNAH BRACELETS
"Savannah bracelets" were also made and handed out at her service. If you cruise around Russellville today, you'll still spot hundreds of people wearing them.



Fundraisers are still happening. This one below happened during spirit week (homecoming week) October 1-5, 2012, which was dedicated to Savannah.

     

The mobile art piece is actually biology and environmental science teacher Chuck Campbell’s personal 1970 Volkswagen Van. Campbell said he drives the van whenever he doesn’t ride his bicycle, which added up to less than 4,000 miles last year. “Over the years, kids have asked if they could paint the van,” Campbell said. “This year, I thought why not let the kids have fun painting my van while we raise money for the Sunshine Fund.”

Savannah was an active member of the Peace Club, which stands for People Encouraging Active Change and Exchange. Sponsor Paul Gray said Savannah was a special and kind of funky kid who was not only well liked and loved by the students, but by the teachers as well. He added that she was all smiles and sunshine, hence the nickname the Smile Fund.

Ingrid, Savannah's mother, said the event Tuesday was a beautiful tribute that honored her daughter and that each time there is an event, or someone shares a story about Savannah, her heart is filled again. “I think this is just awesome,” Ingrid said of the event. “Savannah was like a hippie, gypsy kind of girl. She was positive every day and she really believed in peace, love and happiness around the world. I knew she was well loved by people, but I didn’t know the impact until we lost her.

TATTOOS
Since Savannah's passing, many have gotten tattoos in honor or in memory of Savannah. Here are a few:

           

FACEBOOK POSTS
There were hundreds of posts to Savannah's Facebook wall the day she passed. Many of her friends and family continue to post - below are just a few of many.
The post circled in yellow below, was the last thing Savannah said on Facebook before her accident.



IN CLOSING
Thank you for taking the time to read about our beautiful Savannah. Every penny donated will be directly deposited into the fund.

If you are not able to donate, please do something kind for someone today in honor of Savannah. In speaking of Savannah her mother said, "She was truly beautiful, not just on the outside, she lived life to its fullest every day and encouraged all of us to do the same!".

We miss her terribly.

story:
What is Education Beyond the Classroom?

Students helping students! The purpose of Education Beyond The Classroom is to provide students from kindergarten through 12th grade with FREE online tutoring lessons and help with their home work. These children and youth do not have access to good middle and high school education. They are mostly in inner city neighborhoods in the United States and in many impoverished areas in third world countries.

EBTC was founded by high school students to help other middle and high school students all across the globe.

This is a grassroots effort run entirely by volunteers and we are an emerging 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

We need YOU to help us make this happen with your donations and  referrals. 

What We Need:

All student teachers have their own hardware and software and do not require any assistance. However, since we are helping needy students, and their resources are very limited, we intend to help them as much as we can. In some areas, we need to provide the students with one or more of the following: teaching material, computers, microphones, operating system software, webcams, and internet service if required.

In return, we will welcome you to our extended family, give you a variety of perks to express our gratitude, and thank you for giving these children a chance for a better life. 

Ways You Can Help:

There are many ways you can help our cause and make a difference:

  • First, make a financial contribution to our campaign and choose one of our perks as a token of our appreciation. 
  • Second, and this one is important: Help us by sharing our campaign.  Spread the word. Share it. Know that we sincerely appreciate it.
  • Third, help us spread the word about our work. Please join us in our journey as we make a difference for kids who really need it.

The Impact:

Supporting  Education Beyond the Classroom  is an opportunity to make a real difference in the lives of children who need you. By contributing to this worthy cause, you will:

  • Inspire students to dream big, set goals, and use the skills they learn to achieve their goals.
  • Empower students with digital literacy skills that they need to succeed in school now and in their future.
  • Create a better future. Our long term goal is to provide a strong educational foundation for children and youth, thereby preparing them to be valuable, contributing members of society.

Thank you for your support!

story:
The Concept / Das Konzept

Auf Deutsch (for english text please scroll down)

Ich habe vor zwei Jahren meinen Digitalisierungsservice www.Eridian.de gegründet. Für Verlage und Autoren digitalisiere ich schon seit geraumer Zeit Bücher. Nun habe ich einen neuen Kundenkreis für mich entdeckt. Sehbehinderte und Blinde Menschen, die Bücher nicht mehr auf herkömmliche Weise lesen können (siehe hierzu § 45a UrhG). Mit und durch die Unterstützung des ABSV ist mein Service in dieser Zielgruppe mittlerweile recht bekannt.

Nun möchte ich noch einen Schritt weiter gehen und den Sehbehinderten und Blinden eine barrierefreie Internetplattform bauen, auf der Sie untereinander (mit ihren Freunden) digitalisierte Bücher tauschen können. Ich habe sehr konkrete Vorstellung wie dies mit den aktuell bestehenden Gesetzen konform geht.

Erste Rücksprachen mit Rechtsanwälten, die spezielisiert sind auf das Urheberrecht, bestätigen die legale Umsetzung diese Projekts. 

Die meisten Bücher, die wir in unseren Bücherregalen zu stehen haben gibt es nicht in digitaler Form. Sehbehinderte können aufgrund Ihrer Einschränkungen  papiergebundene Bücher nicht mehr lesen und benötigen ein digitales Format, dass es Ihnen erlaubt die Schrift zu zoomen. 

Kunden können mithilfe der Internetplattform nun Ihre eingescannten Bücher untereinander tauschen, so dass sie auf einmal auf eine große Bandbreite von Büchern zugreifen können, nicht nur auf die eignen eingescannten Bücher. Die Einschränkungen von Sehbehinderten und Blinden werden somit ein wenig kleiner.

Weitere Möglichkeiten: Webbasierter Player zum direkten vorlesen der Bücher. Durchsuchbare PDF-Dateien lassen sich allein schon mit dem Adobe Acrobat Reader vorlesen. Hier gibt es aber bereits weitaus bessere Software auf dem Markt, die von dieser Zielgruppe bereits genutzt wird (z. B. der Screenreader)

Wieviel Kapital wird benötigt und wie werden unsere ersten Schritte aussehen?

Ca. 50.000 € wird für das Gesamtprojekt benötigt. Nach der Erstellung der Seite www.swapswipe.com/beta (Betaphase) soll eine Anschlußfinanzierung folgen.

Funktionsumfang der Seite:

Wichtigster Punkt: Die Internetseite www.swapswipe.com wird in Ihrer funktionsweise barrierefrei aufgebaut (sehbehinderten gerecht).

Jeder Kunde bekommt einen Account. In diesem Account werden seine eingescannten Bücher direkt nach dem Scanprozeß hochgeladen.

Die durchsuchbaren PDF-Dateien werden dem Kunden in verschlüsselter Form, mit Wasserzeichen (Namen des Kunden) und einer Zeitbome online zur Verfügung gestellt. Sofern der Kunde selbst sich das Buch auf den Rechner lädt, kann er dieses 30 Tage lang nutzen/lesen. In diesen 21 Tagen wird das Buch online nicht mehr abrufbar sein und kann somit nicht zum Tausch angeboten werden. Nach 21 Tagen erscheint die PDF wieder im Account, da die Zeitbombe die heruntergeladene Datei unbrauchbar macht.

Sofern ein Tausch mit einem Freund zustande kommt, wird die Datei von einem Account in den anderen übertragen, so dass der Verleiher das Leserecht an seinem Buch für 21 Tage abtritt.

Die Seite wird vorraussichtlich gegen ein geringes monatliches Nutzungsentgelt verfügbar sein. Verleiher bekommen sogenannte "Swaps" für jeden Tausch (virtuelle Währung), die Sie in Sachwerte eintauschen können. 

 

 

In English


Two years ago I started my digitalization service www.Eridian.de. I have been digitalizing books for publishing companies and authors for a long time. Now, I have discovered a new group of customers. Visually impaired and blind people, who cannot read in the traditional way. By the support of the German Society for the blind and visually impaired my service has become popular among that audience. The § 45a UrhG (german copyright law) allows me to do this.

I want to go one step further and design an internet platform for the blind and visually impaired where they can share digitalized books among each other and with their friends. I have exact ideas how this can be compliant with the current laws.

Most books which we have in our shelves are not available in a digital form. Visually impaired cannot read paper-bound books because of their handicap any more and need a digital format, that allows them to zoom. Blind people need the book in a text format (.txt) so that they can have it read out aloud on special devices as for example the "Daisy-Player".

Some of our customers buy books and have us digitalize them for a price that is below the price of the corresponding e-book if that even is available.

Customers can now, by means of the internet platform, trade their books among each other so that they can access a great variety of books and not only those they themselves had digitalized. The impairment of the blind and visually impaired thus becomes smaller.

Consultations with lawyers confirm the possibility of a realization compliant with the law. (in Germany)

Opportunities for the Website:

Webbased player to read the books aloud. Searchable PDF files can be read out aloud by means of the Adobe Acrobat Reader. Here, much better software is available on the market however, which could be made use of for the internet platform.

 

The platform


Eridian wants to create an easy access to any given book for the blind and the visually impaired. Thereby the quality of life of this group of people can be increased granting them access to education and entertainment.

Name of the platform: www.swapswipe.com


You can compare swapswipe.com with the swap opportunity by Amazon and Barnes & Nobles. The diffrence will be that your scanned books uploaded on the platform (by eridian.de) will stay in your property.

However, purchased e-books cannot be offered for trade on this platform except if the publishers can be convinced to work with us and an enlargement of the concept is made possible. We want to create a legal, internet based access to books that can be compared to the business models in the music industry (monthly fees pay for an unlimited number of songs).

The Website will start for the handicaped people in Germany but I would like you to start scanning books for them in your own country and use swapswipe.com for your customers. Germany ist already reserved, sorry!;-)

Did you knwo that there are 285 mio. visiually handicapped and blind people worldwide out there?



What do we need?

Money to create the internet platform. Money for new employers and maybe new scanner (scanner that do not destroy the books / often asked).

I do not require funds for marketing since these funds are generated by my core business.

First Step

The first Step will be to create the internetplatform. Responsable for this field will be www.bytepark.de. Bytepark has already created the website www.eridian.de. (have a look at their references)

I hope that the work can start in November, so we can see in January first results.

Thanks for your help!
story_txt:
The Concept / Das Konzept
Auf Deutsch (for english text please scroll down)
Ich habe vor zwei Jahren meinen Digitalisierungsservice www.Eridian.de gegründet. Für Verlage und Autoren digitalisiere ich schon seit geraumer Zeit Bücher. Nun habe ich einen neuen Kundenkreis für mich entdeckt. Sehbehinderte und Blinde Menschen, die Bücher nicht mehr auf herkömmliche Weise lesen können (siehe hierzu § 45a UrhG). Mit und durch die Unterstützung des ABSV ist mein Service in dieser Zielgruppe mittlerweile recht bekannt.
Nun möchte ich noch einen Schritt weiter gehen und den Sehbehinderten und Blinden eine barrierefreie Internetplattform bauen, auf der Sie untereinander (mit ihren Freunden) digitalisierte Bücher tauschen können. Ich habe sehr konkrete Vorstellung wie dies mit den aktuell bestehenden Gesetzen konform geht.
Erste Rücksprachen mit Rechtsanwälten, die spezielisiert sind auf das Urheberrecht, bestätigen die legale Umsetzung diese Projekts. 
Die meisten Bücher, die wir in unseren Bücherregalen zu stehen haben gibt es nicht in digitaler Form. Sehbehinderte können aufgrund Ihrer Einschränkungen  papiergebundene Bücher nicht mehr lesen und benötigen ein digitales Format, dass es Ihnen erlaubt die Schrift zu zoomen. 
Kunden können mithilfe der Internetplattform nun Ihre eingescannten Bücher untereinander tauschen, so dass sie auf einmal auf eine große Bandbreite von Büchern zugreifen können, nicht nur auf die eignen eingescannten Bücher. Die Einschränkungen von Sehbehinderten und Blinden werden somit ein wenig kleiner.
Weitere Möglichkeiten: Webbasierter Player zum direkten vorlesen der Bücher. Durchsuchbare PDF-Dateien lassen sich allein schon mit dem Adobe Acrobat Reader vorlesen. Hier gibt es aber bereits weitaus bessere Software auf dem Markt, die von dieser Zielgruppe bereits genutzt wird (z. B. der Screenreader)
Wieviel Kapital wird benötigt und wie werden unsere ersten Schritte aussehen?
Ca. 50.000 € wird für das Gesamtprojekt benötigt. Nach der Erstellung der Seite www.swapswipe.com/beta (Betaphase) soll eine Anschlußfinanzierung folgen.
Funktionsumfang der Seite:
Wichtigster Punkt: Die Internetseite www.swapswipe.com wird in Ihrer funktionsweise barrierefrei aufgebaut (sehbehinderten gerecht).
Jeder Kunde bekommt einen Account. In diesem Account werden seine eingescannten Bücher direkt nach dem Scanprozeß hochgeladen.
Die durchsuchbaren PDF-Dateien werden dem Kunden in verschlüsselter Form, mit Wasserzeichen (Namen des Kunden) und einer Zeitbome online zur Verfügung gestellt. Sofern der Kunde selbst sich das Buch auf den Rechner lädt, kann er dieses 30 Tage lang nutzen/lesen. In diesen 21 Tagen wird das Buch online nicht mehr abrufbar sein und kann somit nicht zum Tausch angeboten werden. Nach 21 Tagen erscheint die PDF wieder im Account, da die Zeitbombe die heruntergeladene Datei unbrauchbar macht.
Sofern ein Tausch mit einem Freund zustande kommt, wird die Datei von einem Account in den anderen übertragen, so dass der Verleiher das Leserecht an seinem Buch für 21 Tage abtritt.
Die Seite wird vorraussichtlich gegen ein geringes monatliches Nutzungsentgelt verfügbar sein. Verleiher bekommen sogenannte "Swaps" für jeden Tausch (virtuelle Währung), die Sie in Sachwerte eintauschen können. 
 
 
In English
Two years ago I started my digitalization service www.Eridian.de. I have been digitalizing books for publishing companies and authors for a long time. Now, I have discovered a new group of customers. Visually impaired and blind people, who cannot read in the traditional way. By the support of the German Society for the blind and visually impaired my service has become popular among that audience. The § 45a UrhG (german copyright law) allows me to do this.I want to go one step further and design an internet platform for the blind and visually impaired where they can share digitalized books among each other and with their friends. I have exact ideas how this can be compliant with the current laws.Most books which we have in our shelves are not available in a digital form. Visually impaired cannot read paper-bound books because of their handicap any more and need a digital format, that allows them to zoom. Blind people need the book in a text format (.txt) so that they can have it read out aloud on special devices as for example the "Daisy-Player".Some of our customers buy books and have us digitalize them for a price that is below the price of the corresponding e-book if that even is available.Customers can now, by means of the internet platform, trade their books among each other so that they can access a great variety of books and not only those they themselves had digitalized. The impairment of the blind and visually impaired thus becomes smaller.Consultations with lawyers confirm the possibility of a realization compliant with the law. (in Germany)Opportunities for the Website: Webbased player to read the books aloud. Searchable PDF files can be read out aloud by means of the Adobe Acrobat Reader. Here, much better software is available on the market however, which could be made use of for the internet platform.
 
The platform
Eridian wants to create an easy access to any given book for the blind and the visually impaired. Thereby the quality of life of this group of people can be increased granting them access to education and entertainment.Name of the platform: www.swapswipe.com
You can compare swapswipe.com with the swap opportunity by Amazon and Barnes & Nobles. The diffrence will be that your scanned books uploaded on the platform (by eridian.de) will stay in your property. However, purchased e-books cannot be offered for trade on this platform except if the publishers can be convinced to work with us and an enlargement of the concept is made possible. We want to create a legal, internet based access to books that can be compared to the business models in the music industry (monthly fees pay for an unlimited number of songs).The Website will start for the handicaped people in Germany but I would like you to start scanning books for them in your own country and use swapswipe.com for your customers. Germany ist already reserved, sorry!;-)
Did you knwo that there are 285 mio. visiually handicapped and blind people worldwide out there?
What do we need? Money to create the internet platform. Money for new employers and maybe new scanner (scanner that do not destroy the books / often asked).
I do not require funds for marketing since these funds are generated by my core business.
First Step
The first Step will be to create the internetplatform. Responsable for this field will be www.bytepark.de. Bytepark has already created the website www.eridian.de. (have a look at their references)
I hope that the work can start in November, so we can see in January first results.
Thanks for your help!

story:
SUMMARY

Hi! I'm an independently published author, and patented game designer, and it's clear to me that you can't compete in the near monopoly dominated situation that the media in this world has become without working with others in a spirit of cooperation and support.

 

This is why I created the International Independent Authors and Artists Consortium (IIAAC) a couple of years ago. The purpose of the IIAAC is to create an inexpensive avenue of advertising by connecting businesses (large and small) and creators in the real and electronic worlds, and we need help!

 

WHAT IT IS

IIAAC is different than other attempts (webrings) because it concentrates on real world forms of advertising. Webrings and collectives draw the attention of abusers and money grubbing individuals. They insist that you abide by their advertising standards, many of which prohibit you from networked advertising, or are so disorganized and unmonitored that you don't know what you're clicking on.

 

So for the last two years I've been trying to work with others (from music and movies, to sculptures and books) in order to develop an advertising scheme that is low cost for the average individual to compete but still be effective.

 

The answer we came up with was a catalog system designed to be shown wherever a member makes an appearance. I have to say for a trial run, with a low quality website and no funds spent in advertising, it has shown a degree of success!

 

HOW IT WORKS

As I said above, the basic premise is that members bring copies of the catalog to one of their events. They aren't forced to, but if they do, they gain advertising credit. While showing off their own work, they explain to their audience that they're part of this group which is trying to bring independent creators and supportive businesses into the mainstream. They ask people to check it out, then they go on with their own presentation.

 

The concept of the catalog is as follows:

  • Only a handful of copies are printed at one time.

  • Prospective customers are allowed/encouraged to thumb through the catalog and see if there is anything they might like.

  • If there is something they like, they could use their smart phone to zap a QR code and make a purchase right then and there for the item in question.

  • Only certain people visiting the creator should be given a catalog (such as prospective businesses/Big Wigs), the rest are encouraged to take the more inexpensive business card home.

  • Yes, this catalog concentrates on QR codes, but if a person doesn't have a QR code reader, the downloadable catalog will still have clickable links to the items in question.

  • The fee schedule for advertising is based off a scale of individuals, businesses (small and large), and separated into 2 types- horizontal slots, then half and full page advertising.

  • As stated before, people can earn credits for advertising by advertising in the catalog or IIAAC itself, on their site and/or at their events (such as conventions, book signings, fairs, etc.)

 

 

SUCCESS AND WHY WE NEED SUPPORT

In just 4 events, and no advertising budget, we've managed several hundred hits to the main site, and have received personal and public encouragement by prospective customers. I believe this shows that this concept can be a success! The big issue now is start up funding to fully advertise for IIAAC as well as bring more projects to fruition for the benefit of IIAAC and its members. These projects include, but are not limited to:

  • A professionally executed webpage. While we have dozens of members right now, I am the sole person constructing our internet presence. I want the webpage to look nice, and the only knowledge I have is HTML For Dummies. As a result we need money, or a volunteer, to fashion a professional webpage presence so we can be productive outside of just Facebook.

  • More than one catalog. Right now the IIAAC catalog is a Direct-To-Purchase catalog, which really doesn't help small business owners. Therefore I would like to create a brick and mortar friendly catalog which would allow shop owners to process orders from their customers, thus receiving a portion of profits of the sales of independent material. Catalogs still cost money to print as well as take efforts to design. That's why more funding will help me handle 2 catalogs at once.

  • Serious/steady advertising for IIAAC. I make no money off IIAAC. In fact, I donate quite a bit more than the average person may guess. While I firmly believe in this non-profit style consortium, I need financial backing in order to start with serious advertising. I want to keep IIAAC inexpensive and void of non-participating corporate advertisements. The only way to do that is via sponsor systems such as Indiegogo.com. Book signings and conventions only do so much. Facebook ads, Yahoo ads, newspaper ads, need to be made a reality.

  • *Mall Kiosk Consignment Sales. If we go above and beyond $1,000 we wish to eye Kiosk Consignment Presence in a high traffic mall area.

 

By donating to IIAAC, you aren't just helping me, you are helping every single independent artist and supporting business within IIAAC to gain a larger foothold in near monopoly dominated industries. If you care at all about independent projects of all kinds, you will either directly support us with money or help spread the word around.

 

IIAAC cannot, and will not, promise sales and success. No marketing agency or attempt can ever do that while conducting itself in a legal manner. What we can promise is that we will do our best. Success is dependent entirely on people supporting independent creators. That also means creators have to support each other. I will always carry an IIAAC catalog and business cards wherever I go. I will always advertise for my fellow creators and businesses. I will never take money from IIAAC for my own personal means.

 

The advertising spent here for this indiegogo campaign is paid for entirely by those who advertise in the catalog for its first test run. They believe enough in this catalog to try and make it work.

 

Do you believe in us, do you believe in yourself and in your commitment to support independent creators enough that you will help make IIAAC a success?

 

We're setting our goal at $1,000.00, which will be enough to get a professionally designed website, to guarantee 2 types of catalogs printing at once (brick and mortar, and direct-to-sales QR code), and modest advertising presence.

 

WHAT YOU GET

Rewards for donation are:

  • For any donation, a special personalized thank-you on the Facebook website (which may mean bonus advertising for your business venture)

  • For a $50 donation, the public thank-you PLUS John Rocket merchandise totaling no more than $15 in value.

  • For a $100 donation, the public thank you PLUS John Rocket merchandise totaling no more than $30 in value.

  • For a $800 donation, the public thank-you PLUS the hand-bound typed facsimile of John Rocket. The hand-typed charity edition of John Rocket is $80 in materials fees, the entire novel was re-typed on a 1935-36 Royal Portable Junior typewriter, the pages were scanned into the computer, corrected for some distortion and errors, then reprinted on fine business paper for the sole purpose of raising money for charity. Normally this goes for $195.30, with $120 guaranteed for charity. But for the purpose of raising money for IIAAC, I will include a charity copy along with contract and owner transference of that specific copy to anyone who donates $800 or more to the IIAAC.

 

If you are not interested in John Rocket or its merchandise, and would prefer a substitute of equal value in participation through IIAAC, we will be happy to oblige!

 

Stay tuned to the rewards section as they may be expanded with alternate offers or rewards for donations above $1000.

 

And as always, we would like to welcome ANY independent creator or business, even if they can't donate to our cause.

 

MORE INFORMATION

IIAAC is not a currently registered non-profit, but it is being run through Ninja Nezumi Productions, LLC, for “guarantee assurance” and liability reasons. For any questions, please contact us through any of the following methods:

 

http://IIAAC.ninjanezumi.com

 

http://www.facebook.com/IIAAC

 

IIAAC@ninjanezumi.com

 

http://www.cafepress.com/ninjanezumi/7211289

 

Copies of the book are included as merchandise, along with anything on the Ninja Nezumi Cafepress.com website.

 

WHAT IS JOHN ROCKET?

John Rocket is a superhero I created for the sole purpose of introducing a non-white non-stereotyped hero.  I believe the major comic book publishers have failed the American people by not providing us with non-white heroes who aren't simple cardboard cut outs.  I also believe strongly that John Rocket must be a hero in real life as well as in fiction, hence my charity edition and donations.  To find out more about John Rocket, please visit the following links:

http://thelibrary.ninjanezumi.com/johnrocket/

http://www.facebook.com/TheJohnRocket

story:
Thank you for looking at my project! This business was born from a labor of love and teaching sign language has become a true passion that I love to share. My daughter was born with various medical issues and one was the inability to verbalize. There was no one local that could help teach my infant sign language so I went back to school and learned not just how to sign myself but how to teach children. I am now a certified Master Instructor through the Signing Time Academy and offer an array of services to help people learn to sign! I work with children of all ages and abilities! I have gone out on a limb and opened my own office to create a fun, safe place for families to come learn! Every penny I have is going into my classroom and I need help to finish it up AND to help with the expenses of teaching some of my special families. If we reach the $900.00 goal not only will the classroom be complete BUT one more special needs family will be able to enroll!!! Then every $500.00 raised after that (I am hopeful) will secure tuition, classroom materials and supplies for another special needs family! Our largest struggle will be finding funding for these special families that could benefit the most. Please help me help give these children the gift of communication.
Please share this campaign with as many friends as possible! Your help is very much appreciated!
www.twohappyhands.com

story:
Welcome to our project, Impressions Of YIP – The Essence



This is a project for the people. We want to bring you stories of modern-day initiation, stories of transformation, stories that just might change your life. We want to bring you something tangible that you can hold in your hands and share.

Impressions of YIP is 50 pg. visual representation of The International Youth Initiative Program. YIP is an international residential 10 month program that supports young adults in their pursuit of a higher purpose, and challenges them to find life work that sustains not only the individual but also the world.

 

The aim of this project is to collect content from all 6 running years of the program and bring the message of YIP out to the world. We, the IOY Team are all current participants of YIP.  We are convinced that the gift of this publication will help to carry YIP into the future.

 

Why this project matters to us, and why we want to bring it to you!

 

As young adults in today's world, we are very much aware of the global challenges that are around every turn. Often it can be overwhelming, this constant intake of information that does not usually help us understand how we can contribute towards possible solutions.

 

We are inspired by our participation at The International Youth Initiative Program, which is a new form of education. YIP is playing a vital part in the world by providing current knowledge, tools and skills that move individuals to answer the greater callings of the self and the world. Alumni and participants (like ourselves) are given the confidence that allows us to take responsibility and initiative so that we may step into action for ourselves and for the world.

We are part of a growing collective of young adults that willingly make themselves aware of the many tasks at hand. We are creating a future for this up and coming generation to learn to arise to take on the state of the world today with passion, creativity and commitment.

By releasing this publication we are actively contributing to this programs future so that other individuals have the opportunity to embark on this journey.


What is ‘Impressions of YIP- The Essence’

Impressions Of YIP- The Essence, is the baby sister to the first edition of Impressions Of YIP that was published in May of 2010 during the 2nd year of the programs running.  Since this original version, YIP has been running for four years, which means that the program in whole has evolved into what it is today. Fueled by this original platform we have started this project with the shared dream to create an updated ‘Timeless’ version that will reference all of the YIP years. It will focus on the archetypal experience of YIP and will serve as one of the vessels of the being of this program that we care for so deeply.

Impressions of YIP – The Essence, will provide an accurate and updated portrayal of the program in full as it will encompass both an overview of how the program runs and personal accounts. We will detail Personal Initiatives, Education Revolutions and what it means to be a part of an International Network of Global Changemakers.  Through a compilation of writing, photography, drawings, paintings and poetry from those who have experienced YIP as either a participant or a contributor we will be able to provide you with a unique view of strength and courage. These expressions are a call to you from today’s hopeful generation.


Where do the funds go?

We have an estimated cost of 4,000 euro that should allow us to print our first goal of 1,000 copies. If we are able to raise more with your support, we will increase the amount of printed copies. Please know that all of our proceeds will go only to the printing costs, and that The Impressions Team is working on a voluntary basis out of love for what this program has to offer to the world.

 

Timeline:

Currently we in the process of gathering writing and other artistic works from alumni and contributors within the YIP network with a submission deadline of March 1st 2014. By YIP's annual conference, Initiative Forum (April 15th-20th) we will have a pre-view PDF copy of IOY available for early purchase. On May 22nd we will send the final PDF to printing. Publishing and distribution will begin in early June.


The Impressions Of YIP Team

We, The Impressions of YIP Team are made up of Oona Grönroos, Kailea Frederick, Lena Otte, Linda Kleinheinz & Levi Lenge. We all met each other here at YIP this past fall as we are all current YIP participants for the 2013-2014 year. Although we have only been in session for four months, the experiences that YIP has provided us in this short amount of time have been absolutely transformational. YIP has already played such an essential role in our individual growth and our ability to step into the world with confidence behind our actions.

Each of us came into contact with YIP through various means at different times in our lives. Regardless of circumstance we can each pinpoint the exact first moment of encounter with the program that sparked a knowing that we had come across something life changing.

We started this project in November 2013 with the shared vision of capturing the essence of YIP as truly as possible in one publication. We ourselves wanted to know these stories that paved the path for us. By creating this platform we can give voice to many personal transitions that have taken place through the guidance and support of this program. Through this publication we wish to share the impulse of the first moment of inspiration that lead each of us here.


We are devoted to seeing this project through. If you feel The Call please move with us and share our vision with the ones you wish to fuel.

 

With your support you are helping our dream become a reality. We are so appreciative. We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

 

Mahalo, Kiitos, Danke, Merci,

Thank You!

 

Oona, Kailea, Linda, Lena & Levi
story_txt:
Welcome to our project, Impressions Of YIP – The EssenceThis is a project for the people. We want to
bring you stories of modern-day initiation, stories of transformation, stories
that just might change your life. We want to bring you something tangible that
you can hold in your hands and share.
Impressions
of YIP is 50 pg. visual representation of The International Youth Initiative
Program. YIP is an international residential 10 month program that supports
young adults in their pursuit of a higher purpose, and challenges them to find
life work that sustains not only the individual but also the world.
 The
aim of this project is to collect content from all 6 running years of the
program and bring the message of YIP out to the world. We, the IOY Team are all
current participants of YIP.  We
are convinced that the gift of this publication will help to carry YIP into the
future.
 Why this project matters to us, and why we
want to bring it to you!
 As young adults in today's world, we are very
much aware of the global challenges that are around every turn. Often it can be
overwhelming, this constant intake of information that does not usually help us
understand how we can contribute towards possible solutions.
 We are inspired by our participation at The
International Youth Initiative Program, which is a new form of education.
YIP is playing a vital part in the world by providing current knowledge, tools
and skills that move individuals to answer the greater callings of the self and
the world. Alumni and participants (like ourselves) are given the confidence
that allows us to take responsibility and initiative so that we may step into action
for ourselves and for the world.
We are part of a growing collective of young
adults that willingly make themselves aware of the many tasks at hand. We are
creating a future for this up and coming generation to learn to arise to take
on the state of the world today with passion, creativity and commitment.
By releasing this publication we
are actively contributing to this programs future so that
other individuals have the opportunity to embark on this journey.
What is
‘Impressions of YIP- The Essence’Impressions Of YIP- The Essence, is the baby
sister to the first edition of Impressions Of YIP that was published in May of
2010 during the 2nd year of the programs running.  Since this original version, YIP has
been running for four years, which means that the program in whole has evolved
into what it is today. Fueled by this original platform we have started this
project with the shared dream to create an updated ‘Timeless’ version that will
reference all of the YIP years. It will focus on the archetypal experience of
YIP and will serve as one of the vessels of the being of this program that we
care for so deeply.
Impressions of YIP – The Essence, will provide an
accurate and updated portrayal of the program in full as it will encompass both
an overview of how the program runs and personal accounts. We will detail
Personal Initiatives, Education Revolutions and what it means to be a part of
an International Network of Global Changemakers.  Through a compilation of writing, photography, drawings,
paintings and poetry from those who have experienced YIP as either a
participant or a contributor we will be able to provide you with a unique view
of strength and courage. These expressions are a call to you from today’s
hopeful generation.Where do the funds go?
We have an estimated cost of 4,000 euro that should allow us to print our first goal of 1,000 copies. If we are able to raise more with your support, we will increase the amount of printed copies. Please know that all of our proceeds will go only to the printing costs, and that The Impressions Team is working on a voluntary basis out of love for what this program has to offer to the world. Timeline:Currently we in the process of gathering writing and other artistic works from alumni and contributors within the YIP network with a submission deadline of March 1st 2014. By YIP's annual conference, Initiative Forum (April 15th-20th) we will have a pre-view PDF copy of IOY available for early purchase. On May 22nd we will send the final PDF to printing. Publishing and distribution will begin in early June.The Impressions Of YIP TeamWe, The Impressions of YIP Team are made up of

inspiration that lead each of us here.
We are devoted to seeing this project through. If
you feel The Call please move with us and share our vision with the ones you
wish to fuel.

become a reality. We are so appreciative. We thank you from the bottom of our
hearts!

Thank You!
