& Levi

story:
Who W.E. Are

The Warren East High School Band is a rural high school band located in Bowling Green, KY.  We have a successful Symphonic Band, field a competitive Marching Band, and have Indoor Percussion Ensemble, Jazz Band, and Winter Guard programs.

Over the last several years, our program has grown by leaps and bounds, allowing us to provide more and more students with a quality musical education.  Unfortunately, however, our budget has not grown in the same way as our program.  This has caused our excess instrument inventory to become depleted, and repair needs to mount.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to continue to grow our program, and to provide the students we have with the highest quality music education possible, we are in need of many new instruments and repairs to many of the instruments that we currently have.

All money that we raise will go strictly toward the repair of our current instruments, and purchase of new instruments.  Right now, our current instrument purchase priorities are:

  • 5 Marching Baritones/Euphoniums (approx. $2,000 each)
  • 4 Concert French Horns (approx. $2,000 each)
  • 2 Mellophones (approx. $1,500 each)

While we know that the $5,000 we are seeking in funding won't fully fund these needs, it will go a long way!

As a thank you for your donation, all contributors will receive the heartfelt thanks from the members of the Warren East Band!  All contributions, great or small, are genuinely appreciated.

The Impact

The impact from receiving funding for new instruments will be long-lasting.  These instruments will provide many years of service to our band, and will allow us to offer music education to a greater number of students.  The quality of our program will increase due to the higher quality equipment on which our students will be able to perform.

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can do to help us reach our goals would be greatly beneficial.  Even if you can't help by giving money, you can help the Warren East Band, as well as other bands, in other ways:

  • Share our campaign with family, friends, and anyone that has any interest in music.
  • We accept donations of musical instruments.
  • Attend school band concerts and be involved in the arts in your local schools.  Bands all around the country are suffering major budget cuts and can use any support that you can give.

Thank you SO MUCH for reading this and any support that you can provide!

story:
The world is changing rapidly and no one can predict the future with perfect accuracy. Many of the jobs we recognize today are unlikely to exist in the near future. The path to a successful life is less clear and less determined than it was when we (adults) were in school. Many think there is a strong correlation between what mainstream school systems emphasize and the rise in anxiety, depression, and bullying in our teenagers and younger people.

Everyday more youth (and their parents) are realizing mainstream school systems may not be working for them. Many youth feel less engaged at school: maybe they have interests that are not supported in their school; Some youth are under-stimulated and underchallenged, and others quietly fall behind and lose confidence in themselves.

As a parent, I found myself in this situation with my own son struggling at school and this began my journey to figure out why school wasn’t working for him.

When youth are given an opportunity to learn how to think about and analyze a complex situation, they learn to make choices based on the information they gather. Rather than only learning a particular fact or a recipe of steps, they learn how to evaluate information in many different ways to make informed choices and to draw valid conclusions.

This process builds their self-efficacy and resilience. It gives them a sense that they can handle the uncertain world in which they live.

Makerspace where woodworking, electronics, and designs come to life.

Arc Academy of Inquiry ("Arc") is built around teaching youth how to learn in this resilience building way.  Arc is different, because we go beyond the typical research project with a presentation at the end. Instead, we use a progressive inquiry learning model in an open-space environment with educators who model the mindset of lifelong learning. Each student follows a personalized path that is co-constructed alongside their teachers. This takes students through deeper learning activities that grow and expand their passion about a topic or area of interest.

In an environment that quietly hums with activity and collaboration, students nurture real friendships, learn to advocate for themselves, and feel more certain about their future.

When we hear stories about bullying, stress, anxiety, and depression, some of it is due to an educational system where every student progresses in lock-step with every other student. Those who want to learn more are held back and get bored, while others struggle to keep synchronized with the class and fall behind. The system is not set up for personalized learning and the structure may alienate students leaving them with no opportunity to grow and shine.

Arc’s way of learning, which mobilizes young people’s interest and curiosity, can build resilience and self-efficacy, which helps teens handle emotional distress. Our students meet and often exceed the requirements of the BC Curriculum too. Our formative assessments and the stories we hear from learners (and parents) tell of transformative experiences.

We’ve bootstrapped Year One of the school and kept our expenses low. We spent what we could to ensure the space facilitates learning and minimizes anxiety. We’ve torn down walls and opened up doorways to allow for an open space environment. We’ve invested in Programs that leverage specialty skill sets: Makerspace, Art & Game Therapy, Math Labs, Exploration Days, French Cafe, and others.

Collaborating together; learning together.

In fewer than two years, we’ve created something special. Now we need your help to cover equipment, supplies, and programs so we can grow this school into a pillar of the Greater Victoria community.

By supporting this campaign, you will join a community of people who are concerned that youth need a different education than what we were offered growing up. You will join a community who want to see more education options made available to families. The people who have supported Arc want to give this opportunity to their own children, their grandchildren, and to other people's children.

By showing the success of this model, other schools may adopt this true inquiry model and we can share the benefits with even more youth.

  • Your support means we can enhance and develop our unique inquiry model to offer placements to more students next year.
  • Your support means we can cover costs for our weekly outdoor Exploration Days.
  • Your support means we can increase the hours for specialty staff (Educational Assistants), so they can meet the needs of the Programs.
  • Your support means we can complete a necessary renovation to our Orange Wall so the open-space environment is engineered sufficiently and earthquake prepared.
  • Your support means we can have supplies and equipment to support our students' big ideas and innovative projects.

Any fundraising we reach beyond the flexible goal will help us reach these goals sooner and allow us to better prepare for more students next year.

Learning to cipher and decipher codes at Willows Beach.

With every donation, regardless of the perk you pick, you receive your name being posted on three “Walls Of Gratitude.”

  1. A virtual “Wall Of Gratitude” will be featured on our active Facebook and Instagram accounts.
  2. A dedicated web-page on our website where your name will honorably remain forever.
  3. There will also be a physical wall poster in our school reminding families daily of your generosity.

You’ll also receive a special, mystery thank you from the learners who benefit from your support. Their thank you might take the form of a song, a video, a personalized letter, or handmade object. It'll be up to the learners to be innovative and creative in their thank you. And they have creativity in spades!

Arc made aluminum medallions will be designed and crafted to be wearable and presented with pride. This unique and one-of-a-kind jewelry will be forged within Arc and developed as a learning opportunity for students.

Finally, you’ll receive our everlasting gratitude and the satisfaction of being involved in something special in Victoria's community!

Arc students have explored many topics and ideas. Many have learned subject matter above grade level and many go deeper with their knowledge at their grade level. When they are intrinsically motivated and allowed to follow their natural inquisitiveness, they are open to being exposed to knowledge outside of the BC Curriculum; they regularly consume higher-than-grade-level information.

Before the makerspace was set up.

Gab, student in the gray cap (photo above), graduated grade 8 last year with a comment of, "now I realize that when I started at Arc I had a fixed mindset. From going here, I have more of a growth mindset and know I can do better." He has since moved onto grade 9 at the inquiry high school -- Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry (PSII). We are told by the teachers at Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry (PSII) that they are always excited to welcome students from Arc, as our students already know how to tap into their creativity and curiosity.

Students collaborating on sewing projects

 

At UVic learning about Neanderthals (and archaeology, neuropsychology, math symposiums, biochemistry and microbiology).

 

Exploration Days

Learning can happen outside the four walls of a school too. Our outdoor Exploration Days are more than simple walks around the park. There is learning (and math) in everything we do. Students are prepared with guided inquiries and their own questions prior to exploring a nature sanctuary, salmon spawning area, park, beach, or forest.

Determining species of frogs, birds, and insects at Swan Lake Nature Sanctuary.

 

Inquiry Time

Teachers are kept on their toes daily trying to keep up with the ideas and questions. When students are given permission, their natural ability to be curious and explore turns on. This inquiry time opens the door for going deeper with a topic beyond the standard "2-week project."

Student Quests begin with questions and provocations. To give you a sense of the variety, the following are from students or guided inquiries from teachers:

  • How much plastics will we find on the beach? What zone of Willows Beach had more plastics and why?

  • If photography is the art of observation, what different views will the class have from the same park?

  • Can I make a kitchen knife out of a metal bolt?

  • How can I code a video game in first person view? How can I build a 3D character? Can I learn and use Unity?

  • How can a blacksmith make a plate? How did a blacksmith make swords in medieval days?

  • Can I make my own t-shirts and spirit wear for the school? How do I silk screen a t-shirt?

  • What's the best way to make a website to sell my carved spoons? Is WordPress the easiest for me?

  • What kind of Rube Goldberg machine can I make? How high does it need to start?

From these provocations, students follow a 7-step model to go deeper into questions and research and then into planning and actions. The following two lists represent the questions emerging from many explorations.

Much happens in a week and students need materials to keep going.

 

The inquiry model is based on robust research in education and psychology. It has been actively used for six years at a local high school, Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry, which was founded by Jeff Hopkins.

Interview with Jeff about why middle school is the best time in your life for inquiry learning.

 

At our middle school, there are no rows of chairs, no hourly bells, and no test scores and worksheets. The focus of teachers is specifically on the learning process, not just the learning outcomes. Learners go on cognitive Quests to inquire about ideas and interests, often on topics not available in traditional schools. Questions are co-constructed with learner and teacher, which is the beginning of going deeper into any topic.

This model is interdisciplinary, as well. Quests don't have to be within the silo of a subject. Often Quests cross multiple subjects from math, history, and science to writing and design. Quests follow a 7-step model to allow learning to go deeper in knowledge and give time for reflection. Many of the steps are co-constructed with a student sitting alongside a teacher.

Arc Academy 7-Step Model


“Your dedication and vision are enabling a better place and way for kids to grow into a healthy relationship with learning. Our son loved the trip to Sooke & Foggy Mountain Forge and is really showing signs of starting to embrace the inquiry process in a positive and productive way. The staff is excellent. We’re so glad that this school opened just at the right time for our family and we look forward to supporting it in becoming well-established.” -- Kay, Arc parent

Students prepare learning outcomes prior to Exploration Days.

"G used to come home from school saying “Mom, I want to learn more but I’ve run out of
questions!” He was frustrated with the noise in public school, the necessity for a schedule, and the rapid shifts from one subject to another. He is thriving in Grade 7 at Arc, where he has opportunities to take on a leadership role, to share his expertise, to learn in a variety of different ways, to plan out his own week, and identify his own growth areas. With Arc’s teachers to prompt him and point him in new directions, he is asking questions again. He is learning to use 3D drawing tools to design and build a new house for his pet chickens. He is writing project plans. He is acquiring the math skills he needs to achieve his own objectives. G comes home from school now happy and full of ideas." -- Janelle, Arc parent

Math Labs draw upon student interests. Already motivated, students take on tough subjects.

Even prospective families have something to say. It's exciting that our 30-minute tours with prospective families are booked into January 2020 already. We receive positive comments regularly during the tours as parents see how this model can empower their child.

There were tough times as this school was brought to life. In the 8 months before Arc was even a school, the BC Ministry was skeptical about introducing a new school, the city's bylaws hindered us from most locations in town, and some people I knew were telling me I shouldn't go ahead with it.  I didn't see much of my friends and family and there were days when I was overwhelmed and frustrated. Sometimes I wonder how I did it.

In these moments, I felt a lot of uncertainty. I kept asking myself questions like, "what do I do next" and "how do I keep it going"? Maybe you know what I mean. Maybe you've felt that way when you were trying to do something hard too. What helped get you through those tough times?

One thing I have learned through this challenging process is that I need to put myself in a position where I'm able to recognize and celebrate my accomplishments (no matter how small!), and feel gratitude for the help I've been given along the way. To do this, I had to invite people into that tender and vulnerable space where my vision and hopes were held.

I knew I had to share my dreams and fears. Luckily, I had 8 dedicated, forward-thinking educators, psychologists, and business leaders step up and volunteer to help me design the school. This amazing team of people helped me cut through the junk that wasn't helpful in school and keep only the pieces that we knew were necessary to help kids thrive. Then we needed to share our challenges and fears with a 10-person Getting Started team to raise enough money to open the doors.

Uncertainty and fear cause all sorts of havoc in our minds, don't they? All those thoughts of "this will always be bad" and "I don't have the capability". I have them. We all have them.

So, the most important lesson I've learned through this challenging and humbling process is that I have to invite people into my vulnerable places. When we do this, we do it knowing that not everyone will enter the space with us, but there will be those who do share in the direction we are going.

The seed for needing a different kind of school was planted when I saw my son "surviving" school, not thriving. In kindergarten, he struggled being told to sit and draw for 20 minutes and was separated from the group when he didn't comply. It broke my heart to see him punished for being himself.

Separated from the group in kindergarten when he wouldn't comply.

Then we moved him to a Montessori school. While the elementary program did well teaching him the basics, he was challenged with being contained in a classroom all day and then by the physical shoving and pushing on the playground "when no teachers were around." For some kids, this can be hard to navigate.

I thought to myself on many occasions, "there has to be a better way for children to spend the first 12 years of their life." I was fortunate to have connected with Jeff Hopkins, founder of Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry, and to have co-founded the Rethink Thinking Foundation events for teens. This showed me an education model existed that had components for inclusiveness, student agency over their learning, and environmental conditions to facilitate choice.

Since then, I've met many parents and educators who are excited to see Arc be a staple of the community. I want to thank you for taking the time to involve yourself in this endeavour.

Thank you kindly,

Tom

There are other ways to support the learners and school. And perhaps you want to do more. Here's a few suggestions:

  • Share this fundraising campaign with friends and family. Use social media or email them the link to this page.
  • Talk with your employer about your excitement about this. Often organizations benefit
    from donating, through tax breaks or the exposure they will gain from the “Walls of Gratitude." Donors of goods and services will receive an Arc sticker for their vehicles. We are a Canadian registered charity (#747032282).
  • Point parents to our website (www.arcacademy.ca) for them learn more and book a 30-minute tour for their family.

DELIVERY DATES: The Rewards delivery dates are approximate, and reflect a best-guess for when students will have their thank you gifts and when our volunteer team can deliver the rewards.

WALLS OF GRATITUDE: This is included with EVERY reward. Your name will appear on a physical poster board the students will create and display proudly within the school and on a special page on our website. Regular social media images will be posted with names of recent donors. If you don't want your name mentioned, let us know by emailing us.

STUDENT THANK YOU: This is included with EVERY reward. The students will collaborate and brainstorm on how they want to thank you. A variety of methods are available to them, such as video, song, and crafting something in the makerspace. The message will be heartfelt and personally from the students.

"I SUPPORT ARC" STICKER: This is included with EVERY reward. This "I support Arc" sticker can be placed on your vehicle to show your support and pride. They are designed and printed by families of Arc.

ARC-MADE ALUMINUM MEDALLION: This is included with EVERY reward. This is a molded pattern made of pure aluminum. They can be worn as a necklace, backpack ornament, or car mirror decoration. They are designed and crafted within Arc using the same tools available to students.

THE GRATITUDE PARTY: Founder Tom Hudock will be the host for an inspiring evening, which will include leaders in the community who are supporting Arc and parents of Arc students who will speak about their experiences. Food will include tasty treats from local chefs and restaurants. The party will take place at beautiful place, yet to be confirmed. Guest appearances from a few notable community leaders are expected.

Tom has been living in Victoria for 30 years, which almost makes him a resident Victorian. He uses his consulting and coaching to help bring out the performance in others. He has started 2 businesses in technology and marketing, and 2 nonprofits supporting youth and education. Most recently, he co-founded Rethink Thinking, which ran weekend events for 250 teens from across British Columbia. He has coached business leaders to grow their organizations in alignment with their bigger purpose. His son attends Arc.

 

[Photo coming]
Douglas Manson-Blair is a talented principal who is best known for the creative storytelling and his firm, yet comedic, interactions with students and the team. He's taught at the notable private schools of St. Michael's University and Shawnigan Lake School, where he infused creative and critical thinking into his teaching practices. Whether producing large plays or coordinating athletic games at school, he brings motivation and perspective taking to his engagements.

 

Education Team for inaugural year with Arc.

Michele Worth - Humanities Teacher

Michele is a talented teacher who has the ability to witness the learning of students and meet them where they are at. Notable influences of her work with students include facilitating the creation of comic books and authoring of stories to nudging the confidence in drawing. Her son attends Arc. 

Andrew Murgatroyd - Science, Math and Music Teacher

Andrew is a multi-talented teacher who translates traditional subjects, like math, music, and science, into subjects that students can approach from various degrees of expertise. Creator of the Math Lab and French Cafe, he motivates learning using a practical approach.

Ken Brubaker - Makerspace Education Assistant

Ken is a whiz at helping students take their ideas and make them real. From wooden chairs to scooter engines to sound devices, he brings a hands-on and practical approach to the makerspace.

Ariel Moore - Art and Game Education Assistant

Ariel has brought out the confidence of so many students through his approach of using art and boardgame play to reach them at a personal level. He's a camp leader at the Power of Hope camp for teens and coaches youth using game play.

Ian Mollenhauer - Substitute Teacher

Ian supported the education team when one of our staff went on paternity leave. He brings expertise from years teaching at Glenlyon Norfolk School and sparks the interests of youth with his own curiosity.

Building a new school is a challenge for anyone, let alone a school of the future. It is a substantial endeavor that requires courage and persistence to overcome the hurdles. The Principal, teachers, and families have to be able to roll with the unfamiliar and support children emotionally as well as academically. The school is well underway -- it's taken us months and quite a few dollars to get it to this point. Along the way, we've done what we had to do -- financing much of it from personal funds and family donations.

The funds from this crowdfund will allow us to complete Year Two with the Programs and supplies needed to keep up with student Quests and expand our model to allow for an increase in student enrollment next year.

Our depth of knowledge in education is deep and understanding of budgets is reasonable. It's not the team's first rodeo, so to speak, and this is truly a school born from personal passions to give youth this opportunity.

We say with total confidence, when this campaign succeeds, the Programs will be delivered; backers will love them and be proud to have been part of it; and all rewards will be delivered fully and on a timely basis.

Instead, we use a progressive inquiry learning model in an open-space environment with educators who model the mindset of lifelong learning. Each student follows a personalized path that is co-constructed alongside their teachers. This takes students through deeper learning activities that grow and expand their passion about a topic or area of interest.
In an environment that quietly hums with activity and collaboration, students nurture real friendships, learn to advocate for themselves, and feel more certain about their future.
When we hear stories about bullying, stress, anxiety, and depression, some of it is due to an educational system where every student progresses in lock-step with every other student. Those who want to learn more are held back and get bored, while others struggle to keep synchronized with the class and fall behind. The system is not set up for personalized learning and the structure may alienate students leaving them with no opportunity to grow and shine.



Arc’s way of learning, which mobilizes young people’s interest and curiosity, can build resilience and self-efficacy, which helps teens handle emotional distress. Our students meet and often exceed the requirements of the BC Curriculum too. Our formative assessments and the stories we hear from learners (and parents) tell of transformative experiences.
We’ve bootstrapped Year One of the school and kept our expenses low. We spent what we could to ensure the space facilitates learning and minimizes anxiety. We’ve torn down walls and opened up doorways to allow for an open space environment. We’ve invested in Programs that leverage specialty skill sets: Makerspace, Art & Game Therapy, Math Labs, Exploration Days, French Cafe, and others.

Collaborating together; learning together.
In fewer than two years, we’ve created something special. Now we need your help to cover equipment, supplies, and programs so we can grow this school into a pillar of the Greater Victoria community.

By supporting this campaign, you will join a community of people who are concerned that youth need a different education than what we were offered growing up. You will join a community who want to see more education options made available to families. The people who have supported Arc want to give this opportunity to their own children, their grandchildren, and to other people's children.
By showing the success of this model, other schools may adopt this true inquiry model and we can share the benefits with even more youth.

Your support means we can enhance and develop our unique inquiry model to offer placements to more students next year.
Your support means we can cover costs for our weekly outdoor Exploration Days.
Your support means we can increase the hours for specialty staff (Educational Assistants), so they can meet the needs of the Programs.
Your support means we can complete a necessary renovation to our Orange Wall so the open-space environment is engineered sufficiently and earthquake prepared.
Your support means we can have supplies and equipment to support our students' big ideas and innovative projects.

Any fundraising we reach beyond the flexible goal will help us reach these goals sooner and allow us to better prepare for more students next year.

Learning to cipher and decipher codes at Willows Beach.

With every donation, regardless of the perk you pick, you receive your name being posted on three “Walls Of Gratitude.”

A virtual “Wall Of Gratitude” will be featured on our active Facebook and Instagram accounts.
A dedicated web-page on our website where your name will honorably remain forever.
There will also be a physical wall poster in our school reminding families daily of your generosity.

You’ll also receive a special, mystery thank you from the learners who benefit from your support. Their thank you might take the form of a song, a video, a personalized letter, or handmade object. It'll be up to the learners to be innovative and creative in their thank you. And they have creativity in spades!
Arc made aluminum medallions will be designed and crafted to be wearable and presented with pride. This unique and one-of-a-kind jewelry will be forged within Arc and developed as a learning opportunity for students.
Finally, you’ll receive our everlasting gratitude and the satisfaction of being involved in something special in Victoria's community!
Arc students have explored many topics and ideas. Many have learned subject matter above grade level and many go deeper with their knowledge at their grade level. When they are intrinsically motivated and allowed to follow their natural inquisitiveness, they are open to being exposed to knowledge outside of the BC Curriculum; they regularly consume higher-than-grade-level information.

Before the makerspace was set up.
Gab, student in the gray cap (photo above), graduated grade 8 last year with a comment of, "now I realize that when I started at Arc I had a fixed mindset. From going here, I have more of a growth mindset and know I can do better." He has since moved onto grade 9 at the inquiry high school -- Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry (PSII). We are told by the teachers at Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry (PSII) that they are always excited to welcome students from Arc, as our students already know how to tap into their creativity and curiosity.

Students collaborating on sewing projects
 

At UVic learning about Neanderthals (and archaeology, neuropsychology, math symposiums, biochemistry and microbiology).
 
Exploration Days
Learning can happen outside the four walls of a school too. Our outdoor Exploration Days are more than simple walks around the park. There is learning (and math) in everything we do. Students are prepared with guided inquiries and their own questions prior to exploring a nature sanctuary, salmon spawning area, park, beach, or forest.

Determining species of frogs, birds, and insects at Swan Lake Nature Sanctuary.
 
Inquiry Time
Teachers are kept on their toes daily trying to keep up with the ideas and questions. When students are given permission, their natural ability to be curious and explore turns on. This inquiry time opens the door for going deeper with a topic beyond the standard "2-week project."
Student Quests begin with questions and provocations. To give you a sense of the variety, the following are from students or guided inquiries from teachers:

How much plastics will we find on the beach? What zone of Willows Beach had more plastics and why?
If photography is the art of observation, what different views will the class have from the same park?
Can I make a kitchen knife out of a metal bolt?
How can I code a video game in first person view? How can I build a 3D character? Can I learn and use Unity?
How can a blacksmith make a plate? How did a blacksmith make swords in medieval days?
Can I make my own t-shirts and spirit wear for the school? How do I silk screen a t-shirt?
What's the best way to make a website to sell my carved spoons? Is WordPress the easiest for me?
What kind of Rube Goldberg machine can I make? How high does it need to start?

From these provocations, students follow a 7-step model to go deeper into questions and research and then into planning and actions. The following two lists represent the questions emerging from many explorations.

Much happens in a week and students need materials to keep going.
 

The inquiry model is based on robust research in education and psychology. It has been actively used for six years at a local high school, Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry, which was founded by Jeff Hopkins.

Interview with Jeff about why middle school is the best time in your life for inquiry learning.
 
At our middle school, there are no rows of chairs, no hourly bells, and no test scores and worksheets. The focus of teachers is specifically on the learning process, not just the learning outcomes. Learners go on cognitive Quests to inquire about ideas and interests, often on topics not available in traditional schools. Questions are co-constructed with learner and teacher, which is the beginning of going deeper into any topic.
This model is interdisciplinary, as well. Quests don't have to be within the silo of a subject. Often Quests cross multiple subjects from math, history, and science to writing and design. Quests follow a 7-step model to allow learning to go deeper in knowledge and give time for reflection. Many of the steps are co-constructed with a student sitting alongside a teacher.Arc Academy 7-Step Model“Your dedication and vision are enabling a better place and way for kids to grow into a healthy relationship with learning. Our son loved the trip to Sooke & Foggy Mountain Forge and is really showing signs of starting to embrace the inquiry process in a positive and productive way. The staff is excellent. We’re so glad that this school opened just at the right time for our family and we look forward to supporting it in becoming well-established.” -- Kay, Arc parentStudents prepare learning outcomes prior to Exploration Days."G used to come home from school saying “Mom, I want to learn more but I’ve run out ofquestions!” He was frustrated with the noise in public school, the necessity for a schedule, and the rapid shifts from one subject to another. He is thriving in Grade 7 at Arc, where he has opportunities to take on a leadership role, to share his expertise, to learn in a variety of different ways, to plan out his own week, and identify his own growth areas. With Arc’s teachers to prompt him and point him in new directions, he is asking questions again. He is learning to use 3D drawing tools to design and build a new house for his pet chickens. He is writing project plans. He is acquiring the math skills he needs to achieve his own objectives. G comes home from school now happy and full of ideas." -- Janelle, Arc parentMath Labs draw upon student interests. Already motivated, students take on tough subjects.Even prospective families have something to say. It's exciting that our 30-minute tours with prospective families are booked into January 2020 already. We receive positive comments regularly during the tours as parents see how this model can empower their child.There were tough times as this school was brought to life. In the 8 months before Arc was even a school, the BC Ministry was skeptical about introducing a new school, the city's bylaws hindered us from most locations in town, and some people I knew were telling me I shouldn't go ahead with it.  I didn't see much of my friends and family and there were days when I was overwhelmed and frustrated. Sometimes I wonder how I did it.In these moments, I felt a lot of uncertainty. I kept asking myself questions like, "what do I do next" and "how do I keep it going"? Maybe you know what I mean. Maybe you've felt that way when you were trying to do something hard too. What helped get you through those tough times?One thing I have learned through this challenging process is that I need to put myself in a position where I'm able to recognize and celebrate my accomplishments (no matter how small!), and feel gratitude for the help I've been given along the way. To do this, I had to invite people into that tender and vulnerable space where my vision and hopes were held.I knew I had to share my dreams and fears. Luckily, I had 8 dedicated, forward-thinking educators, psychologists, and business leaders step up and volunteer to help me design the school. This amazing team of people helped me cut through the junk that wasn't helpful in school and keep only the pieces that we knew were necessary to help kids thrive. Then we needed to share our challenges and fears with a 10-person Getting Started team to raise enough money to open the doors.Uncertainty and fear cause all sorts of havoc in our minds, don't they? All those thoughts of "this will always be bad" and "I don't have the capability". I have them. We all have them.So, the most important lesson I've learned through this challenging and humbling process is that I have to invite people into my vulnerable places. When we do this, we do it knowing that not everyone will enter the space with us, but there will be those who do share in the direction we are going.The seed for needing a different kind of school was planted when I saw my son "surviving" school, not thriving. In kindergarten, he struggled being told to sit and draw for 20 minutes and was separated from the group when he didn't comply. It broke my heart to see him punished for being himself.Separated from the group in kindergarten when he wouldn't comply.Then we moved him to a Montessori school. While the elementary program did well teaching him the basics, he was challenged with being contained in a classroom all day and then by the physical shoving and pushing on the playground "when no teachers were around." For some kids, this can be hard to navigate.I thought to myself on many occasions, "there has to be a better way for children to spend the first 12 years of their life." I was fortunate to have connected with Jeff Hopkins, founder of Pacific School of Innovation and Inquiry, and to have co-founded the Rethink Thinking Foundation events for teens. This showed me an education model existed that had components for inclusiveness, student agency over their learning, and environmental conditions to facilitate choice.Since then, I've met many parents and educators who are excited to see Arc be a staple of the community. I want to thank you for taking the time to involve yourself in this endeavour.Thank you kindly,TomThere are other ways to support the learners and school. And perhaps you want to do more. Here's a few suggestions:
Share this fundraising campaign with friends and family. Use social media or email them the link to this page.
Talk with your employer about your excitement about this. Often organizations benefitfrom donating, through tax breaks or the exposure they will gain from the “Walls of Gratitude." Donors of goods and services will receive an Arc sticker for their vehicles. We are a Canadian registered charity (#747032282).

Point parents to our website (www.arcacademy.ca) for them learn more and book a 30-minute tour for their family.
DELIVERY DATES: The Rewards delivery dates are approximate, and reflect a best-guess for when students will have their thank you gifts and when our volunteer team can deliver the rewards.WALLS OF GRATITUDE: This is included with EVERY reward. Your name will appear on a physical poster board the students will create and display proudly within the school and on a special page on our website. Regular social media images will be posted with names of recent donors. If you don't want your name mentioned, let us know by emailing us.STUDENT THANK YOU: This is included with EVERY reward. The students will collaborate and brainstorm on how they want to thank you. A variety of methods are available to them, such as video, song, and crafting something in the makerspace. The message will be heartfelt and personally from the students."I SUPPORT ARC" STICKER: This is included with EVERY reward. This "I support Arc" sticker can be placed on your vehicle to show your support and pride. They are designed and printed by families of Arc.ARC-MADE ALUMINUM MEDALLION: This is included with EVERY reward. This is a molded pattern made of pure aluminum. They can be worn as a necklace, backpack ornament, or car mirror decoration. They are designed and crafted within Arc using the same tools available to students.THE GRATITUDE PARTY: Founder Tom Hudock will be the host for an inspiring evening, which will include leaders in the community who are supporting Arc and parents of Arc students who will speak about their experiences. Food will include tasty treats from local chefs and restaurants. The party will take place at beautiful place, yet to be confirmed. Guest appearances from a few notable community leaders are expected.Tom has been living in Victoria for 30 years, which almost makes him a resident Victorian. He uses his consulting and coaching to help bring out the performance in others. He has started 2 businesses in technology and marketing, and 2 nonprofits supporting youth and education. Most recently, he co-founded Rethink Thinking, which ran weekend events for 250 teens from across British Columbia. He has coached business leaders to grow their organizations in alignment with their bigger purpose. His son attends Arc. [Photo coming]Douglas Manson-Blair is a talented principal who is best known for the creative storytelling and his firm, yet comedic, interactions with students and the team. He's taught at the notable private schools of St. Michael's University and Shawnigan Lake School, where he infused creative and critical thinking into his teaching practices. Whether producing large plays or coordinating athletic games at school, he brings motivation and perspective taking to his engagements. Education Team for inaugural year with Arc.Michele Worth - Humanities TeacherMichele is a talented teacher who has the ability to witness the learning of students and meet them where they are at. Notable influences of her work with students include facilitating the creation of comic books and authoring of stories to nudging the confidence in drawing. Her son attends Arc. Andrew Murgatroyd - Science, Math and Music TeacherAndrew is a multi-talented teacher who translates traditional subjects, like math, music, and science, into subjects that students can approach from various degrees of expertise. Creator of the Math Lab and French Cafe, he motivates learning using a practical approach.Ken Brubaker - Makerspace Education AssistantKen is a whiz at helping students take their ideas and make them real. From wooden chairs to scooter engines to sound devices, he brings a hands-on and practical approach to the makerspace.Ariel Moore - Art and Game Education AssistantAriel has brought out the confidence of so many students through his approach of using art and boardgame play to reach them at a personal level. He's a camp leader at the Power of Hope camp for teens and coaches youth using game play.Ian Mollenhauer - Substitute TeacherIan supported the education team when one of our staff went on paternity leave. He brings expertise from years teaching at Glenlyon Norfolk School and sparks the interests of youth with his own curiosity.Building a new school is a challenge for anyone, let alone a school of the future. It is a substantial endeavor that requires courage and persistence to overcome the hurdles. The Principal, teachers, and families have to be able to roll with the unfamiliar and support children emotionally as well as academically. The school is well underway -- it's taken us months and quite a few dollars to get it to this point. Along the way, we've done what we had to do -- financing much of it from personal funds and family donations.The funds from this crowdfund will allow us to complete Year Two with the Programs and supplies needed to keep up with student Quests and expand our model to allow for an increase in student enrollment next year.Our depth of knowledge in education is deep and understanding of budgets is reasonable. It's not the team's first rodeo, so to speak, and this is truly a school born from personal passions to give youth this opportunity.We say with total confidence, when this campaign succeeds, the Programs will be delivered; backers will love them and be proud to have been part of it; and all rewards will be delivered fully and on a timely basis.

story:
AirShow San Diego

Produced by Air Group One

"Commemorate, Educate, Motivate"

www.ag1caf.org


Who We Are:

Air Group One is the San Diego Wing of the "Commemorative Air Force," a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization headquartered in Midland, Texas. The CAF is a volunteer organization with members from all walks of life, dedicated to preserving the history of the people and planes of World War II.

What We Are Doing:

Air Show San Diego (formerly "Wings over Gillespie") is a privately funded civilian air show. Every year our volunteers give thousands of hours into making a wonderful air show for San Diego families and Veterans and we need your financial support. Air Group One and the CAF preserves these “national treasures” so they appear, fly, and sound as they did some 70 years ago. Our work serves as a constant reminder to the public about the unending sacrifice this country's men and women made, against overwhelming odds, to win the ultimate victory against tyranny and aggression.

Why We Are Doing it:

Air Group One produces it's annual Air Show as a fundraiser to support its Youth Education and Commemoration programs.

To brand for a broader, wider audience appeal, the 18-year annual “Wings over Gillespie” and Air Group One will increasingly serve a larger mission and purpose. Our mission to "Commemorate, Educate, and Motivate"extends the traditional focus of the San Diego Wing of the Commemorative Air Force's dedication to "preserving the history of the people and planes of World War II." San Diego has a deep aviation heritage, and will continue to have a major impact on the future of aviation and aerospace. "AirShow San Diego" will reflect more of San Diego aviation heritage and future. Educating and motivating youth also helps them aspire to service and high-technology careers.

These challenging, exciting times call for advancements on many fronts related to aviation and to the need for a better-educated and -prepared workforce. Air Group One has working relationships with the East County Economic Development Council (ECEDC), the Gillespie Field Development Council, San Diego Air & Space Museum, USS Midway Museum, Flying Leathernecks Museum, and several other aviation-related organizations and education institutions, with new projects to benefit our larger mission to serve the greater San Diego region. 

Where Is Your Money Going:

Air Group One pioneered its A-STEM ("Aviation - Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM)") educational youth program and hosts or supports numerous events educating the public and youth about the importance of veteran commemoration and America's aviation heritage. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Air Group One is always looking for volunteers to join in our missions of education and commemoration. Contact us on our website www.ag1caf.org

Performers:

C-53 D-Day Doll with Paratroopers

Ground Re-enactors Mock Battle

Red Eagles Yak Formation Flying

Smoke-N-Thunder Jet Car

San Diego's 99's

ASTREA

John Collver & "WarDog"

WWII Fighter Dogfight with Pyro!

Over 50 Static WWII,  Antique Aircraft, and Classic Cars

Plus a Beer Garden Sponsored by and featuring Hangar 24 Craft Beer!


*All tickets are single day use only and are non-refundable if the show is cancelled due to weather or other unforeseen circumstances.


Can't donate but still want to support? Click here to Volunteer!

story:
Hi, we're MOVE. What's your name?

MOVE San Antonio does innovative democracy for our generation. We are workin’ hard to build a great future and empower great new leaders to keep making it greater. We are swarms of young Texans, doing democracy in a hands-on way. We put feet on the streets, butts in the seats and votes in the election…eets. We work to make politics more accessible, more equitable and more innovative. We know our generation can save the world and we need your help.

Our leaders are amazing. They're the people that skip meals, overload on caffeine, and stay at the office waaaay past five to get the job done. Six of them - Alex, Bela, Brittany, Daniel, Frank, and Seb - are going through an intensive twelve-week training program to become even stronger organizers and leaders. During our sixth week, we want to provide a memorable experience: a two-day retreat for staff and organizers.

#Math and #theMOVEplan

To provide two days and two nights in a badass cabin, we need to raise $800. $650 of that will go to actually renting a cabin for nine people, and the remaining $150 will go to vegan burgers, s'mores, and gas reimbursements for a few cars to get out in the country.

At this retreat, our staff and organizers will develop as a team: not only will we have trust falls and a cheesy campfire, but we'll also have some real conversations about why we do the work that we do. We'll review our summer organizing program, ask for feedback, and adjust the plans that we've made to better suit the people that work with us. This will allow us to continue improving our programs and our relationships (yep, all of the feels).

Impact Calculus

Our programs have three core principles:

  • Civic engagement – engage voters and advocate for policies that make a lasting impact Texas’s political landscape.
  • Leadership development for the long-term – we’re at the beginning of a leadership pipeline, exposing participants to a network of organizations and relationships to give them a running start at careers in politics and the public interest.
  • Advocacy – build support for, pass, and implement policies that move us forward and create real change that impacts lives and our state.

You can expect all of this to be improved on and built even further with our retreat.

What can YOU do? Great question.

Every little bit helps, and we're not just saying that. Anything you can give will be put to good use - even if it's only a few dollars.

And, if you can't contribute, you can still help us out by sharing this page & giving us a shout out to your friends. PR ain't free, so we'll appreciate the hell out of that too.

story:
Campo, Colorado experienced the worst of the Great Dustbowl in the 30's. Now this agricultural region is in the midst of another very deep drought that has dried up surface water and emptied the landscape of cattle. Families in our small towns across Colorado are struggling to remain on the landscape and keep their cultural heritage and historic places alive just as our ancestors have, but are the hallmark of our communities and the strength of Colorado.

Nineteen high school students from this area want to visit History Colorado in Denver (a 600 mile trip) to view a new exhibit on the Dust Bowl which highlights their hometown and county.  

This group will come to learn, and tell their story to History Colorado staff, and work with legislators at our state capitol so that their story of place can be shared with future generations which is the hallmark of the Colorado Preserve America Youth Summit. This is the Youth Summit's chance to "pay it forward" and help other students live and learn Colorado history and government by coming to their state capitol just as students have in the past.

We Need Your Help!

The group is working to raise money for transportation for this long trip, but needs assistance to help stay overnight in Denver. Although the school district has received a discounted rate on hotel accommodations ($69.00) the total cost is just out of reach for this small school district when they are covering other costs for students such as food and transportation. Like other school districts across the state, they could use our help!

WHY? 

The Colorado Preserve America Youth Summit participants and staff know that experiencing a place makes learning come alive for students. This opportunity will allow students to not only share their story, but to advocate for their community and take a leadership role in making a difference for their region when this region is going through a dustbowl WORSE than the one we all read about in our history books. This is their time to make a difference as only students can~ by being in Denver to learn, and fight for assistance for their hometown.

Although the school district has received a discounted rate on hotel accommodations ($69.00) the total cost is just out of reach for this small school district when they are covering other costs for students such as food and transportation. Like other school districts across the state, they could use our help!WHY? The Colorado Preserve America Youth Summit participants and staff know that experiencing a place makes learning come alive for students. This opportunity will allow students to not only share their story, but to advocate for their community and take a leadership role in making a difference for their region when this region is going through a dustbowl WORSE than the one we all read about in our history books. This is their time to make a difference as only students can~ by being in Denver to learn, and fight for assistance for their hometown.

story:
Summary

GEDs and PhDs provides free, one-on-one tutoring for low-wage workers interested in passing the high school equivalency exam. We also cover the cost of the exam itself. The tutoring is done by PhDs working as adjuncts or otherwise underemployed. Tutors are paid a competitive hourly wage.

This initiative is run jointly by Sarah Kendzior, a journalist and academic, and Shannon Garth-Rhodes, a community organizer and educator who works with low-wage workers in St. Louis, Missouri.

What Does This Program Accomplish?

Low-wage workers cannot afford the fee for the high school equivalency exam. They also struggle with passing the exam, particularly if they have been out of school for a long time. They cannot afford tutoring. Any expenditure is a risk. This program eliminates the risk by making everything free.

Adjunct professors struggle to pay their bills, despite having advanced degrees. Many make salaries under the poverty line. This program would pay them a competitive hourly wage and allow them to use their education to provide a valuable service to fellow citizens.

Tutors will be matched with low-wage workers who struggle with the tutor's area of expertise. For example, if a worker is good at reading but has trouble in math, they could be matched with a math professor. Private tutoring may prove more beneficial than a general course, which does not always target a test-taker’s area of weakness. Workers will be matched with a tutor who they can count on and who will target their individual needs.

Tutors will be trained on the GED or HiSET by Garth-Rhodes, who has an advanced degree in education and has taught the high-school equivalency exam.

Where Is Your Money Going?

Your money will pay for GED tests for low-income workers, for a competitive hourly wage for tutors, and for materials (prep books, sample exams) for the GED test takers. The organizers of this campaign, Kendzior and  Garth-Rhodes, are volunteers and will not be paid. 

Broader Impact

Nowadays neither the most-educated nor the least-educated workers can make a living. Service workers and adjunct professors are both struggling in this economy, despite wildly disparate levels of education. 

This program would help low-wage workers get the credentials they need to be eligible for a better-paying job, and it would help PhDs earn extra income to pay their bills.

The two groups share goals and could learn from each other. Low-wage workers don’t have access to the same resources as PhDs. PhDs could be a source of advice about things like computer skills or applying to college. Low-wage professors are attempting to organize and form a union. Low-wage service workers are doing the same, but with greater success. PhDs could learn a lot from talking to low-wage workers involved in labor organization.

We hope that if this program is successful, it can be replicated in cities throughout the country. Low wages and expensive credentials are problems we all share.

Ways You Can Help

If you are a St. Louis-based low-wage worker who would like free tutoring, please contact us!

If you are a St. Louis-based instructor interested in being a tutor, please contact us!

Even if you cannot afford to donate, please help us spread the word about our campaign!

story:
Our Story

Art ala Cartes mission is to make art accessible to all children and families.  We know the importance of art in childrens lives and would like to offer memberships to low income families as well as non profit partners.  

 

The Impact

Many of these children do not get to do simple amusement activities with their families.  Birthday parties are out of the question for children in the homeless shelters.  By gifting memberships they have a space to invite their friends on their special day.  Art is also an amazing therapy for kids and providing an outlet for them is an amazing way to express their emotions.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $650 to be able to offer a family membership to the homesless shelter partner.  We also need $100 per low income family that we choose to help.  (If you know someone in the portland area that could benefit please email their story to artalacartepdx@hotmail.com

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this on social media sites!!  If you cannot donate funds (though even $1.00 helps) we ask that you drop off recycled goods and art supplies.  Most needed supplies are egg cartons, googly eyes, old puzzles, pom poms, fabric scraps, stickers/labels, small boxes, yogurt containers with lids, macaroni, feathers, kids related magazines, old calendars and greeting cards.

story: Chris doesn't have a passport. We all know he likes to travel and his new city will be fairly close to the Canadian border. To catalyze the inevitable, I'm trying to piece together the funds to buy him his passport. The page says $500 but we only need $140 and I'll be ceasing this campaign once I reach $140. Honestly, anything helps at all: $2, $5, $1. I'll try to cover what's not raised during this process. Get. Chris. Outta. Here.

story:
Goal Reached!

My first goal of $500 was reached! I have started a second campaign to try and match what I have already raised. Thank you all for the continuous support, it is incredible. Here is the link to the second campaign - 
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pavarotti-re...

Guate - Guate - Guatemala! 

In May, I got an amazing opportunity to study abroad during Maymester with CU Denver in San Lucas Toliman, Guatemala. We stayed at Pavarotti Education Center and got to work with the students. During our first day there we were taken on a tour of the school and got to walk through the classrooms and library. Being a future teacher the tour made me very emotional, and those aspects stuck out the most to me. The students are in need of books. They have a library that has a small supply. They are teaching the students English with Shakespeare poetry because they have no other option.  Before I left to come home I knew that I wanted to do something about what I saw. I believe that every child deserves an education no matter what their background is.

While we were at the school we took place in a cultural exchange with the students and taught them the Cha Cha Slide while they taught us a dance of their own. It was such an incredible time teaching each other our dances and then dancing together in front of the school. We were able to communicate great even with the language barrier. Some of the words in the Cha Cha Slide tell you to reverse, and then reverse again. That is why my fundraiser has the name that it does.

Lack of books - Why should you help?

Guatemala is one of the poorest countries in Latin America. 75% of the population lives below poverty line, and 58% lives below the extreme poverty line. 60% are illiterate in indigenous population and 75% are illiterate in rural areas. Families make on average $4 a day. Indigenous Mayans make up half population and account for less than a quarter of the income/ consumption. 

Two-thirds of the children are in poverty. The average schooling is 4 years and THREE out of 10 graduate 6th grade. “In 2007, only 63% of boys and 64% of girls enrolled in Primary school reached the final grade of Primary education,” (UNESCO Institute for Statistics). 9 out of 10 schools lack books and 1 out of 10 rural Guatemalan children even get opportunity to attend school. 

Schools are poorly funded, don’t have adequate teaching materials, lack adequate books, teaching guides, literacy materials and teachers are not trained properly. Many children cannot stay in school; they have to drop out to support their families, they cannot afford uniforms, books, supplies, and transportation. School is free but the fees are too high. 

The “Civil War” has a lot to do with education lacking – Mayans are still excluded from benefits of the country and still remain targets of racism and exclusion from land, labor, and education. When your country is being attacked, reading seems less important.

“Humankind will not recover from its mistake without global education.” 
              - Rigoberta Menchú Tum

Impact

The students at Pavarotti are some of the most talented kids I've ever gotten the experience to work with. I will be raising money to send back to Guatemala for the director of the school to purchase more books to fill the library walls. Anything and everything will be appreciated and will help those students. If you are not able to contribute then please help me spread the word and get my fundraiser out there.

San Lucas Toliman does something to you when you visit. The people, the students, the environment; it changes you. I came home with a piece of Guatemala in my heart, very close to me. I think about those students and my experiences everyday. I got very lucky to be able to travel down to Guatemala. Those students made such an impact on me and I want to be able to help them as much as I can.

story:
Short Summary


Hello!
My names Lily Bateman, I'm a 14 year old student at northeast kinds education Center in canning Nova Scotia.
The trip I'll be going on this summer is to Udaipur, India with 10-20 other youth from around the world. The main volunteer work we will be doing there is helping to build a school in rural India to provide education to the local children . Part of the Me To We trip experience includes intensive leadership training which I am really looking forward to.
I have been working on my own fundraising with projects such as painting murals, baby sitting and I am using my prize money from several arts competitions  I have taken part in towards my fees.
I am interested in many aspects of art as well as youth activism and I am very excited to see the world outside of my community and be immersed in a different culture.
Thank for taking the time to look over my page.
Lily

story:
Hello, my name is Jason Skoubye and I make animated math videos that teach the basic math concepts to elementary students.

I love helping kids learn and I love 3d animation and combined the two by creating videos that are already being used in schools and homes across the United States. 

As a kid I always struggled with math because I did not have a strong foundation in the early grades. I was always playing catch up to the other kids and needed to not only learn from a teacher but to see the math concepts in a fun and visual way that connected with me. After talking with countless teachers and parents I came up with the idea for these videos.

I started producing videos for the 2nd grade over a year ago and have almost two hours worth of videos that teachers and parents are using around the country. I want to continue with more videos for more grades in elementary school. 

I need your help to get videos for the 1st grade!

Here is a link to our website  http://www.commoncore4kids.com/


What is in it for you?

To get about 15 to 20 videos for the first grade it will cost $7,500 to produce and get the videos hosted on servers. We need this money to pay teachers who help us with the videos and for hosting services. 

Alright, now for the stuff you have waited for.......The Perks!

At any level above the $5 amount you can get these perks and the best part is you do not have to wait to receive your perk. We can give it to you once you grab your perk.

  • PERMANENT access to all videos, quizzes, worksheets and any future materials we make. Let me say this again - PERMANENT, this means no annual fees EVER. 
  • At certain levels your entire elementary school will get permanent access but not only that - All children in your school will get access at home through a login created for them.
  • One of the higher levels of perks is at the school district level - This grants permanent access to all elementary schools and all the children in each of these schools. What an awesome gift to give your school district!


If for some reason we do not reach our goal the money we do raise will still go towards making the First Grade Videos but we might not be able to make them as quickly as we hope to.


You can make an impact!

You really can help kids, teachers and parents by helping them have access to these videos. The website and videos are already up and running but with your help we can get first graders access to videos that really help them learn the basic math concepts.

Teachers do not get paid enough to buy this type of materials for schools and now is an excellent opportunity for all of us to help out. Help us produce more videos and give more access to students all over. We can do it!



What if I cannot afford to help?

  • Share this with a school administrator or teacher
  • Share a link on all social media and help us get the word out
  • Ask the community to help and go in on it together

Together we can make a difference and really help kids understand math. Together we can do it!


Here is a link to our website http://www.commoncore4kids.com/


Here is a short video on telling time. We have many others to see on our website with a free 30 day trial to make it easier.


Here is a short video on the penny and the nickel that we have made for First Grade. This along with about 25 other videos will be available with your help. Join us today!


We now have another First Grade Video done so check us out. Math Videos

story:
Greetings Family, Friends, and Supporters.

I, Rob Jackson, am serving as Vice President of Breakthrough's Young Professionals Board and I have taken the challenge upon myself to raise $500 dollars for Breakthrough's Home Court event- an event that celebrates the youth of East Garfield Park.

 

In Chicago's East Garfield Park, where disinvestment has left the neighborhood devoid of opportunity and full of broken dreams, Breakthrough is restoring the broken networks of youth and families and empowering adults in the community to achieve self-sufficiency and break the cycle of poverty.

 

On August 16, 2013, Breakthrough will host it's Home Court Festival at St. Louis Park in Chicago's Garfield Park Community. This event will include a basketball tournament set within a festival of face painting, arts and crafts, and grilling for local children in the community. We are anticipating over 300 children and we need your help! Please help contribute to this cause by choosing to donate. 100% of you donation will go to putting on a fun filled event for the children in the community.

 

Additionally, if you would like to learn more about the organization please visiting Breakthrough's website at http://breakthrough.org/

 

Warm Regards,

 

Rob Jackson II

 

P.S. If you are interested in volunteering or have any questions please reach out to me via e-mail @ rob.a.jacksonii@gmail.com

 

A little bit about what Breakthrough:


What is Breakthrough?

In 1992, Breakthrough was a simple drop-in shelter for homeless adults on Chicago's northside.

 

Today, Breakthrough operates two homeless shelters, a youth development program and a client-choice food pantry in East Garfield Park on Chicago’s westside.

 

Each year, the men’s and women’s shelters serve nearly 1,000 homeless adults, provide 24,000 nights of shelter and serve more than 70,000 meals.

 

The youth development program partners with families to surround young people from preschool to high school with role models. Students are exposed to academic enrichment, arts and science programs, and athletic and fitness programs.

 

The client-choice food pantry, meaning guests select food based on their families’ needs, distributes 10,000 bags of groceries to low-income families in the neighborhood, and offers employment training, on-site health care, and addictions counseling to hundreds of homeless individuals each year.

story:
Thank you for your support!  Together we made this dream become reality!

 

Latest Update!

In this envelope I hold my visa for the Czech Republic! It's official, we're going to Prague!  Let's keep up the good work! 

 

The Scoop

Hi! I'm Richard Fields and I am a full time graduate student earning my MFA in Film & Electronic Media at American University in Washington, D.C.  I've been accepted to study abroad at the Film and Television Academy of the Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague, Czech Republic, but I will need YOUR HELP to get there!

The Experience

The FAMU study abroad experience is a 1 semester (4 months, 114 day) fully immersive program. I will create a short film using 35mm film while receiving instruction from some of the best faculty in the world.  Early on in the program we will study our craft within the classroom for roughly 8-10 hours a day, with weekend excursions and Czech language courses mixed in along the way.  As the program progresses this classroom time will decrease, only to be replaced by our own short film productions!

Prauge is one of the few cities that has preserved it's history, as FAMU sits within the heart of the Czech Republic with buildings that date back to the 1860s.  While there, I want to share the sites of one of the world's most beautiful cities with you, and also a sneak peek of the film I will be creating.

 

The Story

I've been making films for the past 4 years, but the passion for creativity has been with me my entire life. This passion has been expressed through several avenues, and the common factor has been story telling.  Great stories are the source of our life's greatest lessons, and provide the opportunity to influence us as people.  These days, I find myself with a camera everywhere I go, capturing as much of the world around me to share my expereinces with people like you.  It is this power for change, education, and inspiration that has influenced my decision to dedicate my life and love towards making films. 

   

The Breakdown

Your generous donations will contribute to our experience in Prague!

Here's how:

Cost of FAMU Study Abroad: $5,600

Cost of Plane Tickets: $1,302.40 (Cheapest)

Cost Plane Ticket Processing Fee: $35

 

Total: $6,937.40


Although this does not cover the costs of the semester tuition at American university, but the $7,000 will cover the majority of the costs associated with this study abroad experience, allowing for the fluctuation in airline fees.


But what if you raise more?

I'm glad you asked!  Each dollar raised over the goal will go towards enhancing the educational experience. Indiegogo takes 4% of the funding if the goal is reached, 9% if not, so I actually do need to raise over my goal.  Also, you'll be contributing towards my American University tuition and production costs of my upcoming film!

The Ideas

Send me your ideas? What does that even mean?

Well, I'm interested in making this as interactive of a trip as possible.  Something like "project imagin8ion" meets a film student.  

Excited yet?  I'd love to hear YOUR input on things you'd like to see in a film, and the best and most original ideas I'd love to discuss with you to incorporate them into my next film.  Yes film credits will be included!  So whatever way you express your creativity, I want you to share it with me, and who knows you might be my next source of inspiration!

Examples:

Genres, Poems, Songs, Pictures, Situations, Names, Personalities, Scenarios, Places, Paintings, Character Types, Drawings, and the list goes on! 

The Links

To view the website and short films seen in the above images and mentioned in the campaign video, follow the links below:

Website: www.richardtfields.com

Vimeo: www.vimeo.com/richardtfields

Contact: richard.t.fields@gmail.com

 

The Questions


I didn't answer all of your questions? Let's talk!  Email the address above for more info!
story_txt:
Thank you for your support!  Together we made this dream become reality!
 
Latest Update!

In this envelope I hold my visa for the Czech Republic! It's official, we're going to Prague!  Let's keep up the good work! 
 
The Scoop
Hi! I'm Richard Fields and I am a full time graduate student earning my MFA in Film & Electronic Media at American University in Washington, D.C.  I've been accepted to study abroad at the Film and Television Academy of the Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague, Czech Republic, but I will need YOUR HELP to get there!


The Experience
The FAMU study abroad experience is a 1 semester (4 months, 114 day) fully immersive program. I will create a short film using 35mm film while receiving instruction from some of the best faculty in the world.  Early on in the program we will study our craft within the classroom for roughly 8-10 hours a day, with weekend excursions and Czech language courses mixed in along the way.  As the program progresses this classroom time will decrease, only to be replaced by our own short film productions!
Prauge is one of the few cities that has preserved it's history, as FAMU sits within the heart of the Czech Republic with buildings that date back to the 1860s.  While there, I want to share the sites of one of the world's most beautiful cities with you, and also a sneak peek of the film I will be creating.
 
The Story
I've been making films for the past 4 years, but the passion for creativity has been with me my entire life. This passion has been expressed through several avenues, and the common factor has been story telling.  Great stories are the source of our life's greatest lessons, and provide the opportunity to influence us as people.  These days, I find myself with a camera everywhere I go, capturing as much of the world around me to share my expereinces with people like you.  It is this power for change, education, and inspiration that has influenced my decision to dedicate my life and love towards making films. 
   
The Breakdown
Your generous donations will contribute to our experience in Prague!
Here's how:
Cost of FAMU Study Abroad: $5,600
Cost of Plane Tickets: $1,302.40 (Cheapest)
Cost Plane Ticket Processing Fee: $35
 
Total: $6,937.40
Although this does not cover the costs of the semester tuition at American university, but the $7,000 will cover the majority of the costs associated with this study abroad experience, allowing for the fluctuation in airline fees.

I'm glad you asked!  Each dollar raised over the goal will go towards enhancing the educational experience. Indiegogo takes 4% of the funding if the goal is reached, 9% if not, so I actually do need to raise over my goal.  Also, you'll be contributing towards my American University tuition and production costs of my upcoming film!

Well, I'm interested in making this as interactive of a trip as possible.  Something like "project imagin8ion" meets a film student.  
Excited yet?  I'd love to hear YOUR input on things you'd like to see in a film, and the best and most original ideas I'd love to discuss with you to incorporate them into my next film.  Yes film credits will be included!  So whatever way you express your creativity, I want you to share it with me, and who knows you might be my next source of inspiration!
