story:
Dear potential funders,

Play-Place for Autistic Children humbly requests your partnership to provide a fun-filled,  judgment free haven of hope for families affected by autism. Play-Place serves the nation’s fourth state most affected by autism with over 16,000 students enrolled in Michigan schools and approximately 50,000 individuals living in Michigan with an autism spectrum disorder. As a 501(c)3 nonprofit, Play-Place’s objective is to help restore those orphaned opportunities of normalcy by offering families something as simple as the chance to see a movie together — often for the very first time; or receiving that special invitation to a birthday party or sleepover they’re not typically asked to attend.

Through a unique play-powered environment, Play-Place combines recreation and education with a variety of social, occupational and physical therapeutic overtones designed to promote endless hours of excitement, cognitive and social development, sensory integration, balance and coordination, as well as professional support services and respite relief for parents and siblings. Our one-of-a-kind destination focuses on development, life skills and independence to assist families with the everyday nuances of “living with autism.” There is no place like Play-Place anywhere in the world. Play-Place has NO age restrictions. Our youngest program participant is 3 years old and our oldest is 52.  Our bottom line is to create a shared ambiance of inclusion, acceptance and support.

Play-Place for Autistic Children’s capital campaign seeks $125,000 towards the development and construction of our 25,000 square foot safe-haven to address the education, human services and community development needs of this population. Play-Place seeks funding for architectural, design development, and construction services for building improvements. The total build-out cost for Play-Place are an estimated $1,324,000. Securement of the proposed $125,000 from generous donors like you, in conjunction with sponsorships, private donors and foundation grants will keep us moving forward towards our build-out goal.

We appreciate your time and consideration to join hands with Play-Place for Autistic Children in our mission to make a life-changing impact in the lives of so many families affected by autism.  Should you have any questions or comments, please feel free to contact Play-Place at 586-254-6533 or visit our website at www.autisticplayplace.org.

Media Coverage

My TV 20 Detroit - Play-Place allies with another local nonprofit, bringing free supplies to children affected by autism
Metro Parent Magazine - "... Promising lots of fun and an incredible community."
Crain's Detroit Business - "[Play-Place will] create a space where children and families challenged by autism can be included, accepted and supported."
The Voice - "[Shell Jones'] goal was to create a place of understanding, therapy and fun for autistic children and their families"
Sterling Heights Sentry - "... The play place will have plenty of activities that will allow children with special needs to play and learn in an affirming environment."
Shelby TV - "Inclusion, acceptance, and support are just a few of the words describing the... Play-Place for Autistic Children."
Macomb Daily - "[Play-Place] will have programs that are specific to people who have autism and developmental disabilities. It is a venue for education, resource management, recreation and therapy."



AUTISM FACTS:

  • More kids will be diagnosed with autism this year than with AIDS, cancer and diabetes combined;

  • Boys are five times more likely than girls to have autism (1 in 54);

  • Autism is the fastest growing serious developmental disorder in the U.S.;

  • The divorce rate for families with autism is 80%; and

  • Autism costs the nation $137 billion per year, 60% of which is for adult services.

Our Mission

Play-Place for Autistic Children is dedicated to the support and growth of children affected by autism and their families through inclusive play, programming, group therapies, resource management, and respite relief. Formulated on the fact that services and treatment can be expensive and not covered by most health insurance, Play-Place’s objective is to alleviate costs, optimize alliances and defeat autism via big smiles and breakthrough moments. Play-Place’s exclusive model will be a revolutionary compliment to the autism equation of intervention and awareness.

Our 25,000 square foot, one-of-a-kind facility will boast a computer café for interactive academic skill building and communication; a Haircut Hut for a soothing, grooming experience; an “Art of Autism” workshop for creative expression, peer relationship building and self-esteem enrichment; an 18x20 colorful play-scape offering gross and fine motor development, motor planning and sensory-integration; a giant gladiator slide for sensory-integration, balance and depth perception; a 48 seat cinema theatre for behavioral and focus therapy; a Bistro/coffee shop for  that “me-too” conversation, sharing and a chance to exhale -- together with budget-conscious supplementary services including group speech and occupational therapy, hyperbaric chamber therapy, sensory integration services and more.


Our Vision

Play-Place’s vision is to pioneer experiences that combine the magic of hope with the power of play and recovery. Our focus is to become the world’s premier destination for autism relief.




Program Highlights

  • CBI (Community-Based Instruction) education curriculum offering multifaceted lesson plans directed towards local area schools serving as a source for educators and therapists seeking life skill development and classroom reinforcement through scheduled visits. 20+ specialized and comprehensive lesson plans. **Note CBIs are a required part of all special education plans.

  • Resource Management Forums – Weekly conferences connecting parents with autism professionals who provide autism support services, including chiropractic effects on autism, special needs trusts, autism dental specialists, independent living sources, etc.

  • WorkPlus - employment opportunities for young adults affected by autism, focusing on individual strengths and talents with well-defined goals in a safe, inclusive and supportive environment. Individuals will learn job skills, build knowledge and receive continuous support while enjoying a sense of accomplishment, productivity and independence. Play-Place’s vocational/transitional program will include opportunities to work in hospitality/basic food service, greenscaping, janitorial service, commercial kitchen and coffee shop, a creative design workshop with craft and art production, a retail store, maintenance, and light clerical. Our ultimate goal is to have those affected by autism comprise 50% of our staff.

  • “Art of Autism”- This program doubles as a vocational rehabilitation agenda offering a unique approach to employment for those with less cognitive skills and unable to function in an employment capacity, yet are able to share artistic expressions through art. It features the opportunity to showcase framed artwork decoratively displayed throughout the center for sale and at bi-annual art expositions at Play-Place.

  • Career Mobility program is designed to train and advance our employees to more challenging, higher paying positions within the community. Play-Place will initially focus on advancement in three major career paths: Data Processing, Office Services and Accounting basics.


Issue or Problem Our Program Addresses:

While autism’s primary focus of intervention is clinical, research and biomedical based, no one seems to address the everyday nuances of “living with autism.” Outside of the never-ending therapy sessions, doctor visits, blood draws relative to biomedical treatment and the everyday classroom regimen of school, where can these autism affected children and families go without being judged, stared at, mocked, bullied or made to feel uncomfortable? Where can the entire family go to experience some form of normalcy, inclusion and socialization? Play-Place for Autistic Children embraces the elements of play, family, and recovery while the majority of autism supports are very rigid, inflexibly structured and deals solely with the affected individual.

Our unprecedented model combines: play (a child’s natural form of engagement), education (both academic and resource), respite relief, management and direction to assist and support the challenges of autism. In comparison, other facilities that strive to incorporate play within their curriculum at most are only able to achieve the typical school-like sensory room layout with a ball pit, a few therapy swings and colorful mats. Play-Place houses an amusement type schematic design with therapeutic overtones throughout for an exceptional format of fun, friendly, flexible intervention. Additionally, limited and infrequent fun-themed community events and therapeutic programming targeted towards special needs children happen during a short window of operation (2-3 hours) and are oftentimes poorly promoted. Play-Place prides itself in the delightful element of accessibility. Driven by the demand of unpredictability, unique needs and flexibility, we are open 7 days a week, from 9AM-8PM with no age restrictions.

How is our program unique from other programs for children with autism?

The individual, family and community impact of Play-Place’s comprehensive programming is monumental. Play-Place’s vision encompasses individual growth for those affected by autism through therapy, education, inclusion, and social support; family fortitude through respite relief, sustainability and renewal – thwarting the 80% divorce rate of marriages affected by autism; and community empowerment including cost alleviation, enhanced education and awareness, health and employability. Play-Place’s model of unique purpose, design and impact embraces the entire family as opposed to solely focusing on the affected individual. It bridges the gap between isolation and inclusion; therapy and the everyday nuances of living with autism; and misunderstanding and being understood. Play-Place’s variety of services and opportunities stand unmatched in the autism community. There are very few parent/support groups and just as few and infrequent community activities that cater to the “family” aspect of autism.

What is the expected outcome of the program for which we seek support?

The outcome of this program is to serve as a haven of hope for families affected by autism.  The opportunity to function in a natural environment is concrete, reinforcing, and assists in providing educational relevancy for kids and respite relief for the parents and siblings. Play-Place’s multi-purpose programming of education, therapy and recreation is specifically designed to accommodate special needs families seven days a week for family flexibility, respite comfort and overall convenience offering families simple experiences with life-changing impact. Play-Place adds fulfillment and value to the void of something as simple as the chance to see a movie together — often for the very first time; or receiving that special invitation to a birthday party or sleepover they’re not typically asked to attend. Our bottom line is inclusion, acceptance and support.

How will we sustain this facility/program beyond current funding?

The requested funding will give impetus to an unparalleled destination of education, therapy and family support which will not only reinforce individual and family development, but also impact community growth and help shave the nation’s $137 billion per year cost of autism. As outlined below, Play-Place will have a diverse income stream. Based on market research, parent feedback and special education professionals’ input, we have designed a comprehensive model of therapy, social support and sustainability. Play-Place’s low cost, two-tier, monthly fee-based membership will offer an all-inclusive experience of fun, therapy, respite, information, convenience and belonging for the entire family. Our membership revenue will be a key contribution in offsetting operation costs. In addition, one of Play-Place’s principal portals of information, connection, awareness and direct communication will be our advertising solutions platform adjoining autism-related professionals (including dentists, chiropractors, behavior analysts and others) to Play-Place’s exclusive families for invaluable, life-changing connections. Our CBI (Community-Based Instruction) education curriculum (multifaceted lesson plans directed towards local area schools) will be a premier attraction and education/therapeutic source for educators and therapists seeking life skill development and classroom reinforcement through scheduled visits. Play-Place will compliment this programming with CBI extensions (after school life skill and education activities) for children and siblings.

Our target market will be consumer-based with a focus on families affected by autism and other special needs targeting all ages, all ethnicities, all incomes and all education levels.

What is the projected opening objective?  

Play-Place is slated to open its doors August 2014 at which time we anticipate completion of the build-out/renovation process, applicable licensing and program design.

SO PLEASE HELP US!

Play-Place for Autistic Children has never tried crowdfunding before and is a no-overhead, family-focused organization. Whether you can spare $3, $30, or $3,000, every amount will get us closer to realizing our vision for families and children affected by autism and other special needs. We welcome your comments and feedback, and if you have any questions please do not hesitate to call us at 586-254-6533.

View the donor acknowledgement list here.

story:
"Some people search for a beautiful place, others make a place beautiful."   -Hazrat Inayat Khan

On a recent work visit to Jamaica, I had the opportunity to meet someone who made my travel experience a beautiful exchange.  My work involves film/content creation and I'm currently working on a multimedia project that spans a couple of island nations, including Jamaica.

During my trip, I went in search of a special gift for a friend of mine that is undergoing cancer treatment back in Dallas.  I found the perfect a hand-knitted hat, made by Donnett at Donnett's Variety Shoppe, but I also met a young boy named Okery.


Not all entrepreneurs dream of building a big company that will someday be publicly traded or to launch an app that sells for $3 Billion, some have the simple goal of making enough money to go to school and elevate their life to a new level.  "Progress" is a popular word in Jamaica. Okery simply wants progress.

Okery is 14 years old, in 9th Grade, he lives with his family on the Westend Rd.  This is known as "quiet" side of Negril, a perfect setting for a nice bike ride.  There are small boutique hotels, quaint restaurants, the historic Negril lighthouse, cliff diving at the famous Rick's Cafe and local artist selling crafts along this road.  Okery makes bracelets, custom bracelets.

Okery offered to make me a bracelet.  He didn't push, he wasn't rude, he told me why his bracelets were different and how each one is unique.  So I agreed, after all, they were unique.  As he worked, we had the chance to sit and talk.  He talked about his life, his family and his love for Jamaica.  He also told me about his school, which was far away, and how he makes the bracelets so he can afford transportation to get to his school everyday. 

We continued to talk, he told me he is also saving money for a bike.  Not a bike for himself, but a bike that he could rent to tourists so that he can eventually go to college.  Okery made enough bracelets to buy 1 bike and he was only $30 away from having enough money for his 2nd bike.  Being business-minded, he didn't want to offer them for rent until he had a pair.  He's a smart young man.  I gave Okery $30 in exchange for a few bracelets for my crew and told him I would return in a couple of days to pick them up. 


The next morning our crew was up bright and early and headed inland to Little London.  As we approached Donnett's Variety Shoppe, I noticed Okery was already open for business and there was his new bike being offered for rent.  The nearest bike shop is in Savannah La Mar, about an hour away from his home in Westend.  It amazed me that he took the $30 I gave him the previous afternoon, quickly found a way to Savannah and had the bike ready by morning.  Not only was the new bike there, but the custom bracelets were finished as well.

The conversation I had with him that morning stuck with me for the remainder of my time in Jamaica and it's still with me.  It went like this:

Okery: "I like it when people like you come to Jamaica."

Me: "Why?"

Okery; "Because you took the time to talk with me."

The $30 I spent with Okery, was the best $30 I spent in Jamaica.  Not because of the beautiful bracelets I got in return, but because my small gesture made Okery feel relevant and that meant everything to him and to me.

Okery's long term goal is to buy 4 more bikes that he can offer for rent in order to save enough money to go to college.  I'd like for this campaign to send a message to Okery.  I want him to know that he isn't just relevant to me, but his story resonated with many people.  Our small combined effort can offer a huge change in his life. 

His determination and positive spirit is strong.  His business idea is simple but the demand is there.  He is situated in a great location, which makes this business more likely to succeed.  He just needs a little help getting started.

What We Need

We will be in Jamaica for work in June, so we will cover the costs of transporting the bikes (which is quite complicated) and a few accessories that will make them safe and more attractive to visiting Tourists.

Our goal of $850 will provide:

  •  4 Road Bikes totaling $650  (the average bike in Jamaica costs @$150. Shipping costs for getting a bike from the US to JA is equivalent to buying a bike.  So the $$ we raise will go twice as far by buying local in Jamaica.)
  •  Bike Repair Kit/Manual & Tools
  •  Bike Locks

The Impact

 Taking the time to show interest, build relationships and offer support in the communities in which we travel promotes respect and appreciation for other cultures, including our own.  There is strength in numbers and overall the message of support is just as valuable as the bikes themselves. 


If we meet our goal not only will you be part of this wonderful delivery, but we  will document the entire event, including your contributions, so we can share Okery's story in the hopes of inspiring a more connected and kind travel culture.

If we don't reach our goal  we will take what we raise as far as we can towards the purchase of the bikes.

If we exceed our goal we will make a donation of school supplies to Okery's school on behalf of all of our supporters.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that while you might not be able to contribute monetarily, your support in sharing this campaign is just as valuable.  If you know an individual or organization that is passionate about biking, travel and supporting small businesses, please spread the word.
story_txt:
"Some people search for a beautiful place, others make a place beautiful."   -Hazrat Inayat Khan
On a recent work visit to Jamaica, I had the opportunity to meet someone who made my travel experience a beautiful exchange.  My work involves film/content creation and I'm currently working on a multimedia project that spans a couple of island nations, including Jamaica.During my trip, I went in search of a special gift for a friend of mine that is undergoing cancer treatment back in Dallas.  I found the perfect a hand-knitted hat, made by Donnett at Donnett's Variety Shoppe, but I also met a young boy named Okery.Not all entrepreneurs dream of building a big company that will someday be 
publicly traded or to launch an app that sells for $3 Billion, some have the simple goal of making enough money to go to school and elevate their life to a new level.  "Progress" is a popular word in Jamaica. Okery simply wants progress.Okery is 14 years old, in 9th Grade, he lives with his family on the Westend Rd.  This is known as "quiet" side of Negril, a perfect setting for a nice bike ride.  There are small boutique hotels, quaint restaurants, the historic Negril lighthouse, cliff diving at the famous Rick's Cafe and local artist selling crafts along this road.  Okery makes bracelets, custom bracelets.Okery offered to make me a bracelet.  He didn't push, he wasn't rude, he told me why his bracelets were different and how each one is unique.  So I agreed, after all, they were unique.  As he worked, we had the chance to sit and talk.  He talked about his life, his family and his love for Jamaica.  He also told me about his school, which was far away, and how he makes the bracelets so he can afford transportation to get to his school everyday.  We continued to talk, he told me he is also saving money for a bike.  Not a bike for himself, but a bike that he could rent to tourists so that he can eventually go to college.  Okery made enough bracelets to buy 1 bike and he was only $30 away from having enough money for his 2nd bike.  Being business-minded, he didn't want to offer them for rent until he had a pair.  He's a smart young man.  I gave Okery $30 in exchange for a few bracelets for my crew and told him I would return in a couple of days to pick them up.  The next morning our crew was up bright and early and headed inland to Little London.  As we approached Donnett's Variety Shoppe, I noticed Okery was already open for business and there was his new bike being offered for rent.  The nearest bike shop is in Savannah La Mar, about an hour away from his home in Westend.  It amazed me that he took the $30 I gave him the previous afternoon, quickly found a way to Savannah and had the bike ready by morning.  Not only was the new bike there, but the custom bracelets were finished as well.The conversation I had with him that morning stuck with me for the remainder of my time in Jamaica and it's still with me.  It went like this:
Okery: "I like it when people like you come to Jamaica."
Me: "Why?"
Okery; "Because you took the time to talk with me."
The $30 I spent with Okery, was the best $30 I spent in Jamaica.  Not because of the beautiful bracelets I got in return, but because my small gesture made Okery feel relevant and that meant everything to him and to me. Okery's long term goal is to buy 4 more bikes that he can offer for rent in order to save enough money to go to college.  I'd like for this campaign to send a message to Okery.  I want him to know that he isn't just relevant to me, but his story resonated with many people.  Our small combined effort can offer a huge change in his life.  His determination and positive spirit is strong.  His business idea is simple but the demand is there.  He is situated in a great location, which makes this business more likely to succeed.  He just needs a little help getting started.What We NeedWe will be in Jamaica for work in June, so we will cover the costs of 
transporting the bikes (which is quite complicated) and a few 
accessories that will make them safe and more attractive to visiting Tourists.Our goal of $850 will provide:
 4 Road Bikes totaling $650  (the average bike in Jamaica costs @$150. Shipping costs for getting a bike from the US to JA is equivalent to buying a bike.  So the $$ we raise will go twice as far by buying local in Jamaica.) 

 Bike Repair Kit/Manual & Tools

 Bike Locks

The Impact Taking the time to show interest, build relationships and offer support in the communities in which we travel promotes respect and appreciation for other cultures, including our own.  There is strength in numbers and overall the message of support is just as valuable as the bikes themselves. If we meet our goal not only will you be part of this wonderful delivery, but we  will document the entire event, including your contributions, so we can share Okery's story in the hopes of inspiring a more connected and kind travel culture.If we don't reach our goal  we will take what we raise as far as we can towards the purchase of the bikes.If we exceed our goal we will make a donation of school supplies to Okery's school on behalf of all of our supporters.Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that while you might not be able to contribute monetarily, your support in sharing this campaign is just as valuable.  If you know an individual or organization that is passionate about biking, travel and supporting small businesses, please spread the word.

story:
ABOUT THE IDEX FELLOWSHIP

The IDEX Global Fellowship is a 6-month program that offers professional, cultural and social immersion for talented individuals interested in launching careers in the social enterprise sector. Fellows are strategically placed in innovative game-changing environments throughout India and collaborate with their placement organizations to (1) to assess weaknesses and opportunities within their respective spheres and (2) to build innovative solutions that are both scalable and sustainable.

 As a Fellow, I will be living and working on adolescent girls' empowerment in Hyderabad, India.  I am unbelievably excited to build on my past experiences in educating marginalized communities through working for VOICE 4 Girls in Hyderabad, India.  VOICE's mission is to enable marginalized adolescent girls in India to take charge of their futures by imparting critical knowledge, spoken English, and life skills through activity-based camps and mentorship programs. While I've been dreaming of this line of work for quite some time, I need YOU to help me get there!

~~I am also looking forward to overcoming my injuries and running a half marathon, like I've always dreamed!  I am also planning on building on my dance experiences and taking Bharatanatyam--South Indian Classical dance--classes.  Some of you may know that I had the privilege to be in a world premiere Bharatanatyam performance two years ago, and I cannot wait to rekindle my love for the dance form!

MY STORY

A Chicago native and Wesleyan University graduate, I have been committed to combating injustice from a young age.  As young as elementary school, I was educating my classmates on genocide and crimes against humanity.  In high school, I seized the opportunity to continue this work through club leadership, and I also engaged in extracurricular study of civic engagement, participating in service-learning intensives on economic inequality in urban Chicago and post-Katrina reconstruction in New Orleans.  

My life and work at Wesleyan as a Government and Civic Engagement major hammered home my firm beliefs in every individual's right to health, education, and economic justice.  I took on an array of responsibilities, from leading town hunger and homelessness advocacy initiatives, to tutoring college courses in prisons, to founding a local, organic, and affordable produce buying club (more information Here!) 

I also spent the summer of 2011 in Kibera slum of Nairobi, mentoring at-risk girls at Shining Hope for Communities' Kibera School for Girls, and I studied post-conflict transformation in Uganda and Rwanda.  During my time in Uganda, I interned for a human rights organization and aided in their work to monitor human rights violations in hard-to-access villages and to educate adolescents on their human rights.

In essence, I deeply value the respect that every single individual is due, and out of this respect comes my driving passion to work with others and promote social justice.

THE IMPACT

~But Everyone is Talking about Women's Empowerment today!~

The Reality in India:

  • 47% of girls are married before age 18
  • 30% of those married girls are involved in decisions made about their health
  • 30% of girls graduate from the 10th grade
  • Less than 40% of women work for pay
  • Only 15% of adolescent boys and girls receive sex education

VOICE works with girls to develop the tools and support that they need to make informed decisions about their lives.  Furthermore, VOICE 4 Girls doesn't tell its campers what's right or wrong, but it rather arms them with the knowledge and confidence that they need to make that decision for themselves.

WHY AND HOW YOU CAN HELP

While IDEX covers the cost of my housing for these coming six months, everything else--travel, food, health, and tuition--is up to me.  I am covering the cost of my flight travel and health needs, but the living expenses are where YOU come in.  In the past, I have excelled working on difficult tasks in challenging, unfamiliar environments, but I need YOUR HELP to do this.  I am asking friends, family, acquaintances, and friends of friends to contribute to my cause as I volunteer my time, energy, and passion for the next six months.

Want to help but just can't donate?

  • Please spread the word about my campaign!  You can easily connect people this Indiegogo page, or else feel free to introduce over email, snail mail, owl, or any form of communication that inspires you.
  • If you know anyone in the region or country, please connect me!  I'm always desperate for new friends and advice.
  • Educate yourself!  I'm still learning too, but here are a couple of interesting reads:  Logics of Empowerment: Development, Gender, and Governance in Neoliberal India by Anu Sharma; http://www.idexaccelerator.com/#!enterprise-partners/cigc; voice4girls.org

My Experience:

While sitting in a Kibera School for Girls (KSG) classroom three years ago in July 2011, I overhead one student, Molet, gladly accept another student's uneaten lunch, announcing, "I must eat all of the food that I can and get fat because I am poor--" and one of the KSG teachers immediately intervened.  "Molet!  Don't you dare say that we are poor!  Look around you, look at how much you have, this school, these sisters.  Do not say that you are poor.  We, we are RICH."

I hope to bring this same pride and strength of character to adolescent girls in Hyderabad.

THANK YOU SO MUCH

For all of the love and support!  

--Francesca

story:
NOTE TO ALL WE SUSPENDED THE CAMPAIGN EARLY ON:  

Shortly after we launched the fundraising campaign for Brooklyn Young Filmmakers, it became clear that the wonderful storefront business we had moved in with, Huey's Chueys, might not be able to survive this especially harsh and snowy winter.  BYFC can be in the space only if Huey's Chueys is. So we did not promote our campaign as we held our breath as the sisters struggled with whether or not they could afford to continue.

The holiday months November and December had been unusually slow and there were many days in January where no customers came in the store, and now there is still February and March to get through.  No one expected this winter.   For many small minority-owned businesses in gentrified communities (meaning high rents) this winter could prove deadly.   

It has for Huey's Chueys.  With great sadness and to the disappointment of their loyal customers, Jenny and Denny are closing the store, and something special is being lost from our community.  To understand what businesses like Huey's Chueys mean to the spirit of the community read this:  The Night That Made Me Fall In Love With Fort Greene

Brooklyn Young Filmmakers will be temporarily back to organizing our activities from home offices, while continuing with our community projects at other People's Hollywood locations on Myrtle. We're launching our Skillshare Project with an evening of Skillshares March 21st at the Ingersoll Community Center. 

Best wishes to us all

Trayce, Brooklyn Young Filmmakers

p.s. read our campaign text below if you want to know what we are trying to do


HELP US CREATE A PEOPLE'S HOLLYWOOD THAT NURTURES BEGINNERS  

In November, 2013 Brooklyn Young Filmmakers, a volunteer-run 501(c)(3) non-profit, moved in with Huey's Chueys, a Myrtle Avenue storefront business in the Fort Greene / Clinton Hill area of Brooklyn.  Huey's Chueys, a retro sweets shop, was in danger of closing because of rising rent and a loss of regulars as the neighborhood has rapidly gentrified. 

Grassroots filmmakers depend upon an extended community to beg, borrow, and learn from. Brooklyn Young Filmmakers saw the opportunity being in a storefront could provide to create a neighborhood cultural hub. The more exposure one has to diverse lifestyles, human interactions, and avenues of knowledge, the more complete a person will be and the more inspired their accomplishments.

                            

Trayce Gardner, BYFC founder and director, and neighborhood resident, found co-conspirators in the twin Jamaican sisters, Jenny and Denny, who run Huey’s Chueys. The sisters had dreamed of evolving their store into a café and cultural outpost that highlights all the diverse cultures in our neighborhood.(Of course while remaining the only ice cream parlor on Myrtle!). 

THE FEAR

We also shared a joint fear – that what is new will not be blended successfully with what is old.  Yes, more affluent residents and businesses are moving into our neighborhood.  But instead of ignoring or replacing the old, what if creative introductions and collaborations are promoted?  If you have ever visited Brooklyn and loved the mix of cultures, races, and economic groups, you will understand why we so desperately want to succeed.  

HELP KEEP THE GATE OPEN TO A PEOPLE’S HOLLYWOOD

We will soon be at the end of our three month seed period!   After all our work, our sacrifices, our laying foundation…..we could have to close the doors in February.  We are asking you to support Brooklyn Young Filmmakers, and give us another two months to implement our business plan.  If Brooklyn Young Filmmakers is able to grow, we will bring in more foot traffic to the Huey’s Chuey Café, and a small minority owned business will be able to stay in the community.

WHAT WE HAVE ACCOMPLISHED IN SHORT TIME

-  Transformed a storage room into the BYFC office where we hold classes

-  Reconfigured the store’s seating area to create more space for events

-  There has been a great increase in new foot traffic into Huey’s Chueys as people sign-up to participate in BYFC programs

-  We have create new projects in development:  411 Directory for Grassroots Filmmakers, Used Book Drive for Browsing Library, and Skillshare  

-  Recruited two other businesses and a public housing community center to be People’s Hollywood locations that can host events

LAUNCHING OUR BUSINESS PLAN

Brooklyn Young Filmmakers has a business plan that includes grassroots revenue sources: teaching classes, monthly events, renting the space for events, and selling BYFC merchandise.  Now that we are in the storefront space, we are also writing proposals as a cultural center and a community development project.   But we need time to launch our plan.

WHAT WE WILL DO WITH $10,000

We will be able to cover for four months:

-  Rent, utilities, and office supplies

-  Marketing costs and grant writing consultant

-  Stipends for teen office interns

Right now we are taking things month by month and trying to fundraise in multiple ways.   So if this campaign can bring in enough to help us survive even one month, it could be enough to help us get over.   In the spring (after all the cold and snow) we are planning classes and events which will bring in income, plus we can rent out the cafe space for events to bring in income.  

WHAT YOU GET

Help us continue to write a happy beginning for our Brooklyn story and get your name, your city, and your country in our credits for helping to keep Brooklyn– Brooklyn.  Plus we have some cool Brooklyn perks – choose from artist David Weinholtz’s images of the city to the (5) different retro designs on BYFC’s t-shirts!  Come ‘on, for $5, give a big Hooray for Brooklyn! 

                          

                                             

BYFC BACK STORY

Since 2001 Brooklyn Young Filmmakers has offered classes (scriptwriting, becoming a production assistant, and how to organize a low/no budget film and run a set) and produced careers in film seminars with professionals from different crafts.  (See BYFC Milestones).

story:
In short, I need your help. I am at the point in my life where I can focus on becoming a Certified Sommelier. I have eschewed this title for several years, because I was comfortable with my own pursuit of knowledge; however, I have reached the place, that I feel this certification can help me be a better wine steward. Many of you have followed my twitter, listened to my radio show, attended my classes and tastings. If I have helped you in anyway with wine in the past, please help me become a better wine guy, so that I may do even more for you and this city in the future. My goal is to take this certification and find new ways to better serve those interested in wine in Oklahoma City. However, I cannot do it alone. 

The certification requires three days and two tests, which I intend to complete at the same time. After passing the CSW, I feel I can pass this test on the first try. The cost of the first test is $525.00 and the cost of the second test is $325.00.  Being a single father, raising two teenagers by myself, does not afford me the luxury of taking such a venture out of pocket. Between everyone on Facebook, Twitter and Tasting Notes, I believe this is an achievable goal. Anything that helps me attain this goal would be greatly appreciated, whether it is sharing this campaign, donating a bit of money or helping me study. I have never tried anything like this before, but felt like this was a noble cause. My furthering education only helps me educate others, bring better wines to our state and make us a more competitive state.

story:
What does Thaakat mean

Thaakat: (urdu: thaa-qut) - noun

1. the quality or state of being strong

2. something or someone that gives strength

3. a source of moral and mental power or encouragement

What does Thaakat Foundation do? 

No matter how simple the effort or how large the cause, we believe in restoring hope and advancing minds. We promote charitable giving and humanitarian work among the youth by selflessly supporting the act of giving back.

Thaakat Foundation was started by a group of students in the summer of 2007. With Facebook being our initial platform, Thaakat Foundation has grown rapidly, and in 2008 it became a 501(c)(3) government recognized not for profit organization.  Constant appreciation from our supporters and NGO partnerships continue to fuel our initiative towards social responsibility.

Current Projects

Righteous' Konadu Basic School
Thaakat has adopted the small community of Tanobaose in south western Ghana to help provide education to children in need. We have partnered with Clement “Righteous” Boamah, founder of the Konadu Basic School, a free primary school in this village, and will help expand the number of classrooms so more students can attend, while helping Clement provide a safe learning environment and sustained education for these children beyond primary school.
Dreams for Kachra Kundi

In 2012, Thaakat opened the doors to a newly constructed nine-classroom school in Kachra Kundi, and in 2013, expanded with six additional classrooms to accommodate the growing demand for education in this large garbage dump community located 50 miles outside of Karachi, Pakistan.

The 15-classroom school is solely funded by Thaakat Foundation, and we hope to continue support by funding student meals, books, school supplies, staff salaries, and classroom expansion. In 2014, we have over 500 children in attendance and have launched the construction of 12 more classrooms. Our school boasts a 40% female attendance rate and we continue to work with the principal of Idara Al Khair to continue to progress a cultural shift in this area so that more girls may experience their basic right to an education.

Fatama Maternity Center
Thaakat Foundation’s commitment to healthcare and women's empowerment lives on through our newly constructed maternity center. This facility was opened in April 2014 in a rural village in Sierra Leone in Pujehon district. The struggle to get this facility up and running has been a battle worth fighting entirely.

The motivation behind this project: As you drive on the dirt road to Blama Perri you will see many small buildings, halfway constructed, windows undone—almost as if there had been a lot of promise to create something but it never finished. Due to lack of resources, problems with electricity and clean water, these centers, schools and community facilities never make it to reality. We didn’t want this to be us. In addition to this, diseases like malaria, typhoid and hepatitis are rampant in these communities. We knew this could be an opportunity for maternal health but also an opportunity to teach and provide preventative health care solutions for adults and children in the community.

Who are we as Thaakat Foundation, Columbus

We are a group of five students at The Ohio State University, namely Sabeen, Aminah, Wedad, Abshaar, and Moiz, who decided to dedicate themselves to a cause bigger than ourselves. We came together as a team early this past summer, and fell in love Thaakat Foundation's mission. As a campus chapter, we aim to both fundraise for Thaakat's international projects as well as promote local service while simultaneously bridging cultural and religious gaps among the student community. We strive to embody meaning of "thaakat" and spread those values to the greater campus community as well as to our greater global community. 

Where exactly will the funds go? 

The funding will go directly to two different places:

Firstly 50% of the profits from this campaign will go directly to one of the international projects mentioned above, depending on which is in most need at the time of the end of the campaign. That money will contribute to buying varied supplies needed at each project site.

The other 50% will go towards our local service trips. These vary each month depending on what places around Columbus are in need of help and where our members want to go. The money allocated for this purpose will be used as reimbursement for gas, and for T-Shirts to represent our org during each service trip.

In the case that we fall short of our funding goal, we still plan to send half of what we raise internationally.

The Impact

We don't want this project to be one that we reminisce about a few years down the line as a "cool college experience."We want this to something that creates and stimulates actual, tangible change around the world. Why? Because, even if the world will never be perfect, isn't it worth it to work toward a better one?

Peace, 

Sabeen, Aminah, Wedad, Abshaar, and Moiz
story_txt:
What does Thaakat mean
Thaakat: (urdu: thaa-qut) - noun
1. the quality or state of being strong
2. something or someone that gives strength
3. a source of moral and mental power or encouragementWhat does Thaakat Foundation do? No matter how simple the effort or how large the cause, we believe in restoring hope and advancing minds. We promote charitable giving and humanitarian work among the youth by selflessly supporting the act of giving back.Thaakat Foundation was started by a group of students in the summer of 2007. With Facebook being our initial platform, Thaakat Foundation has grown rapidly, and in 2008 it became a 501(c)(3) government recognized not for profit organization.  Constant appreciation from our supporters and NGO partnerships continue to fuel our initiative towards social responsibility.Current ProjectsRighteous' Konadu Basic SchoolThaakat has adopted the small community of Tanobaose in south western Ghana to help provide education to children in need. story:
Hello indiegogo'ers,


I'm Kevin. I am 16 and I live in the Netherlands.
I have known Felicia, who lives in Indonesia, for over 2 years. Her dream is to study in Europe (Germany to be precise) because the education in Europe is far superior than in Indonesia. She would love to work towards a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in Economics. Then it's our ambition to start our own charity or to work for charities associated with education for disadvantaged children. 

Also included in this project is some proof of Felicia's identify.
(Check our updates)

What do we need?

We are trying to raise €700 (minus 4% Indiegogo fee that will be a total of €672).
This will cover the costs for Felicia's visa and her plane ticket to Europe.
She hopes to work and support herself while studying in Europe.

How can you help?

You can back this project with any amount - no matter how small it is. We will update this regularly with what we are doing to raise money ourselves and to show you that we are determined to work towards our goals. 

We would love to hear any suggestions you may have, even you are unable to offer financial support. 

You can also help by sharing this campaign with people you know.

What you can get?

We will send you regular updates on each milestones, for example, how much we raised, when Felicia arrives in Europe, and when she enrolls in a university. 

Thank you for reading this and any help would be much appreciated! Together we can change her life.

story:
Hello!

We are three High Schoolers attending Austin High that have teamed up with the Amala Foundation in our city Austin Texas. It is our last year in High School and we have been reflecting on our school experiences in general and we came to a conclusion; we were all thankful for our education. With that in mind we stumbled on to one of the Amala Foundation's pages and saw six children in need of financial help in order to go to school and stay off the streets.  We immediately started planning and we need your help to do this. This year we are wanting to provide ALL six children the "Gift of Education" this holiday season, please help us make our dream possible!

This is what $16.25 per month/$195 per year can do for a child at Bhatti Mines:

  • A year of education at the Bhatti Mines School
  • Exposure to international volunteers and cultural exchange programs 
  • A safe environment that promotes acceptance, self esteem, and an experience of dignity Year-long connection and support from students, donors and volunteers in the United States. 
  • See more at: http://www.amalafoundation.org/projects/bhatti-mines-school/#sthash.2SWQb9PE.dpuf

What we Need: $1500

100% of the funding will go directly towards the tuition of children.

What you get in return everyone who contributes WILL be posted on our website as a contributor.

$5- Thank you for supporting us! your contribution will benefit us!

$20- you get two post cards of pictures taken in India mailed to you. (US only)

$50- You get two post cards of pictures taken in India and a print mailed to you. (US only)

$100- you will get a hand written thank you note and a print and two cards mailed to you. (US only)


Other Ways You Can Help

Visit the Amala Foundation website to see other ways you can help!

http://www.amalafoundation.org

story:
Short Summary

Hello everybody, my name is Jonah Gercke and I am a 15 year old student at Pacific Ridge High School. Through my school I have been afforded the opportunity to travel to China with the rest of my grade. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Of course, in order to be able to make this film we need to be able to pay for a few necessary items:

1) $4000: The actual trip - As funny as this may sound, a two and a half week trip to China isn't free. Luckily, my school is paying for most of my travel expenses, but we still need money to be able to get there. The school is charging $1700 for the flight to and from China, and without this expense paid I will be unable to even make this film. 

2) $500: The Perks - It costs money to deliver your perks to you, and we want them to be fun! Those perks are listed here:

      A) $10: A personalized thank you note from me.

      B) $50: A signed still from the film in addition to all perks listed above.

      C) $100: Your name written in Mandarin characters in addition to all previous perks.

      D) $500: Dinner with Jonah and all previous perks.

      G) $1000: An exclusive short movie from the assorted clips recorded from friends on the trip, in addition to all previous perks.

The Impact

The impact of this campaign will be huge within the scope of my life. Your donation will be incredibly appreciated by Jonah and his entire family, no matter how large or small.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, I completely understand. There are many other ways in which you can help though: spreading the word is one of the most important things you can do. Whether you simply tell your friends what the campaign is and why they should support it, or you tell your Facebook friends about it, everything you do makes a difference. One donation could make the difference between making China Ridge and not going to China at all. Please tell anyone you know that would be interested in seeing this story come to life how to donate. Also,use the Indiegogo share options that accompany this campaign to spread the word to your friends - the more the merrier!

story:
Continue Your Support to Protect Children From Sex Trafficking!

Although the Indiegogo campaign has ended, our work is only beginning and we are continuing to fundraise.  If you want to help Dr. Titchen, you can still donate by mailing a check to:

AMWA, 12100 Sunset Hills Road, Suite 130, Reston, VA 20190.  

Please write on the memo of the check:  Human Trafficking

You can also donate online via AMWA's donation page:

http://www.amwa-doc.org/donate/human-trafficking-initiative/

Read about Dr. Titchen's vision below:

I'm Dr. Kanani Titchen, resident pediatrician at Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, and A.I. duPont Hospital for Children in Wilmington Delaware, and Resident Division President of the American Medical Women's Association (AMWA).  

I need your help to build a tool that will train doctors to identify and help victims of sex trafficking.

Back when I was still in medical school, I treated a young woman and noticed she had a tattoo that might have indicated her body was for sale.  My colleagues and I raised our eyebrows but said nothing and went about our work.

But I couldn't get the image out of my head. I began to wonder about her story and if I had missed an opportunity to help her.

I began to do some research into sex trafficking and healthcare and what I learned shocked me:

  • HALF of all new HIV cases are among 13-24 year olds
  • Children as young as 7 years old are being trafficked
  • Child sex trafficking is occurring in all 50 U.S. states

We need your tax-deductible donation to help these children -- please donate now. 

Help Me Train Doctors 

Although physicians are in a unique position to identify and intervene for these victims, we are missing them, because we’re not looking for them.  

I conducted a survey of more than 1000 physicians and medical students:

When we consider these victims often live in a state of fear inflicted by their captors, they are more likely to hide the very clues that could help them to safety when seeing a doctor.

This is What I'm Going To Do

AMWA will create an online resource to teach doctors the hidden signs and proper resources that can help these children to safety.

This program will have:

  • A compelling educational video that reinforces all key learning points
  • Downloadable presentation materials
  • Class scheduling component for doctors to invite others to training sessions
  • Map to show the number and location of classes taught and sharing statistics

We need funds to:

  • Build and design the website and social media interactions
  • Rent equipment and vehicles to film leading physicians and traffic survivors
  • Purchase media space to begin promoting the tool at launch

Your Donation is Tax Deductible

This project is a program of the American Medical Women's Association (AMWA). AMWA is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization so your donation is tax deductible. For nearly a century, AMWA has been committed to women's health and the advancement of women in medicine. AMWA understands that sex trafficking is a critical issue for public health, and gender equality. All proceeds from this campaign will go into a special account dedicated to the production of this project.  

This Is An Enduring Campaign

When you help this tool and its associated curriculum to be brought out into medical colleges and the professional community, you're making something that's going to stay up for a long time. AMWA will remain committed to the message and the issue and will use the social features of the site to continually spread the message and better prepare doctors to intervene on behalf of these children.

Our Team is Experienced and Dedicated:

Kanani Titchen, MD, is the 2013 winner of the APPD MidAtlantic Resident Research Award for her research into child sex trafficking and healthcare, is 2013-2014 National Residency Division President for AMWA, and remains a dedicated pediatric resident in Philadelphia, PA and Wilmington, DE.  

Dr. Eliza Lo Chin, MD, MPH, is Executive Director and Past President of the American Medical Women's Association and editor of This Side of Doctoring:  Reflections from Women in Medicine.

Dr. Douglas Howard Chin, MD, FACS, is a practicing surgeon and activist dedicated to advancing public health and gender equality. He has long had an interest in helping victims of international human trafficking and has worked with organizations around the world.

Stuart Culpepper is a creative director and producer of digital, broadcast, and social media.  He is a Webby Award winner and produced the campaign for the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption that won Twitter's Golden Tweet, the award for most re-tweeted message of 2011.

Help By Sharing This Campaign

Even if you're not in a position to donate, please use the sharing tools on this site to link this page to your Facebook, Twitter, Google+ or YouTube streams.

Notice: this campaign is the creation of Dr. Kanani Titchen and the American Medical Women's Association and is not associated with either Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia or A.I. duPont Hospital for Children in Wilmington Delaware.

story:
Little Jackets Academic Camp

My mission is to see this community succeed and rise to the next level in quality and foundational integrity. We also intend on providing a jumpstart for children Pre K-3 while simultaneously providing a clean and safe neighborhood  environment for all of our families.

We are teaming up with our local school district to enhance education needs for children that need that extra little bump. As many as 70 children will be enrolled in our summer programming. Children will be attending a 8 week summer camp that will provide them with breakfast and lunch and teach them skills to start of their successful educational path. This will also enable our community center to continue tutoring throughout the school year.

 The Community Center and Perrysburg Schools will provide all of Perrysburg's qualified children the opportunity to participate in this summer camp. We will provide certified teachers to provide a proper education for these students.

The Perrysburg Heights

Many of the children that will participate in the Little Jackets Academic Camp are from the Perrysburg Heights. In addition to the summer camp, the PHCA will take on several neighborhood projects.

The Perrysburg Heights Community Association was created with the intent to improve the Heights neighborhood and surrounding area. Over the last 23 years we have successfully improved the area but our goal is bigger, we want to take the next step forward.

During this project we want to hire neighborhood residents over the summer to help cleanup and help with the project. We will be roofing, landscaping, providing heating care, plumbing care, electrical care, general maintenance and demolishing a few structures.

We feel that by providing this care we will create a neighborhood and city pride that will help to  unify the area with the feeling of community.

story:
DIGITAL CLASSROOM DREAM

My name is Alexandra Soares-Salivia and I am a full-time English/ESOL teacher at Druid Hills High School in Atlanta, GA. I have taught for 10 years and wouldn't choose another career in the world! However, as any other teacher can tell you, I struggle with finding enough resources to teach my students due to limited funding issues in local public schools. With the more recent push to use technology in the classrooms, it is crucial to have access to tools that before were not needed. I love to use technology in my daily lesson plans, but it is impossible to keep up with it without the necessary tools. I want my students to experience and test ideas in the most technologically advanced possible learning environment, create projects and collaborate with each other using online tools, have limitless sources of information, access digital libraries, and even communicate with students across borders and oceans.  I can only imagine what they could do!

The purpose of this campaign is to raise $9,000 to purchase a set of 24 iPads that will be used with ESOL students (speakers of English as a second language) in a variety of instructional activities. The majority of these students are political refugees that were sometimes born in refugee camps and had very limited access to education. Their skills are lacking in so many ways and they face so many challenges. These obstacles stem from the lack of dictionaries, books and computers at home, inexistent basic computer skills, as well as the lack of experience accessing information online (job search, educational research, college applications, scholarships, general world education). Using iPads in daily instruction would remove these obstacles and create an everlasting impact in the lives of so many children.

Please, support this project and donate. If you cannot donate, share this information with all those who can possibly help us reach our goal.

My students and I would be forever grateful!
story_txt: DIGITAL CLASSROOM DREAMMy name is Alexandra Soares-Salivia and I am a full-time English/ESOL teacher at Druid Hills High School in Atlanta, GA. I have taught for 10 years and wouldn't choose another career in the world! However, as any other teacher can tell you, I struggle with finding enough resources to teach my students due to limited funding issues in local public schools. With the more recent push to use technology in the classrooms, it is crucial to have access to tools that before were not needed. I love to use technology in my daily lesson plans, but it is impossible to keep up with it without the necessary tools. I want my students to experience and test ideas in the most technologically advanced possible learning environment, create projects and collaborate with each other using online tools, have limitless sources of information, access digital libraries, and even communicate with students across borders and oceans.  I can only imagine what they could do!The purpose of this campaign is to raise $9,000 to purchase a set of 24 iPads that will be used with ESOL students (speakers of English as a second language) in a variety of instructional activities. The majority of these students are political refugees that were sometimes born in refugee camps and had very limited access to education. Their skills are lacking in so many ways and they face so many challenges. These obstacles stem from the lack of dictionaries, books and computers at home, inexistent basic computer skills, as well as the lack of experience accessing information online (job search, educational research, college applications, scholarships, general world education). Using iPads in daily instruction would remove these obstacles and create an everlasting impact in the lives of so many children.Please, support this project and donate. If you cannot donate, share this information with all those who can possibly help us reach our goal.My students and I would be forever grateful!

story:
Just a few more days!

We are down to our last few days of our Indiegogo campaign and we have some exciting news!  We have received a quote for a first run of 500 copies our training manual.  All we need is $3,000 and the manual goes to print!

Help us reach that goal by donating.  HUGE thanks to those of you that have already made a donation!


About 6 years ago...

...a horribly abused little boy came into the County of San Diego District Attorney's office. Because of his distrust of people he wouldn't speak. Describing his abuse was too difficult for him to relive, but the case against his abuser weighed heavily on his testimony. Finally, he told his story - to a golden retriever named Dory.    

                                      

Victim/Witness Support Program

With that interaction, the Victim/Witness Support Program began.

Of the thousands of reported cases of child abuse in San Diego County, the District Attorney’s office reports that 60% of these children are abused by someone they know. People they have to face in court.

With your contribution you will give a child confidence when walking into the courtroom with a dog and they can walk out knowing justice has prevailed.  

With your help we will be able to help more children

Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies is writing training materials to train more Victim/Witness Support Teams (a handler with a dog).  The dogs are trained by our friends at Paws'itive Teams (www.pawsteams.org) but the Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies is writing training materials for the people!  Here's why:

  • Currently, there are no formal written materials for the "Teams."  More formalized training means more successful involvement!
  • Requests for dogs during testimony is increasing...so we need more trained volunteer Teams to help out the kids that need the dogs the most.
  • With this $8,000 investment, envision the lives that can be impacted.  This means that we can expand our efforts with the Victim/Witness Support Program by training more volunteers and providing assistance to at least 200 children.
  • Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies will publish the written materials and make them available for a national audience.
  • With this funding, we can replicate this training in cities throughout the United States and we will help more kids!

                           

                            


Along with your donation there are other ways you can help

This is your call to action!

  • Be loud about our campaign.  Share this information so that as many people come across our donation page as possible. Help us get the word out!
  • Be frequent about this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, whatever your favorite social media outlet is!  Post this several times, over several days or weeks, to increase the number of people who will see your support.
  • Be creative...what can you do to help us? Do you have a great idea? Let us know! You may not feel like it's enough, but we appreciate every dollar. Trust us...they all add up. 
Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies appreciates every dollar.  Your contribution will make a difference.


Please share this with everyone you know and thank you so much!

                                     

As a 501(c)(3) nonprofit your contribution to the Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies and the Victim/Witness Support Program is tax deductible.

story:
The teachers at Henry Ford have created an after school tutoring program, but need your help to get our students home!  A majority of students take the school bus home from school and that is their only form of transportation.  This means that most students cannot stay after school for tutoring because they will not have a way home.

We are raising money to buy bus tickets for those students, so that they may stay after school for tutoring.  Any amount you can give will help!  Bus tickets are about $2.00 for a student to get all the way home, so even donating $20.00 allows us to give 10 students bus tickets to stay for tutoring.  

We have so many students that want to stay for extra help, but can't.  Please help our students in Detroit get extra time at school!  The more money we raise, the more students and the more times those students can stay after school.  

Thank you so much!

story:
Chum Reap Suor (Hello!)

My name is Alina Nuth, and I am part of a group called Chicago Khmer for Change. We are a group based in Chicago, IL that is committed to strengthening a network of young leaders who are actively involved in the Cambodian community.

This past November, I had the privilege of meeting a young Khmer Buddhist monk by the name of Prenz Sa-Ngoun at the 2014 Khmer Student Conference in Stockton, CA. It was a chance encounter, and we were able to quickly identify our combined motivation for intergenerational unity and understanding within our respective communities in Seattle and Chicago.

 There is no doubt that history leaves behind a lasting legacy. The Cambodian Diaspora is the result of a difficult past. But just like a lotus born out of the mud, we are finding ways to heal. To commemorate the continued journey beyond survival of the Cambodian Killing Fields, the Cambodian Association of Illinois is planning a Day of Remembrance: 40 Years, Moving Forward. This event is planned for April 18th, 2015.

Please join us in our healing efforts by donating to this campaign:

We want to bring Prenz to Chicago for the Day of Remembrance on April 18th to help bridge and facilitate an intergenerational dialogue within the Khmer American community in Chicago as well as help him understand his role in preserving and securing the Khmer Buddhist culture within future generations. 

--

The details are as follows:

Projected dates for his visit to Chicago are planned for April17th-April 22nd.

The cost for round trip air fare from Seattle to Chicago is currently estimated at $340. The cost for food expenses for 6 days is estimated at $100. Furthermore, a donation of $100 will be made to the temples in Chicago that are able to host him, and another $100 will go towards providing supplies and food for the youth during workshops.

The total amount we are aiming to raise is $640.00

--

While Prenz is visiting Chicago, he will be speaking at and attending the Cambodian Association of Illinois event, Bang Skoll, which is a traditional ceremony to honor our ancestors. He will be attending services at the temples in Uptown, Chicago that is open to the community. And lastly, he will be connecting with the older and younger generations in Chicago through workshops and activities planned by the Khmer Support Giving Circle and Chicago Khmer for Change.

--

Please help us out by donating what you can to our campaign that will undoubtedly strengthen the connections between the Khmer Diaspora. You can also share this link with your networks on social media as well as click on the following links to like our page and keep up with our future endeavors. 

Chicago Khmer For Change:  https://www.facebook.com/ChicagoKhmerForChange

Khmer Support Giving Circle: https://www.facebook.com/KhmerSupportGivingCircleChicago

--

Thank you for your support!

-Alina Nuth

-Prenz Sa-Ngoun

story:
What Exactly Is This Campaign For?

Let me clear some things up by giving you a short summary.

My name is Walter Gainer II and in May 2015, I will spend a month in China through Bluefield College's study abroad program. It has been my desire to learn mandarin and what better way than to immerse myself in the culture. While there, I will learn firsthand the relationship between China and our country and officially begin the next phase of my academic career in international business and law. 

I See... So How Are You Raising Funds For The Trip?

Well, from now until February 10th, I am initiating several efforts so that I may raise $4000.00 for the program. The cost includes:

  • International airfare.
  • Placement with a screened host family and school.
  • Passport and visa assistance.
  • Program service fee.
  • 24-hour support services both in the U.S. and abroad. 

Oh, Okay. That's Pretty Cool! Are You Nervous?

To say "Not at all" wouldn't be true. I can say that I am CONFIDENT that I will reach my goal. 

The thought of me coming back from China with a new perspective of myself and the world is enough motivation to get past any obstacles.

I have a well planned campaign that involves educating all who will listen and fun activities for all who will participate.

So Besides Donating, How Else Can I Help?

The best way to help me with my campaign, along with donations, is to keep talking about it.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Help me spread the word and make some noise about this campaign. You don't have to be a pro to do this. You can:

  • Use Indiegogo share tools.
  • Post a link to your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, really any social media account you have.
  • Email a link to some people you keep in contact with.

And that's all there is to it.

Unconditional donations from individuals and businesses are also welcome! 

I am counting on you for your support!

Sincerely,

Walter N. Gainer II

story:
Short Summary

hi, I'm gilbert, Italian and yaniris, Republican, for years has been my partner is born in us the idea of ​​making this our dream to help children in need Dominicans, after numerous trips to our r.domenicana and saw with my own eyes situations in which vivovo and how they are exploited in some poor areas of the country, I bought a plot with a house to fix in order to give them a better comfort, but my resources are running out so I ask for a contribution to all of you

Problems related to poverty and social deprivation, in an industrial city with many orphaned and abandoned children, are the reasons that led me and my partner yaniris to protect and assist orphaned and abandoned children. To prevent children from being abandoned or exploited by their families in difficulty need not only mine but also your help

ife sometimes puts us to hardships, I have always risked so much to me but now I feel in my heart that I have to do and risk anything for them, I read it in their eyes, so sweet carefree 

On 12 January 2010, a terrible earthquake destroyed Haiti and the situation of Haitian children and their families, has become, if anything, even more dramatic. 

I've seen these things with my own eyes and I was very impressed, giving me the motivation that I feel strong inside me



What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution will be used to complete the work of the existing structure on the ground to try to make it more appealing to the kids who are home, training rooms, a kitchen. a lounge to eat and two classrooms for education, create a field outside outside games. 

The Impact

I have committed nearly everything in this dream and our resources are running out I wonder why your contribution because if I do not finish the work begun I feel helpless in front of these innocent people who do not ask for much but just to live a peaceful life without danger without fear or try to hide in the shadows in their few years of life. 

I hope to finish with a great desire to make this journey with the vosto help and I thank you all in advance


Risks & Challenges

in case you can not work with a contribution to help us to let us know by using the sharing tools Indiegogo!

story:
We are the Igbo Awareness Development Initiative, a charity NGO registered in Nigeria. We are made up of Nigerians who reside within and outside Nigeria. Our objective is to empower the young people in the South East region by training them on specific vocational skills, building skill sets and harnessing the opportunities and drive that exists within these young persons

LEARN A TRADE, REDUCE POVERTY AND HUNGER. The Millennium Development Goals are 8 international goals that were established following the millennium summit of the United Nations in 2000, as well as the adoption of the United Nation Millennium Declaration. While the MDGs are for all of mankind, they are primarily focused on children and the youth, as children and young people are the most vulnerable when life’s essentials are unavailable. They are always the first victim, physically, psychologically or socially. Prominent of these goals is the first goal which is to ‘eradicate extreme poverty and hunger’, a goal committed to by 23 international organisation and 189 countries of which Nigeria is a signatory. The 2013 Millennium Development Goal Reports (MDGRs), which is a performance appraisal of states’ journey to achieving the set MDGs, is mixed. For Nigeria, progress towards achieving ‘Goal 1’in the MDG has been below average and hence less satisfactory. Over 70% of the populace (8 out of every 10 Nigerians) still live in abject poverty and there is still a widening gap between the rich and the poor. For clarity, the first goal in the UN MDG, eradicating extreme poverty and hunger, is subdivided into three targets. Target A, ensures that between 1990-2015, the proportion of people living on less than $1.25 a day is halved; Target B, ensures that a decent employment for women, men and young people is achieved; Target C, ensures that between 1990-2015, the proportion of people who suffers from hunger is halved. This is where our campaign comes into.

PLEASE JOIN OUR CAMPAIGN!!! I invite you to join our in achieving the eradication of extreme poverty and hunger in Nigeria, and thereby meeting a key component of the UN MDG. We believe that this can be achieved and better monitored if focus is made on each region in Nigeria and each region is compared against the other regions in Nigeria. We would focus on the South East region of Nigeria. The rationale for choice is hinged on our proximity to the region and our deep understanding of the region; currently it is a region besotted with the unfavorable clime of gully erosion and gully farmlands. There is a high poverty rate in this region, hence social vile such as kidnapping, baby-factories, armed robbery, mostly as a result of high unemployment rate amongst youths, is rife in this region. With the growing incidence of HIV/AIDS and a high child mortality rate, this region needs all the help it can get. This project, it is hoped, will be replicated across other regions in Nigeria.

The South East of Nigeria, currently consists of 5 states; our aim is to reach 500 motivated young girls, that is 100 per state, establishing skill acquisition centres for these young girls during a set period of time. At the end of the programme they would be fully trained in skills where their main strengths are harnessed and should then become entrepreneurs and business owners in their own rights. The project would be monitored to the last detail to ensure that the objective is met and the trained are able to give back to the society.


Working with at-risk girls poses challenges to both the participants' safety and their ability to continue their training. In order to keep the program participants safe and the families connected with the program itself, the campaign leaders meet regularly with the girls’ family members. In doing so, we aim to create a trusted network in which parents become more invested in their daughters’ education, and can feel that they are taking a proactive role in supporting their futures.


We understand that sometimes you can’t afford to make a financial contribution. However, there are many other ways to support the Learn a trade campaign! There are various ways in which you can participate in this campaign; . • Committing to enlist as a volunteer trainer. We will greatly appreciate donated skills such as fashion design,hair dressing,interior decoration,catering, IT,web design,graphic design and much more• Raising awareness in your own charity, neighborhood and the public around the world about this cause.

You might consider sharing the campaign page on your Facebook or Twitter, or even by joining our social media team!

 

 Please email us at  

Iamlat14@yahoo.com

If you would like to donate but are unable to do so online, or if you’d like to join our team!
