The Alternative Education Resource Organization (AERO) was founded in 1989 by Jerry Mintz. AERO's goal is to advance student-driven, learner-centered approaches to education. AERO is the primary hub of communications and support for educational alternatives around the world. Our network includes Montessori, Waldorf (Steiner), Public Choice and At-Risk, Democratic, Homeschool, Open, Charter, Free, Sudbury, Holistic, Virtual, Magnet, Early Childhood, Reggio Emilia, Indigo, Krishnamurti, Quaker, Libertarian, Independent, Progressive, Community, Cooperative, and Unschooling.AERO's mission is to help create an education revolution to make learner-centered education available to everyone.One of AERO's areas of expertise is democratic process and democratic education, but equally important is the networking of all forms of educational alternatives. Towards this end, AERO provides information, resources and guidance to families, schools and organizations regarding their educational choices. AERO disseminates information internationally on topics such as: homeschooling, public and private alternative schools, and charter schools.
Sir Ken Robinson supports learner-centered education for everyone, will you?
All perks will be made available shortly after the campaign. If you have questions prior to then, please feel free to contact Jerry Mintz at jerryaero@aol.com. 

Ebook Options (Level 1+): One Size Does Not Fit All: A Student's Assessment of School by Nikhil Goyal; Turning Points: 35 Visionaries in Education Tell Their Own Stories; and Flood of Conflict: The New Orleans Free School Story by Robert Ferris.


Individual AERO Membership (Level 2+): View the full list of member benefits here.


Twitter Shout Out (Level 2+): We will ask you for your Twitter handle after the campaign concludes. Follow us on Twitter here.


Any Book (Level 3+): You will be able to pick any book from our store here. We will ask you to provide your first and second choices just in case we are out of stock.


Facebook Message (Level 3+): We will thank you by name on our Facebook page. However, you also have the option to send a short (200 characters or less) message out to our 9,000+ followers. This is a great opportunity to get a plug in for your school, organization, or project. The message needs to be aligned with our mission and tasteful (we'll be the judge, but think professional/no language/controversial content).


Institutional AERO Membership (Level 4+): View the full list of institutional member benefits here.


Complete Catalog of AERO's Print Education Titles (Level 4+): Democratic Education: A Beginning of a Story by Yaacov Hecht; Education: Back to the Future by Len Solo; No Homework and Recess All Day: How to Have Freedom and Democracy in Education by Jerry Mintz; The Outside In Book: A Book About Tolerance by Lisa Mintz Harris; The Self-Organizing Revolution: Common Principles of the Educational Alternatives Movement by Ron Miller; and Turning Points: 35 Visionaries in Education Tell Their Own Stories. View descriptions and find out more here.


Free One-Hour Consultation (Level 4+): We will contact you to arrange your consultation. For more information, click here.


Complete Archive (Level 5+): This is the complete collection of Education Revolution magazines from 1989-2011. A rare an important collection for anyone interested in educational alternatives.


Publish on EducationRevolution.org + Newsletter (Level 5+): Have an event to promote or an article/blog post you're passionate about? This is an ideal opportunity to have it viewed by thousands. Our newsletter reaches over 13,000 weekly and our site is viewed more by 50,000 monthly. The post must align with our mission and be tasteful, so nothing about how standardized testing is the greatest assessment method ever invented (we'll be the judge, but think professional/no language/controversial content). You can submit your post at any time after donation. We suggest 500-1,000 max for effectiveness on our website, but we're happy to work with you. The newsletter post will be a snippet/call out directing to either our site or your own.


Complimentary Registration to AERO Conference (Level 6+): Sugata Mitra will be the featured keynote speaker and we'll have another outstanding program for our 12th annual conference in 2015. More detail can be found here here. Complimentary registration does not include food or lodging.


Free Ad on EducationRevolution.org for 2015 (Level 6+): 600,000 annual unique visitors. Your ad will be featured on every major page of the website. Great for anyone with an organization, event, product, or idea. The ad must align with our mission and be tasteful (we'll be the judge, but think professional/no language/controversial content). You can review the specs and details here. The ad can be posted immediately following your donation.

Questions about any of this? Ask jerryaero@aol.com

story:
Hi You!

My name is Jennifer Smith.

I work with a special program at my campus called Puente, which is a program designed to help underrepresented and often disadvantaged Latino students successfully transfer from a Community College to a 4 year university and then graduate from that university. 

Long story short (ish) -  My co-director and I made a commitment to award all Puente students transferring to a 4 year university a foundation scholarship. 
Because we are good at our jobs, we are increasing the number of transfers to UCs each year, and the scholarship fund  stretches only so far. And so instead of giving 20 students each $100 dollars, I am trying to fund raise on the side to see if I can get that number up just a little bit to about $200 a student, which means I'm trying to raise about $4000. 

The request - whatever you can give, whether that's five dollars or fifty. 

So Please Please Please donate.  

If you are suspicious of online requests for funding, you can always send money directly to the school. If you do that instead of this Indiegogo, it is tax deductible. Total bargain.  Just make the checks out to LAVC Foundation - Puente.  And mail directly to the college Los Angeles Valley College at 5800 Fulton Ave, Valley Glen, CA 91401.  Please indicate clearly that the money is for Puente - otherwise it will go to some other deserving kid, but one I don't know. 

You can also just hand me money the next time you see me, and I will assume that it's for Puente, not for anything licentious. 

I sincerely thank you for considering this request, and I promise that this program really does make a difference, and these scholarships, as little as they are, make a difference too. They pay for gas up to the college, or airfare, books, food, breathing room...

Yay! Thanks! Yay!

Jennifer

P.S. Humble brag: Valley College has been commended at the state Puente Office for our transfer rates compared to other colleges. Oh yeah. And our rates keep going up. Oh, and the Puente program does more with less money than all the other Equal Opportunity programs in the state. Burn other Programs. 


One more P.S. 

I know you may have given to other programs recently, or you may be strapped for cash but loaded with good intentions, or you may have other stuff going on, so if that is the case, consider donating just a dollar. A dollar will do, and even if it don't, I don't love you any less.

story:
Short Summary

I am Samson Abukari a citizen of Ghana in West Africa and the CEO of Watch What You Eat Foundation. I have been involved in community development work for the past 10 years. Helping to put a smile on the face of a disadvantaged person always gives me joy. This I do sometimes with the collective efforts of other like-minded persons.

Consolidating sustainability is a continuation of a project that was initiated by Watch What You Eat Foundation as a means by which dependence on donor funding will be reduced or eliminated. This we try to do by cultivating a total of about 10 hectares of maize and rice which when harvested is sold and used for the operations of Watch What You Eat Foundation.

With your support we will be able to have funds to roll out educative training programs to help over 100 rural farmers to acquire basic principles of management so as to enable them to manage their harvest to meet their family needs and improve their lives. Your contribution will also assist us to engage the services of experts to research and find solutions to basic crop failure and the effects of climate change on crop and vegetable production. 


What We Need & What You Get

A total of $2,000 is needed for the implementation of this Consolidating Sustainability campaign. This is to assist us to pay for the services of hiring tractor services, purchase quality seeds and the purchase of fertilizers for application on the cultivated crops. 

Perks that are available to contributors include thank you emails, a Ghanaian branded thank you card, and personal handwritten appreciation letter. 

Should it happen that we are unable to reach the funding goal we will still go ahead to use what has been raised to implement the project to whatever the level it can.

The Impact

Through this project you will touch and transform many lives not just for this year but spanning several years of the operations of Watch What You Eat Foundation. The sustainability component of the organization aims at cultivating crops every year with the aim of reinvesting the yield into the operations of the organization in the area of training rural farmers, training of youth and rural women and the provision of tractor services and storage facilities for rural farmers. 

The CEO who is a World Hunger Relief Inc, (Waco Texas) trained together with the other staff are very passionate in assisting the vulnerable and disadvantaged in the society and will want to build on the achievements of harvesting over 2500kg of maize last year.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the likely obstacles against this project include access to land, single rain fed crop season, care and management. 

We have been generously offered over 10 hectares of land on which we will be doing the cropping. With regards to the rainfall pattern we are doing all our possible best to do our planting in the recommended window for farming in the area and our dedicated farm manager together with some volunteers and the staff will work seriously on the care and management of the crops.


Other Ways You Can Help

To all our wonderful friends and loved ones we urge you to give towards this worthy cause and you will be glad that you did. Do not hesitate to share this with your family, friends and loved ones but dop remember to use the indiegogo share tools when sharing.

story:
Thank you to everyone who has already donated.  Part 1 raised over USD$4500 (https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/12-000-for-...) so I've launched Part 2 as there is still nearly 10 months left of the year.

To recap, over the next 12 months I will complete 12 challenges to raise $12,000 for the following amazing charities:

1. Lifestart http://bit.ly/1JnIKgk

2. Chris O'Brien Life House http://bit.ly/1ORbtIX

3. MS Australia http://bit.ly/1QMmT4k

4. Variety Club - Link TBA

5. St Vincent de Paul http://bit.ly/1JCcrKC


You can specify which charity you want to support or donate to all at once.

I am planning to complete the following challenges:

1. March 29 - Kayak for kids (18km harbour kayaking)

2. April 11 - Sydney to Ettalong Loop (150km bike ride)

3. May 9 - River Ride (200km bike ride)

4. June 24 - Alpe D'Huez x 2 (60km bike ride climbing and descending the famous mountain in France)

5. July 8 - Guildford to Brighton and back (150km bike ride)

6. Sept 19 - Sydney to Sackville Ferry Loop (150km bike ride)

7. Oct 10-11 - Ride to Conquer Cancer (200km bike ride)

8. Nov 1 - Sydney to Wollongong and back (180km bike ride)

9. Nov 14 - Sydney to Hunter Valley (200km bike ride)

10. Jan 25 2016 - Audax Alpine Classic (200km, or 250km bike ride - if I meet the qualification criteria)

11. Jan 31 2016 - Palm Beach to Whale Beach - The Big Swim (2.8km ocean swim)

12. April 2 - April 16 2016 - The Variety Cycle - Sydney to the Great Barrier Reef (2100km bike ride)

story:
Our Story

Our computers are 20 years old and need to be replaced - our kids can no longer use these machines to do their homework.

The Impact

Computer skills are mandatory in this day in age; without proper computer skills, kids will be at a significant disadvantage - help us prepare them for high school and future employment!


What We Need & What You Get

We need to buy 20 computers for our school; with your help the kids will send you a personalized thank you card!

story:
As many of you know I was diagnosed with a brain tumor on February 10th. My surgery is March 5th. I have faith that I will be okay and able to go on my trip. But because of this as my campaign to raise funds moves forward, I have decided to shift gears and donate to another charity. I thank everyone that donated to Transition House.

For all future contributions made to my trip I will pay forward and donate to THE PEDIATRIC BRAIN TUMOR FOUNDATION. (http://www.pbtfus.org) PBTF is a nonprofit organization dedicated to eradicating childhood brain tumors and providing support to families. This is so important to me and I want to do everything I can to help kids like me.


 

I have been selected to travel as a Student Ambassador with the People to People Student Ambassador program in June 2012. We will travel to Italy, Sicily and Greece. The mission of this educational program, founded by President Dwight Eisenhower, is to create and promote peace across the globe. People to People is the world's most recognized and respected, life changing, educational travel provider, where the world is your classroom. I receive school credit for participating.

The trip is costly (program tuition includes all transportation, accommodations, meals, and educational activities.) and so I had the idea of fundraising for it and donating a portion of the funds to a charity of my choosing. For every donation I receive I will in turn â€œpay it forwardâ€ and donate to The Pediatric Brain Tumor Foundation.

By donating to this cause you are not only helping me to experience a life changing event but you are helping children and their families effected by a brain tumor.

Every donation big and small gets me closer to my goal. This donation is tax deductible. Please pass the word....we can do something great together! Post on your facebook or linked in. Thanks.

THANK YOU!

story:
Introduction and Background:


  • My name is Scott Forest Pulsipher. I work for a Park and Recreation Center with whom I bring my Kendo Club to one of their local After School Programs. I have been training with swords and other weapons since I was a young boy. I have read and am currently reading over many widely respected philosophy books which I also bring to the Kendo Club.

Why is this Campaign Important to Me:

  • The significance of this campaign goes beyond the 'Box' of comprehension. The Significance not only Fills the Empty Box full of worth and a wealth of personal understanding for each student, but it also is not limited to the 'Box' itself; and may later flow forth to become something even greater and more enriching than foreseen. Today I meditated and developed a saying, "The moment you understand your own present limitations, is the moment you can evaluate methods to evolve past them." I truly believe that Kendo has brought me to understand more about my Body, my Mind, and my own personal Limitations. I know that I can guide each student individually and the team as a whole to the same understanding. I just need a few things to aid me in making it a reality, not for me, but for these young adults. I want to be the last stepping stone for these students before they themselves get to make the decision to go on and further their education and understanding of the world. I want to give them the Power to Think as an individual and to work as a Team towards common goals. I want to enrich their lives with Confidence and High Moral. I want to infuse their minds to accept nothing Honor to come forth from their own individual actions; and to become leaders and examples of those actions. The reason why this Campaign is important,... is because it will help shape the future through personal growth and understanding of the new generation of young adults ready to join their fellow citizens in a respectful, mutually beneficial and symbiotic manner. As a Contributor, you will assist me in achieving this goal. ^_^

What We as a Team Need and What You as a Contributor Get:

  • Developing a Kendo Club at the High School level (Freshmen-Senior)

  • Purchasing Armor, Training Swords, Craft materials: Cloth (purchased in bolts of cloth, used for creating a Team Bannar [4 season banner], Tenugui - head/sweatbands), Time Capsules, Cubbyhole Container for gear, Reading and Reference materials related to Kendo and Philosophy.

---

09/22/2013

Scott Forest Pulsipher


Last week during the “Club Awareness Lunch Event” in the Quad, here at the High school, I recruited approximately 8-10 more students (Almost Doubling my attendance to a total list of 20-22) to the after school program/Kendo Club Sign-In-Sheet. I have put together the above shopping list which, if purchased, will allow me to begin implementing great things for the program. The students will begin training in Kendo without the need of sharing gear and no one will be left out to watch during training sessions. What I bring to this after school program through Kendo is the same premiss found in any other sport:


  • Physical Activity:

    • Standard Beginner Techniques

    • Observation Skills

    • Through working out, Greater Self Respect and Internal Gratification.

  • Group / Team Enrichment:

    • Technique Exchanges

    • Tournaments (Down the road in the year)

    • Talent Show

    • Arts and Crafts

      • Team Banner (which will Model as a Form of Earning “Badges”)

      • Armor Storage Cubby Holes on Wheels (Lockable)

      • Time Capsules

      • Customised Tenugui (Head/Sweatbands)

    • Group Discussions on Philosophy Books (ex: Bruce Lee)

I have seen many methods of “Storage” which will not only keep the items we potentially obtain, secure onsite; but will also render me not having to handle my own personal mother-load of gear to and fro’. (Of course I will still carry certain items unique to my own personal use day in and day out; but if half or more of the equipment is already on-site, the burden of preparation with loading and unloading equipment alone will be reduced, exponentially). Last year I purchased Five additional “Shinai” (Bamboo Practice swords) so that I could train students in the Way of Kendo (the Art of the Japanese Sword). At the start of this year, I began to assert and make plans for a Number of potential Arts and Craft Ideas which would bring the students together as a Team, inspiring them, bringing on a new level of respect for themselves, their peers, and their gear. Some of my Arts and Crafts Ideas are as follows:


  • Bogu Armor Cubby’s (Basically Lockable Lockers With Sign-In/Out-Sheets):

    • With Top Container for Shinai Practice Swords.

  • Tenugui Customization (Head/Sweatband):

    • Gaining Appreciate For Gear through Self Worth

      • Ex: “I Made This!” and so therefore I have a greater Appreciation for it.

    • Created with:

      • 100% Cotton (I have examples and Pictures of Exact Type of Cotton “Weave”).

      • Fabric Cloth Dyes/Inks (Assorted Colors).

      • Sewing Machine.

      • Iron / Ironing Board.

      • I myself have some cloth (already) that I can contribute. But may need more due to the influx of student awareness/involvement within ASSETs and the Kendo Club.

  • Shinai Bag’s (Customization Colors/Design Fabric):

    • Again, Gaining Appreciation for their Gear through making something for their own Armor/Practice Weapons.

      • Assorted Clothes to Choose from as the group.

      • Clothes will be cut and Sewn by Students.

  • Flags and Opponent “Markers / Indicators”:

    • Can be Crafted and Not Purchased.

      • I myself have some cloth (already) that I can contribute.

      • Will Need Wood Glue (Add to Shopping List)

  • Time Capsules:

    • Made of PVC Piping and Screw Caps

    • Japanese Dowel Style Scroll

      • Corked / Preserved in Bamboo, and placed inside Time Capsule.

    • Among Other Probable Things Added to the Capsules as the year progresses:

      • Matching “Team Friendship Bracelets”

      • Certificate of Participation Presented by me: Scott Forest Pulsipher / ASSETs Team

      • Etc...


Shopping List:

~Kendo Club~


  • “Starter Kit” From: https://www.eurokendo.co.uk/starter-kit.html($180.00 +shipping /per student)

    • All of the Basic Uniform articles highly suggested to have in order to participate in Kendo: (Unlikely to Find Cheaper Elsewhere due to this being a Set  vs Individual piece purchases)

    • ***Will Need Personal / Individual Measurements from All Students /per Kit.

    • ***Reason for Multiple Individual Purchases:

      • With this, no one student will be left out just watching because they don’t have gear

      • Cleanliness/Hygiene, non-shared, no cross contamination through bodily fluids, Sweat.

    • Comes With:

      • Kendo Gi and Hakama (Shirt and Pants)***Non-shared, Main Sweat Absorber

      • Shinai (Bamboo Training Sword) *** Must Be 39” long (which is “Regulation” Length)

      • Bokken (Sturdy Wooden Training Sword Used for NON-Contact “Kata” / Forms)

      • ***Bokken will only be used by students that Display Superior Control and Resolve.

      • Training Sword Bag (Should Hold Both the Shinai and Bokken)

      • Tenugui (Headband Worn Under the Helmet to serve as a Swear Guard for the Eyes and Face)***Non-shared, Main/Primary Sweat Absorber


  • Ready Made 6mm Bougu Armor Set, Found On: http://www.ninecirclesusa.com/Bougu_-_Kendo_Armour/Ready_Made_Bougu/Ready_Made_Bougu_Sets/Ready_Made_Bougu_Set_-_6mm_Machine_Stitched.aspx($265.00+shipping /per student)

    • All the Basic Armor pieces Required to Participate in Kendo: (This is the cheapest “Beginner” Set, aside from sets that are considered “Peewee” or Adolescent age group Armor Sets) ***Will Need Personal / Individual Measurements from All Students /per Bougu set, which Includes the following:

      • “Men” (Helmet / Facemask)***Non-shared, Main Sweat Absorber

      • “Do” (Chest Guard / Midriff Protection)

      • “Tare” (Waist / Groin Protector)

      • “Kote” (Forearm / Wrist & Hand Protection) ***Non-shared, Main Sweat Absorber

      • “Bogu Bag” and Armor Fittings / Cords


  • Water Bottle w/ Straw, From Sports Chalet Country Club Mall:

  • ($3.99 x 20 = $79.80)http://www.bestkendo.com/kendo-water-bottle.html

    • The functionality of this water bottle will allow students to quench their thirst w/o (without) removing/taking off their “Men” (Helmet).***Non-shared, Bodily Fluid: Saliva

    • Just Looked online at Sports Chalet, and these water bottles were not available (online). Though, I have purchased one recently at the Country Club Mall Location.


  • Reference and Philosophy Materials, Obtained from “Barns & Noble” / Amazon.com:

  • ($10.00-25.00 x 12 books = $120-300)All reference Materials will be Kept onsite for student use and will Not be checked to be taken Home.

    • I personally possess copies of all the literature that I plan to cover but I see a benefit to having the wealth of knowledge upon our Bookshelves within the program.

  • Kendo - The Definitive Guide,  Hiroshi Ozawa.

  • Bruce Lee’s, Striking Thoughts, Wisdom for Daily Living

  • Hagakure - The Book of the Samurai, Yamamoto Tsunetomo

  • Musashi’s Book of Five Rings, Stephen F. Kaufman, Hanshi 10th Dan.

  • Sun Tzu’s - Art of War

  • Yojokune, Life Lessons from a Samurai,  Kaibara Ekiken, Translated by William Scott Wilson.

  • Warrior Wisdom, Kasumi Tabata, By: Tuttle.

  • The Way of the Modern Warrior, Stephen F Kaufman (Tuttle)

  • Warrior of the Light - A Manual,  Paulo Coelho

  • The Life Giving Sword- William Scott Wilson

  • The Lone Samurai - the Life of Miyamoto Musashi, William Scott Wilson

  • Siddhartha, Herman Hesse (Great American Classic)

  • Journal/Ledger to Take Notes on the above material.


  • Cloth used in the following Arts and Craft Projects:

  • ($2.99-10.00 /per yard of cloth & /per student: TOTAL Cost Approx: $1150.00 / 20 Students)

    • Matching Team Tenugui - Head/Sweatband worn under the helmet armor piece.

      • I can obtain Three Tenugui per yard of cloth.

    • Matching Cloth Shinai Bag Carrier

      • Two yards in Length, minimum. Can make anywhere from 3-4 bags per 2 yard length.

    • Team Banner - Team / Club Pride Banner

      • Two Yards of Cloth

      • Would like to Create Four Banners throughout the year for each seasonal look/design.

    • Matching Team Obi (Belt)

      • Three Yards of Cloth per student


  • Cubbyhole Storage Container for Bogu and Shinai Training Swords:

  • (TOTAL Cost Approx: $227.38 + )

    • ($21.97 x One Box) 2” Coarse Drywall Screw 5 lbs.

    • ($3.68 x 20 = $73.60, before tax) 1.5” Corner Brace Galvanized 4 pack.

    • ($2.27 x 3 = $6.81, before tax) 1.5” Non-Remove Pin Hinge Zink 2 pack.

    • ($25.00 x 5 = $125.00, before tax) Wood Panels 4’ x 8’

    • TOTAL Cost Approx: $227.38 +
story_txt:
Introduction and Background:
My name is Scott Forest Pulsipher. I work for a Park and Recreation Center with whom I bring my Kendo Club to one of their local After School Programs. I have been training with swords and other weapons since I was a young boy. I have read and am currently reading over many widely respected philosophy books which I also bring to the Kendo Club.
Why is this Campaign Important to Me:
The significance of this campaign goes beyond the 'Box' of comprehension. The Significance not only Fills the Empty Box full of worth and a wealth of personal understanding for each student, but it also is not limited to the 'Box' itself; and may later flow forth to become something even greater and more enriching than foreseen. Today I meditated and developed a saying, "The moment you understand your own present limitations, is the moment you can evaluate methods to evolve past them." I truly believe that Kendo has brought me to understand more about my Body, my Mind, and my own personal Limitations. I know that I can guide each student individually and the team as a whole to the same understanding. I just need a few things to aid me in making it a reality, not for me, but for these young adults. I want to be the last stepping stone for these students before they themselves get to make the decision to go on and further their education and understanding of the world. I want to give them the Power to Think as an individual and to work as a Team towards common goals. I want to enrich their lives with Confidence and High Moral. I want to infuse their minds to accept nothing Honor to come forth from their own individual actions; and to become leaders and examples of those actions. The reason why this Campaign is important,... is because it will help shape the future through personal growth and understanding of the new generation of young adults ready to join their fellow citizens in a respectful, mutually beneficial and symbiotic manner. As a Contributor, you will assist me in achieving this goal. ^_^
What We as a Team Need and What You as a Contributor Get:

Developing a Kendo Club at the High School level (Freshmen-Senior)
Purchasing Armor, Training Swords, Craft materials: Cloth (purchased in bolts of cloth, used for creating a Team Bannar [4 season banner], Tenugui - head/sweatbands), Time Capsules, Cubbyhole Container for gear, Reading and Reference materials related to Kendo and Philosophy.

---
09/22/2013
Scott Forest Pulsipher
Last week during the “Club Awareness Lunch Event” in the Quad, here at the High school, I recruited approximately 8-10 more students (Almost Doubling my attendance to a total list of 20-22) to the after school program/Kendo Club Sign-In-Sheet. I have put together the above shopping list which, if purchased, will allow me to begin implementing great things for the program. The students will begin training in Kendo without the need of sharing gear and no one will be left out to watch during training sessions. What I bring to this after school program through Kendo is the same premiss found in any other sport:

Physical Activity:

Standard Beginner Techniques
Observation Skills
Through working out, Greater Self Respect and Internal Gratification.

Group / Team Enrichment:

Technique Exchanges
Tournaments (Down the road in the year)
Talent Show
Arts and Crafts

Team Banner (which will Model as a Form of Earning “Badges”)
Armor Storage Cubby Holes on Wheels (Lockable)
Time Capsules
Customised Tenugui (Head/Sweatbands)

Group Discussions on Philosophy Books (ex: Bruce Lee)


I have seen many methods of “Storage” which will not only keep the items we potentially obtain, secure onsite; but will also render me not having to handle my own personal mother-load of gear to and fro’. (Of course I will still carry certain items unique to my own personal use day in and day out; but if half or more of the equipment is already on-site, the burden of preparation with loading and unloading equipment alone will be reduced, exponentially). Last year I purchased Five additional “Shinai” (Bamboo Practice swords) so that I could train students in the Way of Kendo (the Art of the Japanese Sword). At the start of this year, I began to assert and make plans for a Number of potential Arts and Craft Ideas which would bring the students together as a Team, inspiring them, bringing on a new level of respect for themselves, their peers, and their gear. Some of my Arts and Crafts Ideas are as follows:

Bogu Armor Cubby’s (Basically Lockable Lockers With Sign-In/Out-Sheets):
With Top Container for Shinai Practice Swords.
Tenugui Customization (Head/Sweatband):

Gaining Appreciate For Gear through Self Worth
Ex: “I Made This!” and so therefore I have a greater Appreciation for it.
Created with:

100% Cotton (I have examples and Pictures of Exact Type of Cotton “Weave”).
Fabric Cloth Dyes/Inks (Assorted Colors).
Sewing Machine.
Iron / Ironing Board.
I myself have some cloth (already) that I can contribute. But may need more due to the influx of student awareness/involvement within ASSETs and the Kendo Club.


Shinai Bag’s (Customization Colors/Design Fabric):

Again, Gaining Appreciation for their Gear through making something for their own Armor/Practice Weapons.

Assorted Clothes to Choose from as the group.
Clothes will be cut and Sewn by Students.


Flags and Opponent “Markers / Indicators”:

Can be Crafted and Not Purchased.

I myself have some cloth (already) that I can contribute.
Will Need Wood Glue (Add to Shopping List)


Time Capsules:

Made of PVC Piping and Screw Caps
Japanese Dowel Style Scroll
Corked / Preserved in Bamboo, and placed inside Time Capsule.
Among Other Probable Things Added to the Capsules as the year progresses:

Matching “Team Friendship Bracelets”
Certificate of Participation Presented by me: Scott Forest Pulsipher / ASSETs Team
Etc...

~Kendo Club~

All of the Basic Uniform articles highly suggested to have in order to participate in Kendo: (Unlikely to Find Cheaper Elsewhere due to this being a Set  vs Individual piece purchases)
***Will Need Personal / Individual Measurements from All Students /per Kit.
***Reason for Multiple Individual Purchases:

With this, no one student will be left out just watching because they don’t have gear
Cleanliness/Hygiene, non-shared, no cross contamination through bodily fluids, Sweat.

Comes With:

Kendo Gi and Hakama (Shirt and Pants)***Non-shared, Main Sweat Absorber
Shinai (Bamboo Training Sword) *** Must Be 39” long (which is “Regulation” Length)
Bokken (Sturdy Wooden Training Sword Used for NON-Contact “Kata” / Forms)
***Bokken will only be used by students that Display Superior Control and Resolve.
Training Sword Bag (Should Hold Both the Shinai and Bokken)
Tenugui (Headband Worn Under the Helmet to serve as a Swear Guard for the Eyes and Face)***Non-shared, Main/Primary Sweat Absorber

“Do” (Chest Guard / Midriff Protection)

story:
Personal Testimonial Videos - Mike, Ricky, Ruth, Allison, Ryan, Chris

College Improv Tournament - A Summary

The College Improv Tournament is the largest improv tournament (and festival, really) in the world.  Last year, we had 126 teams and 13 regional tournaments, and the tournament as a whole took place over 6 months.

Now we are about to begin our biggest year ever, with as many as 150 teams nationwide (and some Canadian teams as well) competing in the regional tournaments.

Part 1: What CIT Already Provides

CIT gives not only gives students a goal to work toward during the school year, but it also provides students with the opportunity to make connections with each other as well as regional professionals and theatres.

CIT participants recieve feedback from professional improvisers acting as judges, as well as the on site producers who open themselves up to all types of questions (improv past college, Chicago, how to stick together and succeed, etc.).

Many students and groups who have competed in CIT Regionals have been invited back by the regional theatres to put on shows or even join the theatre's resident company!

Every match of the College Improv Tournament Season is webcast live and saved online.  This not only provides the ability for family and friends who cannot travel to see CIT teams compete, but also allows all CIT competitors nationwide the ability to see what other teams are doing.  All shows are also recorded on a backup camera in the case of a lost connection.  

At the National Level, CIT provides the top teams in the country to meet, perform, and gain industry contacts during their weekend in Chicago.  as many as 13 judges (live and watching the online webcast) tally in to decide the winners of each round.  This ensures that all schools of thought on improv are represented.  

At the National level of the tournament, all teams are at a professional level of performance.  The judges at the Nationals always speak about the quality of the groups and how they put on better shows than most groups in Chicago.  

CIT Nationals gives students the opportunity to be seen and make contacts with some of the best improviser professionals Chicago has to offer.

CIT is part of Chicago Improv Festival's Educational Outreach Program. The Chicago Improv Festival Productions' mission is to celebrate the present, honor the past, and showcase the future of improvisational theatre, in all of its multi-disciplinary expressions, through local, regional, national, and international prespectives; by presenting and producing performances and workshops for both the general public and practicing improvisational theatre artists.

Part 2: What CIT Would Like to Provide

Better Video Equipment - Currently our cameras are not "top of the line" by any means.  With better funding, we can not only rent or buy better cameras, but also hire the people who know how to run them and shoot the improv to make the students look as good as they are.

Food! - We'd like to be able to provide at least one full meal to all teams during the regional tournament.  The best thing we can do, is keep students in the theatre so that they all watch each other.  The day is packed so tight with teams performing, that often groups must miss a match just to have time to eat lunch.

Water! - Bottled water seems easy, but when you have almost 1,000 participants nationwide, and you need to give each participant at least 2, it starts to add up.  Better funding = better hydration.

Hotel Packages - Many of our groups are traveling at least 3-4 hours to compete in the tournament, and we can foster better connections if we can provide them discouted rates at one hotel.  That way, all the students are staying in one place, and connections can go beyond the theatre!

Rental Cars/Lodging - Right now we need to bring more producers and videographers to each tournament, and we need to finally put them in hotels and get them rental cars.  The responsibility and work that each of these producers puts in should be adaquately resciprocated with adaquate housing and transportation (in the past, producers have used public transit and friends' or strangers' couches-- not ideal).

Trophies for 2nd and 3rd place on a regional level - There are so many good teams now (in part due to the tournament) that more teams should be recognized and rewarded.  

Meals for the Judges - All of our judges are professionals who volunteer their time to help the next generation of improvisers, and we'd like to keep them happy by at least offering them food.

Expense Breakdown

CIT 2012-2013 – 20,000

1 meal for all students involved – $6,000

2 meals for all judges - $360

Accommodations and transportation for 2 producers and 1 videographer – $10,000

Higher quality video of performances - $1,200

Extra videos of performers – $1,200

Hotel package deals in cities for performers - unknown

Water for performers – $700

2nd and 3rd place plaques - $300

Wristbands for all performers - $250

The Impact that CIT Has - Check the VIDEO Testimonials from CIT Alumni at the top!

Many CIT Alumni are currently professional improvisers.  

College Teams give credit to CIT for providing them the motivation to get better.

CIT offers it's alumni the opportunity to work with and improv the tournament.

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you own restraunt in any of our regional cities? Do you know someone who might be willing to donate food on bottled water as a sponsor? Would you like to become a sponsor on our video content/programs/website?  if so, please email CITproducer@gmail.com ASAP!

Our Regionals take place in:

Austin, TX

Boston, MA

Chicago, IL

Los Angeles, CA

San Francisco, CA

Philadelphia, PA

NYC, NY

Atlanta, GA

Kansas City, KS

Seattly, WA

Minneapolis, MN

Indianapolis, IN

If you don't have anything tangible to contribute, just share the campaign to anyone you know so your voices can better be heard.  We're trying to help grow the next generation of comedians.  If we can have your help, we'd sure appreciate it!

story:
About me

I am 29 years-old Peruvian, my passions are sports and travel. I practice basketball, surfing and hiking. Some years ago I have discovered - from my travels and hikes - that I love photography.

I have been working for more than 5 years in Marketing. Now I want to stop for a while, study an MBA, increase my skills and expand my vision. But what I really want is to figure out what I will really want for the future and how I can have a positive impact in society.

I am sharing you my MBA application assignments (Essays / Prezi) and my Website. I think that would help you to know a bit more about myself and my motivations.


About the campaign

I'm far from being a great photographer, but I've taken some nice pictures in my travels - most of them of beautiful Peruvian landscapes. I want to share one of my pictures with every person who helps me complete my MBA budget.

Back in April, I was accepted to a Top 10 MBA program in Madrid. Unfortunately, I was a little late to ask for financial aid from the school. I ended up asking for the money I needed on student loan from my bank in Peru. The period to pay back these loans is only 7 years so the total amount of money I could get from the bank was not enough to pay for my MBA. I am planning to sell all my belonging (including my camera!) to complete my MBA budget, but I still need $6,000 more to cover my living expenses.
I can only promise that as soon as I have a job again I will help others as you are helping me. I can pay this forward!

It would be nice If you can help me with a couple of dollars, everything counts!


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you're unable to contribute money, you can help by spreading the word. If you have any friend who would like to have a nice picture for a few dollars let them know about this campaign.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Willow and I will be turning 15 this coming year, my dream has always been to travel around the world discovering new places and learning about the people there. I have formulated a plan that may allow me to do this at a young age. I plan to travel with an organization to Germany and stay there for 10 months studying abroad. This time overseas will allow me to immerse myself into the modern German culture, and distinguish the exhilarating properties of this foreign country. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • My overall goal for this trip is 25000 this will include program tuition, living expenses, domestic travel, passport fees and visa prices.
  • I am an exceptional student and try to push myself to the max, I am very active and like to be around people, I have many ideas and am eager to learn and desperate to try new things. 
  • If I do not reach my goal I will save it up and try again for next year.

The Impact

This is only the beginning, this trip to Germany with provide a lot of experience that can be utilized in the future, I want to help other kids like me who strive for excellence and search for new things. I want to help other kids in different nations explore all of their options or at least give them more options. How can I do this without understanding where they come from, how they live, what they expect for themselves?

Other Ways You Can Help

Any help is appreciated and getting the word out there is really important. Uploading or linking my campaign to facebook, twitter or tumblr accounts would help a lot. I thank you for everything!

Break it down for folks in more detail:

My overall goal for this trip is 25000 this will include program tuition, living expenses, domestic travel, passport fees and visa prices.
I am an exceptional student and try to push myself to the max, I am very active and like to be around people, I have many ideas and am eager to learn and desperate to try new things. 
If I do not reach my goal I will save it up and try again for next year.



The Impact
This is only the beginning, this trip to Germany with provide a lot of experience that can be utilized in the future, I want to help other kids like me who strive for excellence and search for new things. I want to help other kids in different nations explore all of their options or at least give them more options. How can I do this without understanding where they come from, how they live, what they expect for themselves?


Other Ways You Can Help
Any help is appreciated and getting the word out there is really important. Uploading or linking my campaign to facebook, twitter or tumblr accounts would help a lot. I thank you for everything!

story:
The Missouri Valley College Summer Performing Arts Camp
seeks to provide quality Performing Arts training for youth in the Marshall,
Missouri Area. 

What started in 2010 as an acting camp providing experience with Improv and Shakespeare, has grown into a performing Arts camp offering classes in Acting, Improv, Shakespeare, Dance, and Musical Theatre. 

Up until now the camp has been funded through tuition, but this year we would like to make a change.  We want to offer the camp to more students by making it free for all who wish to participate.  This will allow those students who need exposure to arts participation the most, an opportunity to benefit from this free experience.

This is where you come in.  Your donation will help us cover instructor stipends, administrative costs, and other camp expenses.  This will ensure that every child who has a desire to express themselves through the performing arts will get the opportunity to grow! 

If you want to help, but don't have the financial resources at this time, you can help us by spreading the word of this campaign to others who might be able to give.

If you can help us financially we ask that you also share this with others who might wish to help as well! 

Please invest in the future of the arts in our rural community!

story:
My Story

My name is Meaghann, and I am currently a student at the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee. I am a nursing major, and I one day aspire to be a part of the humanitarian organization, MSF. In order to gain insight on volunteering abroad, I am spending my winter break in a Costa Rican orphanage. My first day in the country will be 1/2/2012, and I will be there for two weeks.

The Impact

Costa Rica on the back of strong resources, a stable Government and increasing tourism is becoming one of the more affluent countries in Central America. However this is causing problems whereby citizens from neighboring countries (such as Nicaragua) are immigrating into Costa Rica, causing an increase in unemployment, homelessness and poverty. The aim of our childcare program is to provide individual attention and assistance to children from difficult backgrounds in Costa Rica. Many children at the projects we work with do not receive the level of affection and education that they deserve, and volunteers therefore play an important role in working alongside local staff to improve the educational, emotional, and hygiene conditions of the children. Volunteers will work in orphanages, community centers, daycare centers, schools, soup kitchens and kindergartens. Work varies but generally consists of providing individual attention, sharing affection with children, paying with children, organizing games and activities, educating children regarding hygiene and assisting with home work.

What I Need

I need to raise enough money to pay for the registration fee ($220), the program fee ($550), insurance ($100), airfare ($600), and transportation to the airport from the orphange. I need approximately $1,500, anything above this limit I will donate directly the the orphanage I am placed in.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help me raise money by getting the word out by sharing this with anyone who may be interested in helping me!

story:
What We're All About

My name is Johnel Barron aka “Mr. B,” founder and creator of the Teach Me How To Study™ Program an element of my larger entity iSTRIVE, a multimedia movement dedicated to the guiding principles of service, hope and achievement for the millennial generation.

 

My belief: Without education, success is impossible.

 

Over the past 12 months, I’ve brought the Teach Me How To Study™ motivational message with its tools for success in schools to 6,000 students live and in person in Los Angeles and Atlanta. But that is only the start! With your support, over the next 18 months, I can reach millions of students across the country via the Teach Me How To Study™ Tour.

 

My organization’s aim is to motivate, inspire and educate students in high school to not just start school, but to finish. To encourage lifelong learning. College may not be for everyone, but learning is.

 

I just want to shout this message from the rooftops!

 

I want to bring this message to the masses!

 

This Is For The Community 

Every year 1.2 million students drop out of high school and over 54% of students that start college, do not finish. By motivating student audiences to focus on their studies and to realize that it’s not just for school that we learn, it’s for life, we will fulfill our mission of creating and nurturing tomorrow’s leaders today.

We help students launch from school and land in life.

Public education in America is at a crossroads. The current system is too expensive to sustain and it does not consistently provide students with the skills they need to be responsible, contributing citizens in today’s global community. And yet we know that the educators, parents and students want it to be different. We believe that with the Teach Me How To Study™ Program when you inspire the heart, the hands and feet will follow.

 

Teach Me How To Study™ is a national movement leveraging leadership, life skills, mentoring and educational programming. Teach Me How To Study™ offers a variety of programming options designed specifically for schools and educational organizations. We conduct workshops for educators who seek to improve their interpersonal working environments. In addition, we offer programs for students in the form of team building workshops, youth adventure programming and inspirational speaking engagements.

 

Bottom line: We target high school and college students to promote drop-out prevention, improve GPAs and test scores, and encourage them to graduate from college. 

Specifically, the Teach Me How To Study™ mentoring program is helping raise student achievement by assisting public schools and local efforts across the country to implement an effective, comprehensive student support model that is based upon scientifically-based research and effective practices.

 

That is what the Teach Me How To Study™ Tour is all about! Putting the focus back on education. Keeping the students from getting frustrated so they can finish school and have fun doing it! 

 

It Has to Start Somewhere

It is our goal is to reach millions of students across the country through the teachings of this program. We’re not kidding! Plans are in the works. Conversations are buzzing across the country. But a national tour has to start somewhere and that somewhere is promotion.

 

 

This $15,000 cash infusion will allow us to focus on the foundation:

 

  • Website revisions to include free study resources for students of all ages

 

  • Website revisions to include special college preparation section for students and families

 

  • Video promo production

 

  • Travel to critical corporate sponsorship meetings

 

  • Deposits for our kickoff event

 

  • Creation of promotional packages for key stakeholder   conversations

 

This $15,000 is only a fraction of what we will need to create this incredible national tour. However, we are a resourceful team with a remarkable network of people like you who have stepped up to share this message with your community. Your support is what helps us to stretch this $15,000 farther than we could all ever imagine.

 

 

Join The Movement
 

Here’s our plan. Raise $15,000 in 5 mini-campaigns of 15 days each! Bold we know - but as we tell the kids, anything is possible! Help us move closer to the national tour starting in early 2012.

 

With these mini-campaigns, we can keep the excitement high, build a community of people interested in national education (like YOU!), and build the foundation for the tour stops to be announced later this year.

 

Spread The Word

 

This movement will touch the hearts of students, their families and their educators all across the country.

 

Help us share the movement with:

 

People who love children

People who have children

People who know children

People who love to study

People who want students to have the tools they need to study

People interested in joining the dialogue about national education

People who want to see students excited about learning

People who want to see students stay in school

 

Do you know anyone who fits into one of these categories?

 

  • Share this IndieGoGo link. Join the conversation on social media.

 

  • Email your friends!

 

  • “Like” us on Facebook – This is Johnel’s Fan Page ~ “Mr. B”!

 

  • Johnel’s Personal Facebook Page is another place to start a dialogue!

 

  • Tweet with us and about us. Follow the story as it builds.

 

  • Twitter! @johnelbarron

 

  • Check out “Mr. B” at www.johnelbarron.com


 

SHARE SHARE SHARE…THANK YOU!

story:
Touching Stories brings storytelling to life for people with developmental disabilities by integrating a variety of multisensory stimuli into each story kit.

 

Who we help

Stories are how we know our world -- they are the way we learn about each other and the way we learn about ourselves. For people with significant development disabilities, the world can be too small and too quiet because they don't have the language for stories.

 

What are "Touching Stories?"

Touching Stories helps people communicate and connect with others through story. We have been telling special, multi-sensory stories to adults and kids with developmental disabilities since 2011. The story kits we create allow people to enter the world of story through things they touch, smell and manipulate. When we tell these tales we see their faces light up as they understand and connect with our stories, and it's an amazing gift.

 

Who we are

We are a small non-profit organization, made up entirely of people who donate our time, energy and resources to making these stories happen. But we need your help. We want to continue to provide our unique stories to as many people as possible, and we are looking for your support to fund ten new story kits to be distributed to day programs, schools and libraries so that more people can know and hear our stories.

These kits, made of high-quality materials mounted to sturdy canvas boards are costly to create. We spend hundreds of both dollars and hours developing new stories that will engage, delight and teach the special people we serve. Any funds donated above our funding goal means more story kits we are able to donate to a waiting school or agency.

We want our program to be available to anyone who can benefit. We donate our story kits to agencies that serve people with developmental disabilities so that these stories can be told over and over again. Each kit comes with 2 stories and a dvd which quickly and easily demonstrates how to use each of the manipulatives. The training video is an essential piece of each kit, so that those telling the story can learn how to tell them in the same way every time. Through repetition, people with developmental disabilities can increase their vocabulary, understand communication, learn to predict what will happen next, and make connection to the stories within their own experience.

 

We are the only organization in the United States doing this work

If we can't tell the stories, they simply won't ever be told, and the world for people with developmental disabiltiies will remain a little smaller; a little quieter.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The money you donate will help us develop, produce and distribute free of charge 10 Touching Stories kits. Developing stories that integrate all of the senses while working within the limitations faced by people with developmental disabilities involves a lot of trial and error, but once created, these kits can be replicated and made available at a much lower cost. Each Kit contains 2 new stories and a training video. These ten kits can bring story to hundreds of people who have never been part of the world of story before. In addition, your donation will help us produce training videos so that those who work and live with people with disabilities can learn how to tell these stories. This instructional video allows us to get these stories in more hands and allows many more people to benefit from our stories.

What your money pays for:

$7500 for the development, production and distribution of new stories with a unique training video for each new story.

$1500 to replicate and distribute additional story kits and videos. Each dollar we make in excess of our goal helps us get that many more story kits in to that many more hands.

We want the people we help to know who is helping us! As a supporter of this program you’ll be recognized for your donation: a credit on our videos... your company's name and logo on one of our story kit pages... or on the bags that our story kits come in. With some donations, we'll even name a title character after someone special for you and let you decide who will get the story kits!

We are a 501(c)(3) charity, which means donations to our campaign can be tax-deductible --CHOOSE THE PAYPAL OPTION WHEN MAKING YOUR DONATION TO RECEIVE YOUR TAX DEDUCTION.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to your donation, you can help us by letting people know about this amazing program and us! Please visit our website: www.touchingstories.org watch our videos at: http://www.youtube.com/user/OurTouchingStories Like us on Facebook:http://www.facebook.com/pages/Touching-Stories/...

And share!

story:
In 2012, under threat from fundamentalist rebels, a team of archivists, librarians, and couriers evacuated an irreplaceable trove of manuscripts from Timbuktu at great personal risk. The manuscripts have been saved from immediate destruction, but the danger is not over. A massive archival effort is needed to protect this immense global heritage from loss.

THE STORY OF THE MANUSCRIPTS IS NOT OVER! ******************************************

Thank you all our Indiegogo friends. Your efforts are helping to preserve a priceless heritage for the entire world. OUR WORK IS NOT DONE! The danger to the manuscripts is still urgent. To learn more about how we are continuing our efforts and to contribute, visit our web site at http://t160k.org and follow us on Twitter @T160k.

We will continue to keep you informed of how your contributions are helping to preserve the manuscripts. Sorry, we cannot offer Indiegogo perks now that the crowdfunding campaign is over.

*********************************************************************************************************

Abdel Kader Haidara has been steward of his family's library since age 17

Though removed from immediate threat, the manuscripts are still jam packed in footlockers used for their evacuation and the current environment of this precious world heritage is significantly more humid than Timbuktu. There are already signs of damage and exposure to moisture.  

The purpose of this campaign is to fund the preservation effort required to store the manuscripts in an archival, moisture-resistant manner during their exile from Timbuktu.  If physical harm from the current packing situation continues and if mold and mildew  spread in the corpus due to increased humidity, the damage will be devastating.

Timbuktu is a traditional center of peace, learning, and scholarship

By contributing, you are directly funding the archival materials and labor required to save these works. In recognition of your support, we can ensure that your name or a personal dedication will be associated with these works in perpetuity, and we will provide you with a token of your contribution to keep as an enduring memento.

This is a legacy that will continue to enrich our world, with the potential to advance the causes of peace and good governance in Africa and the world for generations.

About the Libraries in Exile Project

Libraries in Exile is sponsored by T160K, an international initiative forged in the evacuation of these treasures from Timbuktu and dedicated to protecting and preserving them until they can be returned to their home. It is the center of a growing global family who have pledged to this urgent effort.

Funds contributed to this project will be used to purchase moisture traps, archival boxes, and the additional footlockers required to safely store these manuscripts, as well as to cover the significant labor effort required to unbox and re-pack the manuscripts for preservation.

Tamasheq craftsmen learning book and paper conservation

How your contribution makes a difference

There are over 300,000 unique manuscripts to be saved. We know this is an immense task, but remember that each $30 contribution means the rescue of another irreplaceable treasure.

The corpus of manuscripts is incredibly varied and beautiful

All supporters will receive a personalized digital certificate symbolizing your participation in this great adventure suitable for high-resolution printing and framing. You will also be listed as a supporter on the T160K web site.

A contribution of $30 pays the materials and labor costs required to preserve a single manuscript wrapped in a protective moisture trap and stored in its own archival box. These are objects of amazing beauty and represent a tangible benefit to all of humankind.  All supporters at $30 and higher will have a personal dedication and a small photo affixed to the box of the manuscripts they helped save, a permanent legacy to your contribution.

In addition, any backer may add to their pledge, in increments of $30, and we will add their dedication to more manuscripts boxes as more are preserved.

Every $30 contributed is another manuscript preserved

Master photographer and long-time student of Timbuktu Joseph Hunwick is donating five beautiful large-size photographic prints of Timbuktu and the manuscripts to our campaign! These are avaialble as perks at the $500 level. The prints are gorgeously printed by the photographer using archival inks and museum-quality paper.

With contribution of $1000 we will send you a collection of high-quality archival 8x10 prints of photos in our collection. You can see several of these photos on this page and in the campaign gallery.

We are able to offer a limited number of original illuminated artworks featuring calligraphy by a Timbuktu craftsman using techniques and materials similar to those used to create the manuscripts. We will discuss your art selection with you. It may be a selection from one of the libraries or something of personal meaning to you.

To preserve an entire footlocker, including the materials and labor, is a commitment that not everybody can bear, but if you have this ability and feel the call to help, your contribution will pay for the full costs and materials to preserve the contents of one of the footlockers evacuated from Timbuktu. Each footlocker contains 300 manuscripts on average. This represents a significant legacy for future culture and scholarship. We thank you. If you are able to support us at this level, we will also  send you a selection of photo prints from our collection and a personal letter of thanks.

We are also able to offer a limited number of Skype conversations, personal conversations, and speaking engagements with Stephanie Diakité who has been personally involved with the preservation and evacuation efforts.

Finally, we can offer an amazing adventure--the opportunity to visit the manuscripts in person in Mali. This entails some risk in the current political situation. We will need to vett you for security purposes and you will be required to sign a waiver and cover your own travel expenses.

And anybody can contribute by spreading the word and telling others about the work we are doing.

The libraries of Timbuktu

The corpus of Timbuktu dates back for generations, with numerous private libraries that have been handed down from generation to generation for over 700 years, creating a record of commerce, poetry, scholarship, law, and everyday life that has undiminished power to teach and inspire today. The libraries include manuscripts form Andalusia and Southern Europe, Arabia, Egypt, the Arab trading ports on the Indian Ocean, and Morocco and other centers of medieval learning, as well as the region of Timbuktu itself. Timbuktu is a traditional crossroads of culture and has played a peacekeeper role in the region. The manuscripts chronicle this role. They represent an astounding diversity of topics and authors, including a significant number of women’s voices.

A book of genealogy

A cultural heritage of this magnitude has incredible power to bring people together. We saw this power when people from all walks of life, whole villages, and speakers of every language in the region gave their time and effort, even under considerable risk, to help us evacuate them to the south. We believe that securing these manuscripts is a positive step towards a process of enduring peace and a reduced toll of human misery for this entire region.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can give monetarily as much as they would like, but you can still contribute. Please help us support this project by spreading the word about this campaign, sharing it using the Indiegogo sharing tools, and telling others the story of the libraries of Timbuktu. We can also use volunteers to help get the word out about our work. Please visit our web site at http://T160K.org/ if you would like to register to volunteer.

Thank You, Corporate Sponsors

Creekside Digital: Top-Quality Scanning of Books, Newspapers & Microfilm 

In the Press

Spiegel Online, Vor Islamisten gerettet, vom Schimmel bedroht

The HuffingtonPost, France, Trésor culturel en péril: sauvons les manuscrits de Tombouctou

Christian Science Monitor, 'Libraries in Exile' fights to save priceless manuscripts in Mali

The Guardian Books, Librarians in Exile Group Launches Appeal to Save Timbuktu Manuscripts

StarAfrica.com, You can Save the Manuscripts, Interview with Abdel Kader Haidara and Stéphanie Diakité


The Next Web, 300,000 ancient manuscripts were saved from rebels in Timbuktu, but now face a slow death by rot

CNN, "Saved from Islamists, Timbuktu's manuscripts face new threat."

The New Republic, “The Bibliophiles of Timbuktu: How a Team of Sneaky Librarians Duped Al Qaeda and Saved Some of the Ancient World’s Greatest Artifacts.”

University of Oregon Video, “Stephanie Diakité – “The Evacuation of the Timbuktu Manuscripts and Their Life in Exile: The Work of T160K”

Frequently Asked Questions

The Indiegogo campaign is over. Can I still contribute?

We are still actively seeking contributions to preserve the manuscripts. Visit our web site at t160k.org to learn more. Unfortunately, we cannot offer Indiegogo perks now that the campaign is over. We are urgently working to fulfill all the requests and ship the much-needed materials to Mali.

Is my contribution tax deductible? By choice our work does not have tax exempt status anywhere except in Mali. This means that we will pay taxes on contributions made outside Mali and that people who kindly contribute to our work from outside Mali cannot claim a tax deduction for their financial contributions.  

How does the illuminated manuscripts giveaway work? For our last week on Indiegogo we’re giving away one of our unclaimed high-level perks to one supporter: an original, customized piece of illuminated art. This art will be created using generational techniques by a Malian craftsman living in exile like the manuscripts. To participate, you must contribute to this campaign at the $30 level or higher and share your dedication or a message of support on a social media site with the #T160K tag. On Facebook, simply like and share our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/T160k) with the #T160K hashtag. If you’re sharing on another network, please email us at contactt160k@gmail.com and let us know where so we can add you to the list. People employed by T160K, campaign volunteers, or individuals working directly with us on this campaign or their families are not eligible to receive this reward. We will select one person at random to receive the reward. ABOUT THE REWARD: you will receive a hand-made piece of illuminated calligraphy on a theme of your choice drawn from the content of the manuscripts themselves. We will work with you to select your theme and a suitable excerpt.

I want to help! We can always use your help! To volunteer your time or expertise, please register through our web site http://T160K.org/. 

Can I feature your story in my blog or publication? Absolutely! We have a collection of images and information that you can use on our web site. Please feel free to contact us as well if we can help in any way.

Are you available for interviews? There has already been a lot of interest from the press in this project, and we are happy to help out in any way. Send us a message, and we’ll respond to you right away.

What does T160k mean? Early in the evacuation, when there was little help coming from outside Timbuktu, a timely contribution from an unexpected donor enabled us to save the first 160,000 manuscripts. We named our initiative in memory of that event: T for Timbuktu, 160k for the first 160,000 manuscripts.

Are there any plans to digitize these manuscripts? Efforts to digitize the manuscripts have been ongoing, but they have been interrupted by the current violent uprising. The manuscripts are composed of extremely fragile papers and unstable ferrous inks which literally burn when exposed to traditional "hot light" scanning processes. A significant number of manuscripts have already been scanned using cold circuit photography. It’s our dream to provide for the long-term preservation and digitization of these manuscripts once they are out of immediately danger.

Have the manuscripts been removed from Mali? The manuscripts currently reside in Mali, where they have resided for 700 or more years, and we believe they should remain there.  Everything possible will be done to ensure this. 

What proportion of the funds collected is going to preservation and how are they being managed? Funds donated to this campaign will go directly to covering materials and labor costs associated with preservation, minus the amount required to cover required Indiegogo and PayPal fees as well as the fulfillment of the contributor perks described above. We project fulfillment costs to be 10% of the total funds collected or less. We are paying a fixed fee for assistance in fund raising and no part of the funds collected for this campaign are going to the fund raiser. Abdel Kader Haidara and Stephanie Diakité and their respective organizations will be managing the funds to ensure that the preservation effort uses them as effectively as possible and to the highest standards.

Why are you using crowdfunding to fund this need? The need to preserve the manuscripts is urgent. We can’t wait for governments and organizations with deep pockets to respond to this need. It is through the efforts of ordinary people that the manuscripts have been preserved this long, and that they have survived the violence affecting Mali today. Crowdfunding is enabling of participation and we believe this is a key to the sustainable safeguarding of the manuscripts. Organizations that wish to partner with us in this effort should contact us at contactt160k@gmail.com.

Who is T160K? We are dedicated to the protection, preservation and study of the ancient manuscripts of Timbuktu. Our long-term vision is the return of the manuscripts to their home in Timbuktu and to apply the vast knowledge they contain to the peace process in Mali and in other places in Africa. T160K was co-founded by Stephanie Diakité, JC-JD/MBA/Phd and Abdel Kader Haidara.

Stephanie Diakité, JC-JD/MBA/Phd is a jurist and a poverty eradication institutional development specialist working in more than 40 countries in sub-Saharan Africa through her firm, D intl (see http://dintlafrica.com/) and a book artist and book and paper conservation specialist.  

Abdel Kader Haidara is the generational curator of one of the most important libraries of manuscripts in Timbuktu and founder of SAVAMA DCI (see http://www.savamadci.net), an association of private Timbuktu libraries committed to public access.

For more information, visit our web site: http://T160K.org/.
story_txt:
In 2012, under threat from fundamentalist rebels, a team of archivists, librarians, and couriers evacuated an irreplaceable trove of manuscripts from Timbuktu at great personal risk. The manuscripts have been saved from immediate destruction, but the danger is not over. A massive archival effort is needed to protect this immense global heritage from loss.
THE STORY OF THE MANUSCRIPTS IS NOT OVER! ******************************************
Thank you all our Indiegogo friends. Your efforts are helping to preserve a priceless heritage for the entire world. OUR WORK IS NOT DONE! The danger to the manuscripts is still urgent. To learn more about how we are continuing our efforts and to contribute, visit our web site at http://t160k.org and follow us on Twitter @T160k.
We will continue to keep you informed of how your contributions are helping to preserve the manuscripts. Sorry, we cannot offer Indiegogo perks now that the crowdfunding campaign is over.
*********************************************************************************************************

Abdel Kader Haidara has been steward of his family's library since age 17
Though removed from immediate threat, the manuscripts are still jam packed in footlockers used for their evacuation and the current environment of this precious world heritage is significantly more humid than Timbuktu. There are already signs of damage and exposure to moisture.  
The purpose of this campaign is to fund the preservation effort required to store the manuscripts in an archival, moisture-resistant manner during their exile from Timbuktu.  If physical harm from the current packing situation continues and if mold and mildew  spread in the corpus due to increased humidity, the damage will be devastating.

Timbuktu is a traditional center of peace, learning, and scholarship
By contributing, you are directly funding the archival materials and labor required to save these works. In recognition of your support, we can ensure that your name or a personal dedication will be associated with these works in perpetuity, and we will provide you with a token of your contribution to keep as an enduring memento.
This is a legacy that will continue to enrich our world, with the potential to advance the causes of peace and good governance in Africa and the world for generations.
About the Libraries in Exile Project
Libraries in Exile is sponsored by T160K, an international initiative forged in the evacuation of these treasures from Timbuktu and dedicated to protecting and preserving them until they can be returned to their home. It is the center of a growing global family who have pledged to this urgent effort.
Funds contributed to this project will be used to purchase moisture traps, archival boxes, and the additional footlockers required to safely store these manuscripts, as well as to cover the significant labor effort required to unbox and re-pack the manuscripts for preservation.

Tamasheq craftsmen learning book and paper conservation
How your contribution makes a difference
There are over 300,000 unique manuscripts to be saved. We know this is an immense task, but remember that each $30 contribution means the rescue of another irreplaceable treasure.

The corpus of manuscripts is incredibly varied and beautiful
All supporters will receive a personalized digital certificate symbolizing your participation in this great adventure suitable for high-resolution printing and framing. You will also be listed as a supporter on the T160K web site.
A contribution of $30 pays the materials and labor costs required to preserve a single manuscript wrapped in a protective moisture trap and stored in its own archival box. These are objects of amazing beauty and represent a tangible benefit to all of humankind.  All supporters at $30 and higher will have a personal dedication and a small photo affixed to the box of the manuscripts they helped save, a permanent legacy to your contribution.
In addition, any backer may add to their pledge, in increments of $30, and we will add their dedication to more manuscripts boxes as more are preserved.

Every $30 contributed is another manuscript preserved
Master photographer and long-time student of Timbuktu Joseph Hunwick is donating five beautiful large-size photographic prints of Timbuktu and the manuscripts to our campaign! These are avaialble as perks at the $500 level. The prints are gorgeously printed by the photographer using archival inks and museum-quality paper.
With contribution of $1000 we will send you a collection of high-quality archival 8x10 prints of photos in our collection. You can see several of these photos on this page and in the campaign gallery.
We are able to offer a limited number of original illuminated artworks featuring calligraphy by a Timbuktu craftsman using techniques and materials similar to those used to create the manuscripts. We will discuss your art selection with you. It may be a selection from one of the libraries or something of personal meaning to you.
To preserve an entire footlocker, including the materials and labor, is a commitment that not everybody can bear, but if you have this ability and feel the call to help, your contribution will pay for the full costs and materials to preserve the contents of one of the footlockers evacuated from Timbuktu. Each footlocker contains 300 manuscripts on average. This represents a significant legacy for future culture and scholarship. We thank you. If you are able to support us at this level, we will also  send you a selection of photo prints from our collection and a personal letter of thanks.
We are also able to offer a limited number of Skype conversations, personal conversations, and speaking engagements with Stephanie Diakité who has been personally involved with the preservation and evacuation efforts.
Finally, we can offer an amazing adventure--the opportunity to visit the manuscripts in person in Mali. This entails some risk in the current political situation. We will need to vett you for security purposes and you will be required to sign a waiver and cover your own travel expenses.
And anybody can contribute by spreading the word and telling others about the work we are doing.
The libraries of Timbuktu
The corpus of Timbuktu dates back for generations, with numerous private libraries that have been handed down from generation to generation for over 700 years, creating a record of commerce, poetry, scholarship, law, and everyday life that has undiminished power to teach and inspire today. The libraries include manuscripts form Andalusia and Southern Europe, Arabia, Egypt, the Arab trading ports on the Indian Ocean, and Morocco and other centers of medieval learning, as well as the region of Timbuktu itself. Timbuktu is a traditional crossroads of culture and has played a peacekeeper role in the region. The manuscripts chronicle this role. They represent an astounding diversity of topics and authors, including a significant number of women’s voices.

A book of genealogy
A cultural heritage of this magnitude has incredible power to bring people together. We saw this power when people from all walks of life, whole villages, and speakers of every language in the region gave their time and effort, even under considerable risk, to help us evacuate them to the south. We believe that securing these manuscripts is a positive step towards a process of enduring peace and a reduced toll of human misery for this entire region.
Other Ways You Can Help
Not everyone can give monetarily as much as they would like, but you can still contribute. Please help us support this project by spreading the word about this campaign, sharing it using the Indiegogo sharing tools, and telling others the story of the libraries of Timbuktu. We can also use volunteers to help get the word out about our work. Please visit our web site at http://T160K.org/ if you would like to register to volunteer.
Thank You, Corporate Sponsors

Creekside Digital: Top-Quality Scanning of Books, Newspapers & Microfilm
